Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Attention: Education Service.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

I have your letter of the 10th instant regarding the request made by Reverend Father J. Brachet, Principal of the McIntosh Indian Residential School, for a small boat.

I quite understand that your Department has spent a large amount of money for the construction of the road from the school to the station of McIntosh and that it is also yearly spending a fairly large sum for its maintenance.

But there is a problem of recruitment which must not be forgotten at McIntosh. All the reserves that send students to this school are north of it and there are no roads of any kind which can be used. For recruiting purposes a boat is therefore essential.

So that the Department would not be put to too much expense, I forwarded to Father Brachet the letter that I received from the Peterborough Canoe Co., and told him to select the cheapest boat capable of doing his recruitment. Personally, I would have advised him a much more expensive one, but he chose a 15 ft. boat without a canopy and powered with an out-board motor. That is possibly, the cheapest boat that you ever purchased for a residential school. I therefore hope that you may want to reconsider your decision.

Thanking you in anticipation, I remain,

Yours very truly,

J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.

Dear Sir:

We feel very anxious that the work on the proposed Indian Boarding School at Mc Intosh may begin early in the spring. We have inspected for a good location and come now to propose to You and to the Department a site for said Indian Boarding School.

This land is situated in the Province of Ontario, 3 miles more or less North of the station of Mc Intosh, on the C.N.R. (G.T.P.) line, and may be described as Concession L.K.175, a regular quarter Section, 160 acres, and concession L.K.174 of similar size and immediately adjoining the former.

This land was surveyed by Mr A. Mc Meekin, residing at 216 Main Street, Kenora Ont., an Ont. land surveyor, for a certain Mr Wilson of Winnipeg. This land however has been abandoned several years and can now be considered as Crown Land. I however advised Mrs Wilson of our intention to take same for the Indian School.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6220, file 472-9, part 1)
Hoping the Department shall not experience any difficulty in getting this site, which is a good farming land and very suitable to our purpose,

I remain, Dear Sir:

Your humble servant:

J.B. REYS O.M.I.
Provincial
January 4th, 1924.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Superintendent General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

I am advised by Rev. Father Reys of the Oblate Fathers that he has chosen as a suitable site for an Indian School certain lands near McIntosh, Ontario, comprising 320 acres more or less, and being known as Locations L.K. 174 and 175 Canyon Lake.

I am acting for Mrs. Margaret Wilson of this city who is interested in the property. The property was surveyed for her late husband James A. Wilson the intention being that one-quarter section would be occupied by Mr. Wilson and the other quarter by his son William Wilson. Some improvements were made on the property but the son went away to the war, and was killed at the front. Mr. Wilson Sr. was killed accidentally on the C.N.R. in the early part of 1918. Owing to these happenings Mrs. Wilson was unable to go into occupation of the property.

Mrs. Wilson is prepared to release all claim to the property upon payment of $775.00. Out of this amount she would pay the price of the land asked by the Ontario Government, namely $1.00 per acre. There are also expenses of surveying which are still unpaid. These would also be paid from the said amount. As Mrs. Wilson's solicitor I would undertake to obtain from her a Quit Claim Deed or such other documents as may be necessary to release her claim, and would also undertake to see that the said accounts are paid before handing any balance over to Mrs. Wilson.

I may say that in 1916 I had certain correspondence with the Department of Lands, Forests & Mines at Toronto with a view to obtaining title to the properties for Mrs. Wilson without the necessity of performing the usual homestead duties. The Department did not agree to this but they stated that they would consent to Mrs. Wilson disposing of her interest in the land to any other party who would undertake to do the settlement duties. I presume therefore that there would be no difficulty in arranging the matter satisfactorily.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Ottawa, 28th January 1924

Sir,

This Department has been considering establishing an Indian school near McIntosh, Ontario, and one of the sites which would appear favourable for this purpose is the 320 acres comprising locations 174 and 175, Canyon Lake.

Would you be good enough to inform me if these locations are now recorded as Provincial Crown Lands or if the fee has passed to private individuals? In event of the fee having passed from the Crown, kindly advise me as to the name and address of the party or parties from whom it would be necessary to obtain title to this property.

Your obedient servant,

SUMMER RESORT REGULATIONS

1. Crown Lands in each district and localities as may be considered advisable in the discretion of the Minister may be purchased by the Provincial Government for the purpose of resort purposes or other similar purposes, subject to the following regulations:

2. Where surveys have been made, no such location shall be laid out except where the surveyor has reported that the land is suitable for the purpose intended.

3. Where surveys have not been made, the location shall be laid out by the surveyor appointed by the Minister, who shall report whether the land is suitable for the purpose intended.

4. On other islands the price shall be $50.00 per acre, including all costs incurred by the Crown, such costs included within the survey of the Provincial Government surveyors.

5. If an application is made for the subdivision of any parcel of land containing less than five acres, the Minister may consider the subdivision of such parcel, but if the area is considered unsuitable for subdivision, the Minister may refuse to make the subdivision.

6. The Crown reserves the right to subdivide any parcel of land containing more than five acres, and such subdivision shall be made at such prices as may be deemed advisable by the Minister.

7. The purchase price of surveyed land shall be paid before the date fixed by the Minister, and if payment is not made within six weeks from the acceptance of the offer, the sale shall be cancelled and the land returned to the Crown.

8. If a building is erected on any parcel of land containing less than five acres, the sale shall be cancelled and the land returned to the Crown.

9. If a building is erected on any parcel of land containing more than five acres, the sale shall be cancelled and the land returned to the Crown.

10. If a building is erected on any parcel of land containing more than five acres, the sale shall be cancelled and the land returned to the Crown.

11. All lands shall be sold subject to the provisions of the Act, and any special regulations which may hereafter be made regarding the sale of lands.

12. The sale of timber shall be reserved to the Crown with the consent of the Minister, and the sale of timber shall be subject to the provisions of the Act.

Toronto, January 15th, 1924.

Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 13th inst. in reference to obtaining a school site at McIntosh for an Indian school, I have to say that locations L K 174 and 175 were squatted on by James A. Wilson who had them surveyed as farm locations. The locations lie within the English River Pulp Limit and Mr. Wilson, the squatter on the lands, died and his widow has not been able to procure the lands.

In any event, the Department would not consider granting so large an area for a school site and if your Department desire to procure 5 acres in that vicinity for school site purposes it may be taken up under the regulations regarding the disposal of summer resorts, trading posts and other lots required in small areas.

I enclose you a copy of these regulations for your information.

Yours truly,

Deputy Minister Lands and Forests

J.D. McLenn Esq.,
Acting Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6220, file 472-9, part 1)
Ottawa, Jan. 18, 1924.

Sir:

I have your No. 9765 of the 15th instant, relative to this Department's application for a school site near McIntosh. I have to state, in reply, that the intention is to erect an Indian residential school, and, as the pupils are taught farming, gardening and the care of stock, it is important that adequate facilities for such training are provided. At other institutions of this type as much as 1000 acres is used for school purposes.

It would be to this Department's advantage to secure locations L K 174 and 175 and I should be pleased if you would indicate what steps will be necessary to arrange title.

I note that the heirs of Mr. J. A. Wilson, who was a squatter and who had the lands surveyed, may have an adverse claim and you might inform me whether it would be better to have the Department of Indian Affairs settle this claim or whether this could be adjusted by your office.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

MEMO FOR FILE:

Father Boyer, of Father Boys' Office, St. Boniface, called at the Department and mentioned that they were not altogether satisfied with the proposed site for the McIntosh Indian Residential School. He suggests that the Department ascertain if the property mentioned on the telegram hereunder is available.

I am of the opinion that the matter of securing a site should not be hurried until the Church Authorities have made up their minds as to where they actually want the school to be. The town plot mentioned in the telegram is adjoining the station of Quibell.

R. W. O.
Toronto, April 23rd, 1924.

Dear Sir:-

Re locations L X 174 and 176.

Referring to your letter of the 18th January, 1924, and the application of the Department of Indian Affairs to secure the above mentioned farm locations which were surveyed on behalf of one J.A. Wilson, situate in the district of Kenora; I have to state that your application has been given favorable consideration.

The lands may be disposed of to the Department of Indian Affairs to be used for the purpose of Indian residential school at $5 per acre provided your Department makes a settlement with the Wilson family who, I think, may be found through their legal representatives in Winnipeg, Messrs. Farquhar, Myers, Hastings & McNabb, 406 Sterling Bank Bldg., Winnipeg, Man. If no settlement can be arrived at with the Wilson family a sale may be carried out at $5 per acre cash.

Yours truly,

W.C. Cain
Deputy Minister Lands and Forests.

APPROVED BY HIS HONOUR THE LIEUTENANT-GOVERNOR,
THE 16TH DAY OF JANUARY, A.D. 1907.

Upon the recommendation of the Honourable the Minister of
Lands, Forests and Mines, the Committee of Council advise that
Regulations adopted by Order-in-Council of 21st June, 1898, under
St. Victoria, chapter 8, entitled "An Act respecting Water Powers,"
be rescinded, and that the annexed Regulations be adopted in their
stead.

The Committee further advise that the accompanying form of
lease be approved for leases of water powers issued under the said
Act and Regulations, subject to such changes as may be necessary
and authorized in individual cases.

Certified,

J. LONEDALE CAPREOL,
Clerk, Executive Council.

REGULATIONS RE WATER POWERS.

1. These rules and regulations shall not apply to water privileges
which in their natural condition at the average low stage of water
have not greater capacity than 150 horse power.

2. In granting or leasing, otherwise than under these regula-
tions, any Crown Lands upon which a water privilege is situated,
or which may be flooded or overflowed in consequence of the
development and utilization thereof, the said privilege shall be
reserved to the Crown, together with such an area of land in
connection therewith as shall in the opinion of the Minister be required for the proper development of the same, and the construction of all necessary dams, weirs, tunnels, races, flumes, sluices, pits and other structures or works, and the erection of buildings and fences on the said lands and premises or any part thereof, and storing grounds and yards in connection therewith; and there shall also be reserved in any such grant or lease, the right to flood any portion of the lands so granted or leased upon compensation to be made to the owner or lessee thereof by the person or persons to whom the privilege may afterwards belong, and the said water privilege, land and rights so reserved shall form a separate property and may be dealt with as hereinafter provided.

3. The right to lay out and use such roads as may be necessary for the passage to and from such water privilege or land shall be reserved in all grants or leases of contiguous or adjoining lands.

4. The applicant for a water privilege situated on Crown Lands shall file in the Department of Lands, Forests and Mines, a plan and field notes by an Ontario Land Surveyor of survey thereof; and also a report by a competent engineer satisfactory to the Minister showing:

(a) The location of the water privilege applied for, and a description of the land required in connection therewith.

(b) The height of the fall or rapid, the volume of water at the average high and low stages of same, the estimated capacity in horse power of the fall or rapid in its natural condition at the average low stage of water, the height of the dams or weirs (if any) which it is proposed to construct, and the increase in the level of the water which such dams or weirs will bring about.

(c) The plan by which the applicant proposes to develop the water privilege, showing the dams, weirs, tunnels, races, flumes, sluices, pits and other structures or works, and the manner to build or make in connection therewith, the estimated cost thereof, and the form in which the power is to be used or transmitted, that is, whether by direct energy, electricity, compressed air, etc.

(d) The land or lands which would be overflowed or otherwise affected by the raising of the water or the construction of the dams, weirs, sluices, races or other works in connection with the development or use of such water privilege, and the owner or owners thereof.

The applicant shall also show the nature and location of the business, plant or manufactory in connection with which it is proposed by the applicant to utilize the water privilege, and the number of hands employed in the privilege to be developed and utilize, and shall furnish proof satisfactory to the Minister that the said water privilege is required for the applicant's own mechanical or industrial purposes or to supply an actual or anticipated demand for power in the neighbourhood of the privilege.

Provided that the Minister may dispense with the requirements of any of the preceding clauses of this regulation in case the information, plans, etc., required to be furnished are already in the possession of the Department of Lands, Forests and Mines.

5. If so required by the Minister, the applicant shall furnish at his own expense all such measurements, plans, specifications, descriptions, levels, elevations, locations and other information he may deem necessary for the proper consideration of the application; and the applicant shall also, if required, submit to the Hydro-Electric Power Commission of Ontario the plans and specifications showing the proposed works for the development of the said privilege, and such works shall not be proceeded with until the said Power Commission has approved the same.

6. The applicant shall submit such proof of his financial standing and ability and intentions to develop the said water privilege as shall be satisfactory to the Minister.

7. Before the lease of a water power is granted the Minister may require the applicant to deposit with the Treasurer of the Province a sum of money to be named by the Minister, conditional upon the carrying out of the works of construction and development specified in the lease within the period therein named; such sum to be returned to the lessee upon the due performance of such condition, or to be transferred to His Majesty the King for the use of the Province of Ontario.

8. Upon compliance with the foregoing regulations and upon approval of the application by the Minister in writing he may order a lease of the water privilege to be issued to the applicant upon such terms and conditions and at such rental as may be fixed by the Minister. The rental reserved by any such lease or any renewal thereof shall be payable yearly in advance.

9. No such lease shall be granted for a longer term than twenty years, but the lessee shall have the right of renewal of such lease for two further and successive terms of ten years each upon such terms and conditions as may be agreed upon or may be fixed by the Minister.

10. The right of timber owners and others to drive their logs or timber down any river, stream or other body of water, as now by law established, shall not be interfered with, lessened or restricted by the granting of any such lease; and if any dam, weir or other structure be erected or built in connection with the development of any such water privilege, the lessee shall make full and proper provision, as now by law required, shall be made by the lessee for the safe and convenient passage of logs and timber over and through the same.

11. The lessee under any such lease shall not destroy or obstruct the navigation of any river, stream or body of water.
previously navigable; but shall provide such locks, canals, passages and other means as may be necessary for the proper and safe surmounting or passing of any dam, weir or other work made or erected by the lessee, and may be required for purposes of navigation by the Government of Canada.

12. In addition to any other conditions or provisions required by the Minister, the lease shall contain conditions and provisions to the following effect:

(a) Requiring the development and use within a period or periods to be named in the lease of a specified quantity or quantities of power or energy, estimated in horse power.

(b) If the quantity of power required by the lease to be developed within a period or periods therein named does not at the full rate of horse power per period upon report being made by the said Hydro-Electric Power Commission to that effect, and also that there is a bona fide demand for power which can be supplied therefrom, the Lieutenant-Governor-in-Council may, by Order-in-Council, require the lessee to develop the said privilege to its full capacity or to such other extent as he may deem proper or requisite within a period or periods of time to be named in the said Order.

(c) For the use by other parties than the lessee of surplus or unused water or power not required by him for the purposes of his business, plant or manufactory, on such terms as may be agreed upon.

(d) Failing an agreement between the parties concerned as to the rates or conditions for supplying power by the lessee to any person, company or corporation, or by any person, company or corporation receiving power from the said lessee, and any other person, company or corporation, the lessee shall immediately notify the said Power Commission, and any Order made by the Lieutenant-Governor-in-Council upon report thereon by the said Power Commission fixing and determining the said rates and conditions shall be final and conclusive and binding upon all parties concerned.

(e) In case of submission to the Hydro-Electric Power Commission as in Paragraph (d) hereinabove, the said lessee on being so directed by the said Commission shall produce all books, accounts, records and statements verified by affidavit, showing the cost of constructing, equipping and maintaining the works for the development of the said privilege and delivering the power therefrom.

(f) Upon complaint in writing being made that any municipal corporation is granting bonuses by supplying power, light or heat below cost to manufacturers or others whether such municipal corporation is the lessee of a water privilege or is deriving power therefrom from or through such lessee, the Lieutenant-Governor-in-Council may refer the matter to the said Hydro-Electric Power Commission, who may dispose of the same in manner provided by Chapter 15 of the Ontario Statutes of 1906, or any amendment thereto.

(g) For the purpose of ascertaining the quantity of power actually developed or capable of development and water privileges or rates of rental payable under a lease thereof, said Power Commission, or any engineer appointed by it for that purpose, shall have free access to all parts of the works, and all books, plans or records bearing on the quantity of power, and may make measurements, take surveys, make tests and make calculations as to the quantity of power so developed or capable of development made by the said Commission or by such engineer shall be binding upon the lessee.

(h) The power and authority to acquire water powers and works by purchase, lease or otherwise, or without the consent of the owners thereof conferred upon the said Power Commission by Chapter 15 of the Statutes of Ontario of 1906, shall be exercisable by the said Power Commission in respect of any water power leased under these regulations or any works connected therewith.

(i) During the construction of the works for the development of any water power, the said Power Commission or any engineer appointed by it for that purpose shall have free access to all parts of the works for the purpose of inspecting the same and of ascertaining that the construction thereof is in accordance with the plans and specifications approved by the said Power Commission.

(j) For the erection and maintenance by the lessee of a durable and efficient fishway when so required by the proper officer or authority in that behalf.

(k) During the continuance of the lease, the lessee shall keep and maintain all dams, weirs, sluices, raceways, flumes, sluices, pits and other structures and works necessary for the development and use of such privilege in good repair and condition, and shall not wilfully or otherwise injure or destroy the same or any part thereof, but at the expiry or sooner determination of the lease, shall leave the same standing and remaining in good repair and condition reasonable wear and tear thereof and damage by fire and tempest only excepted, and so that their subsequent usefulness shall not be lessened by any act of the said lessee.

(l) At the expiry or sooner determination of the lease, the water privilege shall revert to and become the property of the Crown as fully as if no such lease had been granted, together with all buildings, works, machinery, engines, pipes, flumes, sluices and other structures or works made or erected by the lessee in connection therewith, and all buildings erected on land covered by the lease; but the lessee shall be allowed a reasonable time to be fixed by the Minister in which to remove and remove and complete him in the removal and use of the privilege, failing which removal, such machinery shall become the property of the Crown. Provided that where any such buildings or structures are of a permanent
character and necessary or useful for the proper development or utilization of the water privileges, the Lieutenant-Governor-in-Council may upon report in their behalf by the said Hydro-Electric Power Commission, pay the lessee by way of compensation therefor and purchase thereof such sum or sums as he may deem proper upon the same being appropriated for the purpose by the Legislative Assembly of the Province.

(e) The lease shall at all times be subject to any general regulations thereafter made by the Lieutenant-Governor-in-Council affecting the construction and operation of works for the development of water privileges or the supply of water therefrom.

13. The Lieutenant-Governor-in-Council may cancel any water power lease issued under these regulations for non-payment of rental within 90 days after the same is due and payable, whether the same shall have been demanded or not, or upon report by the said Power Commission that the conditions as to construction of the works for the development of water privileges have not been complied with, or that at any time after the water privilege has been developed, either in whole or to the extent to which the lessee is bound or required to develop the same the said lessee has committed any act or neglect for the purpose of one year effectually to produce power from the said privilege, except for his own use or that of other persons, unless hindered by unavoidable accident, or that the lessee has failed or neglected to comply with any order made by the Lieutenant-Governor-in-Council concerning any matter or thing arising under the lease concerning which such Order is made; and publication of any Order-in-Council cancelling such lease shall be sufficient proof that the same has been duly and lawfully cancelled. Provided due notice shall be given a lessee before such cancellation in order that he may have an opportunity of being heard, should he so desire.

14. Where a water privilege is applied for by a municipal corporation for the purpose of supplying water, power, light or heat for the use of the inhabitants of the said municipality, the Minister may issue a lease of said privilege to such corporation if otherwise entitled to receive and hold the same, on such special terms and conditions as may be recommended by the said Power Commission and as at such time as he may deem proper.

15. The word "Minister" in these regulations shall mean the Minister of Lands, Forests and Mines or any Minister of the Crown performing the duties of the Minister of Lands, Forests and Mines in his absence or during a vacancy in that office; and the Minister may refer to the Hydro-Electric Power Commission of Canada any application for the grant of any water privilege or any matter arising out of such application or any lease made in pursuance thereof, whether hereafter or heretofore issued, for consideration, investigation and report.

16. No water power lease shall be valid or effective unless the same is issued under the Great Seal of the Province, and is signed by the said Minister.

Dear Sir:

We enclose field notes and accounts for survey at McIntosh, Ont.

In regard to water power between Forest and Canon Lakes, we may say that we do not regard the result given in the field book as indicating the actual theoretical available horsepower, being probably considerably too high as the water is no doubt above the average at this season. There is a dam in poor repair at the outlet of Forest Lake, this has a six foot opening in it, the sill at the opening being 2.65 feet below the level of Forest Lake. The water in the pool below the dam and away from the influence of the current in the timber slide is 0.63 feet below the level of Forest Lake. The results given were obtained by measuring the current in the timber slide 300 feet long and five feet wide and taking the depth of water in the slide, as the dam and entrance to the slide are leaking badly it was estimated that 70% of the water was going through the slide. The information in regard to the watershed drained by this stream appears to be very vague and there is probably no reliable information in regard to rainfall at this point so that this method of calculating the power does not appear to be available without considerable investigation.

It would probably not be necessary or desirable to hold the water of Forest Lake above its present level which appears to be about normal high water and to do this a dam of the height of the present one would be sufficient.

Yours truly,

Phillips & Benner

Ottawa, Ont., August 13th, 1924.

Mr Duncan C. Scott,
Deputy Supt General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Mr Scott:

Referring to your letter of the 5th inst., in the matter of preliminary work at McIntosh Indian Boarding School, I wish to thank you for the authority given for the clearing of approximately forty acres and the blazing of a trail from the station to the school. In connection with the same matter I wish to state the following.

Your remarks about the docks and slide have been noted and we will govern ourselves accordingly.

The clearing of the land in our estimation and according to work already done will cost approximately $110.00 an acre, making a total of about $4,400 for the forty acres required. As already stated, the site of the intended school and surroundings are thickly wooded and the work of clearing is extremely difficult, but this work has to be done for the protection of the school from fire and also for the purpose of having land for cultivation.

The temporary shelters referred to are exclusively for the use of the men presently working on the site and cost from $500 to $600.

As you are aware, the Oblate Fathers have already spent a considerable amount of money at McIntosh for preliminary work and I take the liberty, in the name of Very Rev. Fr Beys O.M.I., of asking for an advance of $4,000. I herewith enclose salary sheets and vouchers for material already received and used. The total amount is $2,554.25 which partly accounts for the request of an advance.

Hoping that this request will receive favorable consideration, I remain

Sincerely yours,

Dear Mr. Hunter,

The Department is building a residential school on the west shore of the south end of Canyon Lake near McIntosh Station on the Canadian National Railway, (G.T.R.) about 165 miles east of Winnipeg.

When this line was constructed the right of way across this lake was filled in and a culvert about 18 feet in width was constructed as a waterway. The railway company, however, constructed this culvert close to the shore of the lake and as a consequence navigation is not practicable.

All the supplies for the school have to be taken by snow from McIntosh Station to the school, a distance of about three miles, and to reach the destination on the lake it is necessary to pass through this culvert.

Will you be kind enough to advise me whether the railway company obtained authority from your Department for filling in the right of way across the lake and if so, what provision, if any, was made for navigation.

MEMO FOR DEPUTY MINISTER:

With reference to the letter of the 11th ultimo, from the Department of Indian Affairs in attached file IO,971-1, regarding navigation on Canyon Lake, Ont., I beg to transmit herewith a report thereon dated the 14th inst. from Mr. District Engineer V.Y. Mercourt.

The District Engineer reports that the Dept. of Indian Affairs have constructed a school for Indians at the lower end of a small arm of Canyon Lake, near McIntosh on the Can.Nat.Ry., about 165 miles east of Winnipeg. It is understood that it is proposed to build in connection with this school, stables, a saw mill and power plant, etc. The material for these works, as well as the furnishings and supplies for the school, will have to be brought from rail head at McIntosh to the school by water, as overland traffic in the summer months is impossible. Previous to the construction of the Can.Nat.Ry., the natural depth of water in Canyon Lake was sufficiently adequate for these purposes. When the railway was constructed the right of way across this small arm of Canyon Lake was filled in and a culvert and artificial channel built to take care of the flow of water. While the culvert and the channel provide ample clearance and width, the channel itself is not sufficiently deep for the present needs of navigation.

It is stated further that the supplies mentioned above will be taken in barges towed by a motor launch, and to provide sufficient draft for these vessels a minimum depth of 4 feet at low water level will be required. As far as can be ascertained this work was constructed without permission being granted under the Navigable Waters Protection Act.

I would suggest that the Department write to the Company and point out that the work seems to have been constructed without permission being granted under the Navigable Waters Protection Act, and request that they provide the necessary channel.

(sgd) E.M. Cameron,
Chief Engineer.

Winnipeg, Man. January 27, 1925.

Culvert - Canyon Lake, Near McIntosh, Ontario.

Memorandum to Mr. Warren.

Answering yours of the 21st instant, the National Transcontinental Railway Act is silent on the matter of obstructing or diverting navigable waters.

The Government Railways Act does not, in my opinion, apply, firstly because its provisions are not incorporated in the N.T.R. Act, and secondly because it only applies to Railways vested in the Crown and under the control of the Minister of Railways. This Act provides that the "Minister" shall not obstruct any navigable waters. The work on the N.T.R. was done not by the Minister but by the Commissioners of the N.T.R.

The Dominion Railway Act is only made applicable in a limited way, that is certain powers are given, but no obligations, duties or restrictions are imposed. Accordingly, I do not think the navigable waters provisions of the Dominion Railway Act apply to this work.

The only other Act that has any bearing on the subject is the Navigable Waters Protection Act in force in 1909 when the work was done. This Act did not forbid a fill such as that at Canyon Lake. In any event as the Crown is not specifically named in the Act it is not bound by its provisions.

Accordingly it seems to me that when this fill and diversion were made by the Government no statute was infringed.

Even if this work had been done in contravention of a statute, it seems to me the deepening of the stream to permit of navigation would be a matter of construction and not one of "operation and management" which latter are the only powers entrusted to us in relation to the N.T.R.

I would suggest, therefore, that reply be made to the Dominion Government that no sanction were required for the work done without under the Navigable Waters Act, or any other Railway Act, and that the matter being one of construction is one for consideration by the Dominion Government alone.

"G. M. Hair"
Solicitor.

Dear Sir,

Referring to Mr. A. F. McKenzie's telegram of the 28th instant, authorizing me to have work completed to insure three feet of water in the McIntosh culvert on the C.N.Railway near McIntosh School. On the 26th instant I received a telegram from Mr. E.W. Robinson, District Engineer of the C.N.R Port Arthur, saying:

"Have gang now working on concrete culvert McIntosh. Clearing loose rock from channel and when this is done suggest it will not be necessary to deepen waterway in the solid rock. Stop. If possible wish you meet foreman Welsh at McIntosh on Wednesday."

I went to McIntosh arriving there midnight Tuesday. On Wednesday in company with the Rev. Principal and the Brother, we met Foreman Welsh and looked over the situation. The foreman explained it would be a very expensive job to put in coffer dams and take out much of the solid rock, and also that the amount of the appropriation, $2,000, was just about exceeded. He informed me that with the expenditure of a little more money and providing the water kept warm, he could guarantee a depth of three feet of water for very little more expense, and as the Principal informed me they could manage with this amount, I sent the following telegram to Mr. Robinson:

"Foreman Welsh guarantees at least three feet of water in culvert at present water level when all loose rock and a few points of solid rock are cut. Stop. School could manage with this providing this depth absolutely guaranteed. Please instruct your foreman. (signed) Frank Edwards."

Dear Sir,

Referring to your letter #130-7-9 of the 4th instant re improvements on culvert Canadian National Railways near McIntosh School. I visited this School on Saturday and Sunday, the 7th and 8th, and found that the Railway Company had moved their men from the work and the depth in the culvert at one point was only 2 ft. 6 inches and not 3 feet as promised. It is impossible for the School to take their launch through with any supplies and in going through with a row boat and outboard motor, they even hit bottom. The Principal is letting the water through the dam from the lakes higher up so as to enable the water power branch to do the necessary work in repairing the hole in the culvert. This will bring up the water a little and perhaps they will then be able to go through. They have to bring gravel from the lake North of the track through the culvert to the School for the repair work to the dam, which is being started in a few days, and as they are unable to bring the launch through, they request authority to purchase a large Johnson Outboard engine. The Father Provincial from St. Boniface was at the School and we discussed the matter. Your letter of October 30th, with copy of letter attached from Mr. J.D. McLean, Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

The work performed this year embraced the removal of loose rocks in the channel approaches to culvert and the blasting of small projecting pieces of rock. A quantity of clay was also secured and deposited in a pile at the South end of South approach, in anticipation of coffer-damming the channel, which scheme was later considered too expensive and abandoned.

The additional depth secured from this work in places exceeded 5 ft., but on the average was slightly less. I made an inspection of this Culvert three weeks ago, and in testing the depth of water, found it about 2.5 ft.

Canyon Lake at present, on account of the low precipitation this past Summer and Fall, is about 1 ft., 6 inches, or 2 ft., lower than normal. This condition, alone, in my opinion, accounts for the difficulty experienced by the Indian School Authorities in navigating the channel. Under normal water levels they should experience no difficulty whatever.

I have estimated it will cost about $8000.00 to lower the approaches an additional 2 ft., through solid rock, which estimate includes the de-watering of the existing channel in order to enable blasting to be done. The most expensive part of this operation is the coffer-damming of the open ends and the blocking of seams in the rock side walls of the approach, in order to keep water from seeping through the walls.

I am still of the opinion that the expense involved is not warranted, and that the Indian Dept. would do well to consider the use of shallower boats and barges.

Dear Sir,

On my trip of inspection to McIntosh School last week, the Principal asked me if the Department could not do something re raising the water in Canyon Lake, so that his boat could get through the culvert. The work done by the C.N.Railway has not deepened the channel enough. He informs me that if a dam was put at the outlet of Canyon Lake, it would raise the water sufficiently for his purpose. He says that Mr. E.Wallace a small lumber man operating there, has authority from Toronto to put in a dam, but he is not going to do so.

If the Department made a grant of $1000.00 for this purpose, the school would put in the dam under the superintendence of Brother Eugene Gothier, so as to keep the water up to normal height, and the water would not be raised in the lake enough to do any damage to the settlers, campers or anyone else.

Ottawa, January 24, 1931.

Sir:

I have your 108-20 of the 15th instant, with reference to a grant of $1,000 for the erection of a dam near the McIntosh Indian Residential School, so that the level of Canyon Lake will be raised and the passage under the C. N. R. culvert made deep enough for the school boats. There are no funds available for this purpose at the present time, nor will there be any during 1931. Further, there has been so much difficulty in connection with the raising of waters in this section, that the Department wishes the school to see if the present situation is not satisfactory before we even consider making application to the provincial authorities for the right to change the level of the lake.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.
Sir:

I visited the McIntosh Indian Residential School on Sunday, the 3rd instant. I found conditions here to be satisfactory, the school well managed, and in a most cleanly condition. The pupils had all returned from their holidays.

Owing to the low water in Canyon Lake, the school launch, which brings in all supplies, has difficulty in getting under the culvert of the C.N.R. track. The Principal suggested that the Department provide a grant to build a dam at the outlet of the lake. I told him it would be impossible at the present time to consider making any grant for this purpose.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Sutherland
Acting Superintendent of Indian Education.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

Sir:

The marginally noted, Indian boy, and pupil of St. Joseph's Boarding School, has been found hard to manage, due to his age, by the Sisters in charge of the school.

I have communicated with the Principal of the McIntosh Indian residential school with regard to having him transferred there and am in receipt of a reply from Rev. Father Perrault, in which he advises he has room for the boy and is willing to accept his admission.

I would be pleased therefore, if authorization could be obtained to have the above-mentioned transferred to the McIntosh school, and also to be advised whether or not a Government Warrant is to be issued for his transportation, or if accounts should be obtained for the cost and a voucher submitted the Department for payment.

Dear Sir:

I intend to have the following pupils discharged at the end of June; being of age limit:
- 32 Laurent Abraham
- 42 Albert Tahpahkah
- 75 Joseph Kljik
- 76 Maurice Pitikkan
- 90 Yvon Nicanipinens
- 12 Wilfrid Stone
- 124 Georges Spence
- 0121 Florence Tenesco
- 0132 Revina Abraham

And I would like to keep for another year the three following girls:
- 046 Emerentienne Nenaogijik
- 048 Sarah Nenaogijik
- 081 Therese Kapeskang

These three girls like the school and wish to stay for another year.

046 and 048 Emerentienne and Sarah Nenaogijik are orphans and have no place where to go. With another year they would be old enough to get a place and we would try to find a good one for them. Being very good girls, it would be very sad if, after their school time, they get spoiled, for the reason of having no body and no place where they can be protected.

As for 081 Therese Kapeskang, this girl was 16 years old a few days ago; she is half blind and also neglected by both parents who do not live together. During the last summer holidays she stayed with her sister who died last winter. Now she is homeless and unable to earn her living being so blind.

For these reasons I ask the Department to grant us the authorization of keeping these three girls for another year.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Principal

Last week a periodic visit was made to the McIntosh Indian Residential School by the undersigned. It was brought to my attention that about twelve children from Grassy Narrows I.R. had not returned to the School since last fall. Approximately half this number were new pupils who should have been enrolled in September. We gave notice in writing to the parents or guardians in November, informing them that the children must be sent to school immediately. Only two children have been returned to date as a result of this warning.

I would suggest that a member of the R.C.M.P. from Kenora be sent to Grassy Narrows with instructions to bring all delinquents out to McIntosh. Some of the children are out with their parents on the trap lines, consequently it would be impossible to contact all of them at once.

It is proposed that the parents and guardians be prosecuted under Section 10 for failing to have their children attend school after having been notified. This action would not be practical until Treaty time but even then it would serve as a good example.

G. Swartman,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
January 25, 1943.

Mr. G. Swartman, Indian Agent, Sioux Lookout, Ont.

I have your letter of the 18th instant, with reference to certain Grassy Narrows children who failed to return to the McIntosh Indian Residential School at the commencement of the current academic year.

If you consider that the R.C.M.P. would be able to reach any appreciable number of these children, you may arrange to have one of the officers visit Grassy Narrows. However, the Department does not see any necessity for this action if he would only secure one or two pupils.

I agree with you that the compulsory clause in the Act should be enforced regarding these Indians and this phase of the question should receive your attention at Treaty time.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

I am today in receipt of the following letter from Mr. G. Shortman, Indian Agent, Sioux Lookout, Ont., dated the 17th instant:

"Further reference is made to previous correspondence concerning truant children at the Grassy Narrows I.R., also to your report dealing with patrol work to that point.

"We have been advised by the Reverend Principal of the Nettleton Indian Residential School that six children were brought in as a result of your recent visit to the Reserve. I believe this represents practically all the children of school age, with the possible exception of one or two sickly ones, who are permanent residents of Grassy Narrows. Consequently we do not propose taking any further action at this time. The Reverend Principal has expressed himself as being well satisfied with the results.

"It is noted that the reasons given by the parents or guardians for not having their children sent to school were partly due to insufficient clothing & footwear at the school, also that they were severely punished by being locked up in rooms, etc. These statements given you by the Indians are nothing more or less than lies. Our Inspector, Mr. Hamilton, who recently visited the school, stated that he was of the opinion that the children at Nettleton were better clothed than those in any other school in his Inspectorate. He has had occasion to know that some punishment at this school is severe but nothing that would justify a complaint of this nature. I mention this for purposes of record only.

"We wish to thank you for your co-operation in this matter."

In view of the above no further action will be taken in this connection.

H.O.E.B.D.C.,

Ottawa,
March 27, 1943.

Mr. G. Swartman, Indian Agent, Sioux Lookout, Ont.

I desire to refer to official letter of January 25, with reference to returning certain Grassy Narrows children to the McIntosh Indian Residential School.

From recent reports received from the R.C.M.P., it is noted that through their cooperation 6 children have now been returned to the school. We have also received a copy of your letter of March 17 addressed to the R.C.M.P., and feel that you took the proper action in supplying them with the information contained in your letter.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Sioux Lookout, Ont., May 17th, 1943.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

We have been requested by the Reverend Principal of the McIntosh Indian Residential School to have the following pupils remain at the school for another year:

- Therese Kapeskang, No. 081
- Sarah Nenaokijic, No. 048
- Emerentienne N., No. 046
- Suzanna Ferguson, No. 086

The reasons given are as follows and my investigations reveal them to be correct: The parents of Therese Kapeskang do not live together. This girl is almost blind having undergone an operation for cataracts about eighteen months ago. She has no place to go and is not employable. The Nenaokijic girls are orphans and also have no place to go, although we will endeavour to have them employed if suitable work can be found for them. Suzanna Ferguson is an illegitimate orphan, consequently there is nowhere for her to go when she leaves the school unless we are able to find employment for her as well as the others.

It is recommended that these girls be allowed to continue at the school for another year or until such time as arrangements can be made for their employment.

[Signature]
Indian Agent.

GS:K
Ottawa,
May 19, 1943.

Mr. G. Swartman, Indian Agent, Sioux Lookout, Ont.

With reference to your letter of the 17th instant, the Department approves Therese Kapeshang, No. 081, remaining in the McIntosh Residential School for another year.

There is a considerable demand for domestic servants in Ottawa and the Department has been successful in placing several Indian girls in such positions where they are giving reasonable satisfaction. We are anxious to obtain bright, intelligent girls for other positions of a similar nature and under the circumstances we would appreciate receiving from the Principal and yourself detailed information regarding each of the other three girls mentioned in your letter; namely, Nos. 045, 046 and 086. You should state if they have had any training in domestic work while at the school and also express an opinion regarding their ability as domestic servants. If any of the school staff or yourself have a camera you might let us have pictures of the girls.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Mr. G. Swartman,
Indian Agent,
Sioux Lookout, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Re: Suzanne Ferguson O 86

We would greatly appreciate if you could obtain that this young girl be granted another year at School. We won't by no means let her out of school to work for any one and we do hope she gets married during the coming year. It would be the only way to assure her a safe future.

Poor illegitimate child of an abused young girl she would surely follow her mother's path judging by her attitude and disposition.

We believe that the only means to save her is to let her choose here the man she likes and we prefer to keep the girl at school even at our own expense than to let her go out and work for any one.

The child given to the school by her dying mother must and will find here happiness and protection.

Trusting you fully understand this request
I am Yours truly

Reports Re Treaty Payments 1943
Sioux Lookout Agency

May 27th; Fair and cold, North wind.
Paying Grassy Narrows and Wabuskang Band members all day.
Payments completed at 5:00 P.M. and returned to post.

May 28th; Fair and warm, light S.W. wind.
Paid a few more Band members who arrived during night.
Listened to complaints and grievances most of morning and held meeting with Band in afternoon. They request that the Department give assistance toward providing them with portable sawmill. They were given to understand that this might be possible after the war but not at present. The matter of American Tourists, hunters and fishermen, supplying the Indians employed as guides, with liquor was brought to my attention. I would suggest if possible that arrangements be made with the Ontario Department of Game and Fisheries to have printed on each license issued to non-residents a warning in this regard. They also wanted to know if it was the intention of the Indian Affairs or the Department of Game and Fisheries to deprive them of the right to hunt and fish for their own use off their reserves. The subject of children being sent to the Residential School at McIntosh was fully discussed. The reasons given for not cooperating fully were not very impressive. I agreed to meet the Chief and Councillors at McIntosh some time in September and investigate each complaint with the School authorities. The Band passed a resolution to have all outside Band members living in the vicinity of, or on, the Reserve transferred to the Grassy Narrows Band. This did not include the Wabuskang Band members.

Gifford Swartman,
Indian Agent.

Sioux Lookout, Ont., Oct. 7th, 1943.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

We are enclosing herewith Quarterly Returns from the McIntosh Indian Residential School for the Quarter ended September 30th, 1943, also nineteen applications for admission, as well as discharge forms for the same quarter.

It is noted that Rita Ajopinace, listed as pupil No. 0190 is under school age, but since she has no one to look after her, it is recommended that she be admitted to the McIntosh school.

G. Swartman,
Indian Agent.

Sioux Lookout, Ont., Oct. 6th, 1943.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

From time to time we have applications for admission from the Indian Residential Schools in this Agency listing pupils whose names are spelled entirely different from those shown in our Census Books and Treaty Pay-Lists. We have suggested to the school authorities that the names be shown exactly as on the Treaty tickets in order that there will be no confusion or difficulty in identifying the children at a later date. Since this request has not always been complied with, it is recommended that the Department issue instructions to the school authorities that the children's names must be listed the same as appears on their Treaty tickets.

[Signature]
G. Swartman,
Indian Agent.

Ottawa,
November 11, 1943.

Reverend Sir:

I understand that pupils 046 and 048 have recently returned to the McIntosh Residential School. In view of the fact that these girls are orphans and the special circumstances in each case, it has been decided to allow grant for them until you find it possible for them to secure employment. I trust that you will be successful in doing so in the near future. In any case it should be distinctly understood that grant will not be allowed for them for a longer period than to June 30, 1944. If they have not been discharged in the meantime they will have to be discharged on that date.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

McIntosh Indian Residential School
McIntosh Ont. November 17th, 1943

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Sir:

Thanks for leaving pupils No 046 & 048 another year at School. But I think that my request was not well understood. Pupil 048 who is the oldest one, left the school sometimes in June and went to work on a good catholic family at Sioux Lookout. Although lonesome, she did not return to the school and according the last news I believe she will keep up with her work. I consider her case definitively settled and her name is not going to be shown in my returns.

Pupils no 046 came back in the beginning of September and I am glad you have approved her readmission in school for another year.

Yours very truly

Ottawa,
May 8, 1944.

Mr. G. Swartman, Indian Agent, Sioux Lookout, Ont.

We have just received the application form for the admission of Beatrice Iassens to the McIntosh Indian Residential School. You state that the father of the child requested that she be placed in a residential school, but this request alone is not sufficient to justify her admission to a residential school. The application form shows that she is only three years of age and that both parents are living. Are there any special reasons why they could not support the child until she is of school age? An early reply would be appreciated.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Referring to your letter of May 8th, File 130-7-10, with respect to the above noted, we are attaching herewith copy of letter recently received from the Reverend Principal of the McIntosh Indian Residential School concerning this child.

GS:K
McIntosh Indian Residential School
McIntosh Ont May 20th 1944

Mr. G. Swartman
Indian Agent,
Sioux Lookout, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Re: Beatrice Iasens #117 Grassy Narrows

This little girl was brought here by her father last Summer during her mother's illness and for a few months she was sent back and forth from the school to her home till finally the mother said she couldn't look after her and the little one was neglected.

We thought she was too young to be admitted, but she really is very reasonable and we prefer to keep her for good than to see her dragging here and there. She will be three in July and we do hope you admit her at school definitely.

The child is very well used to us now and it is all to her advantage that she stays here.

Hoping a favorable answer soon
Yours very truly

[Signature]
Principal
Ottawa, May 25, 1944.

Mr. G. Swartman, Indian Agent, Sioux Lookout, Ontario,

With reference to your letter of May 22, the Department approves the admission of Beatrice Iassens to the McIntosh Indian Residential School.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Pupil 174 Cecil Penewatang (Abraham) Mrs. Bierre Penewatang is the grand mother of Cecil. She has adopted him at birth and has always looked after him since. Her husband died last year and being old herself, she can no longer care for the boy.

Re: Danielson, Carl, Pte., H-204618.

Dear Sir:

On January 23rd, 1945, the application for wardship of the step-children of the above-named soldier was heard. When the evidence re residence was taken, the mother volunteered the information that the children were Treaty Indians, although she had lost her treaty status through her marriage to Danielson. The case was remanded until January 31st, 1945, to have the Indian Department represented.

At the second hearing the Indian Department was represented by Mr. Ward Leroy, who states that by a ruling of the Indian Department these children are to remain wards until they are twenty-one years of age. The Magistrate stated that he found the children neglected, and if it were not for the fact that they were already wards of the Indian Department, he would have made them wards of the Children's Aid Society.

Indiscussing this matter afterwards with Mr. Leroy, he told us that he was thinking of sending the children down to the MacIntosh School. The little girl is crippled and he thought it might be arranged for her to attend the Shiner's Hospital in Winnipeg from the school.

We will be interested to know your decision on this case and shall be glad to give you any further information you may require.

Mr. J. G. Burk, Indian Agent,
Fort Arthur, Ont.

The Department is in receipt of a letter from the Dependents' Allowance Board, enclosing copy of a communication dated February 2 from the Children's Aid Society, Fort Arthur, with reference to three Danielson children. In this connection I might refer you to departmental letter of May 25, 1945.

In the letter from the Children's Aid Society it appears that they consider the children are not receiving proper care and consequently they endeavoured to have them made wards of their Society. However, it is stated that your clerk, Mr. Leroy, was present at the hearing and he intimated that it was your intention to have two of the children sent to the McIntosh School and the little girl placed in a hospital in Winnipeg. We do not appear to have received any correspondence from you regarding the placing of two of the children in McIntosh. Provided they are physically fit and are eligible for admission to that school, we are quite prepared to approve their admission. Please let me hear from you as soon as possible in connection with this matter.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

March 13, 1945.

Indian Affairs Br., Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

I have your letter of the 9th instant, file 130-7-10, with reference to a communication received from the Children's Aid Society of the City of Fort Arthur, regarding the marginally noted Indian children.

As their home, in the City here, was found unfit to live in they were brought with their Mother to magistrate's court, and we arranged to have them admitted to the McIntosh Indian residential school, where they would be cared for. One of the children, however, (Merle) is at present a patient in our Squaw Bay Indian Hospital on the Fort William Indian reserve. Applications for their admission to the McIntosh school have not been forwarded to Ottawa, due to the fact that their Mother refused to sign the application forms, but it is expected these will be forwarded you in a few days time.

With reference to Elizabeth, one of the children sent to McIntosh school, Dr. Gillie, our Indian doctor, considers that she should be given treatment for her hip at the Shriner's Hospital, at Winnipeg, Man., just as soon as she reaches a certain age. This matter is under his consideration at the present time and you will be advised later.

I trust that my action in this matter meets with the Department's approval.

J.G. Burk, Indian Agent.

April 30th, 1945.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa,

I wish to acknowledge Mr. Phelan's letter of April 20th, File 130-7-10, with respect to McIntosh Indian Residential School pupils.

James Paishk and Alex King are still at the school. I discussed this matter with Rev. Father Perrault who informed me that these boys were sent in from Red Lake with the understanding that they were members of his church. Their parents, or guardians, in the case of the King boy, were away on their trap lines and it was impossible to get in touch with them. From your letter of January 31st I understood that I was authorized to make the most practical arrangements possible under the circumstances, and after reviewing all the information available, I decided that the logical solution would be to have the boys remain at McIntosh until June. I will interview the parents and guardians in June or July and discuss the matter fully with them at that time. It is nearly five years now since I have seen the Paishk family. Consequently I am not very familiar with their latest religious belief. In the meantime it is recommended that the boys be allowed to remain at McIntosh as grant-earning pupils until the end of the present term. It is also recommended that all Missionaries, when recruiting pupils for the various schools, be requested to take every precaution in order not to have children of one faith being admitted to a school of different faith. This only causes a lot of unnecessary controversy, correspondence and ill will.

We are returning herewith the applications for admission of the two boys in question.

[Signature]

Ottawa, 20 September 1946.

Mr. G. Swartman, Indian Agent,
Sioux Lookout, Ontario.

We have received your letter of the 14th instant requesting $300.00 to cover transportation of children to McIntosh Indian School by plane.

Before any expenditure was incurred for air travel for which the Department was expected to pay, we should have been consulted. Presumably it was known for some weeks previous to Sept. 1st, that these children would be going to the McIntosh School. Was it impossible to make arrangements for the transportation of these children in a less costly method? As you know, air transportation is expensive and principals, missionaries and our own officials interested in placing children in residential schools should make every possible endeavour to have them brought in the least expensive manner. In many cases parents would be prepared to bring the children themselves without any expense to either the School or the Department.

The extra money involved in providing air transportation could be used to much better advantage at practically any Indian Residential School.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, OTTAWA.

The enclosed letter has recently been received from Reverend Father Comeau of McIntosh Indian Residential School applying for a grant of $300.00 to cover airplane fares for children coming in to school from the Northern points. These are for the most part orphans and neglected children and it is recommended that a grant of $300.00 be provided.

Swartzen,
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

I wish to acknowledge Mr. Phalan's letter of September 20th, 1946, File 130-7-10 (W.T. 1) with respect to our recommendation for a grant to cover air transportation charges for pupils coming in to McIntosh Indian Residential School from the remote northern points.

During the summer months in the north I endeavoured to recruit certain children for both our Residential Schools, as instructed. Parents and guardians would promise on the spot to send or bring the children out early in September, but it often seemed they change their minds. Some children have arrived at the Schools concerned, but no previous arrangements had been made. In tracing back we find they decided among themselves to send others instead of the ones we had previously arranged for. This might partly explain why we are not in a very good position to be certain in advance, just how many children will come out to School.

We have had a few come out from Port Hope and Lansdowne to the line by canoe. This is a very hard trip of nearly 100 miles with many portages. At this season of the year the parents feel that they are neglecting their own livelihood during the period required to bring the children out. It should be remembered too that in most places none of the parents are not anxious to send their children to Residential Schools and refuse to spend any time or energy in getting them out. Children from Ogoki are obliged to come out by plane due to the fact that the water route south is not navigable by canoe at this season.

In most cases, however, the children are brought out to school without any cost to the Department, either by white people interested in their well-being, or the parents paying the air fares themselves. It is just for children who should be at school and for whom no other means except air transportation is available or practical that the grant was applied for by Father Comeau and recommended by the undersigned.

A glance at the geographical situation of the Sioux Lookout Agency will show that most of the pupils for the Residential Schools must come from the North. There are not sufficient children living off the Reserves along the main line of the C.N.R. to provide the necessary pupilage.

I realize that the extra money required for air transportation would go far and be used to good advantage at any Residential School, but there is no object in having these Schools unless they are kept reasonably well filled.

---------- over.
Indian Affairs Branch - Cont'd.

Therefore in view of the foregoing, it is recommended that the grant of $300.00 for the McIntosh School be provided and we will do our utmost to see that it is spent only on those pupils who have no other means of transportation and who otherwise would be denied the opportunity of attending School, which has always been our endeavour.

Ice Conditions.

An ice-sheet forms on all the lakes in this region during the winter, but gradually melts in place during the warm weather of spring. At the time of the survey Forest Lake was practically clear of ice, but Canyon Lake was nearly wholly covered, except along the immediate shores. The ice was, however, very much honeycombed and melting rapidly.

Detailed Work at the Site.

The work at the site consisted of a reconnaissance survey of the stretch of river between Forest and Canyon lakes, an examination of the banks of Forest lake with a view to determining the effect of raising its water-level, a cross-section of the river and banks on the line of the dam, and a profile of the river from lake to lake. From the notes of the survey, the accompanying plan has been prepared, showing the contours of the bed and banks at five-foot intervals, the nature of the surface materials, and the water-levels and highwater marks. The cross-section on the dam-line, the profile of the river, and a key-plan showing the location of the site are included. Photographs of the site are appended hereto.

The site is accessible from McIntosh station on the C. N. Railway by a water-route of two miles in the summer, or by travel over the ice by team in the winter. There are no summer roads, and the small amount of power available would not warrant any expenditure for their construction in a country of such a character.

As shown on the plan and profile, the natural fall of the river at the time of the inspection was 12 feet in a distance of about 350 feet. This fall takes place in a fairly uniform rapid over a bed of smooth granite. At the head of the fall is an old lumbering-dam, with a six-foot sluice in the centre, used to direct the main body of the stream into the log-chute, which extends down the right channel. The proposed scheme of development would include the lengthening and raising of the dam to a sufficient height to raise the water-level of Forest lake to elevation 112.0, (i.e., three feet above highwater mark), provision for a sluice gate to control the flow, the installation of a pipe line from the dam along the right bank to the foot of the fall, and the construction of a powerhouse.

Possible Power:

Under the maximum regulated head of 17 feet and the estimated low-water flow of 14 c.f.s., the power available at the site is 32 h.p. By the use of the storage, however, it is estimated that the minimum flow may be increased to 25 c.f.s., although the head will be decreased as the storage is used until it is 14 feet. Under these conditions the estimated minimum power available is 32 h.p.

Use of Power:

The amount of power available is sufficient only for small local uses such as lighting, pumping for water supply, sawing wood, etc. There is at present no market at the site, but it is proposed to establish there a small Indian mission-school, for the purpose of which the power could be very advantageously employed.

**LOCATION AND ACCESSIBILITY**

The Canyon River Power Site is located on the short stretch of the river separating Forest and Canyon lakes. The main Canyon river forms the outflow channel of Canyon Lake into the Wabigoon river. The power site is about one mile in a direct line from McIntosh, a station on the Canadian National Railway, 169 miles east of Winnipeg. Owing to fallen timber and muskeg the site is practically inaccessible by overland route during the open water period, but it is readily accessible by a two and one-half mile water route.

**GENERAL DESCRIPTION**

The stretch of river carrying the overflow of Forest Lake into Canyon Lake is about 350 feet in length and divides past an island at the lower end. The channel is from 70 to 100 feet in width, shallow and boulder stream and there is a descent of about 18 feet between the two lakes.

During earlier years lumbering operations were carried on above Canyon Lake and a timber and rock dam was built across the outlet of Forest Lake to raise the lake level. From an opening in the dam a log chute extended to Canyon Lake. However, no lumbering operations have been carried on for years on these lakes and the dam and log chute are now unserviceable.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6221, file 472-16, part 1)
During the past summer the land on either side of the stream has been cleared and an Indian School is now in course of erection upon the left bank. The general topographical features of the site are shown on an accompanying plan.

WATER SUPPLY.

General Description of Drainage Area.

As the greater part of the area draining into Canyon Lake lies in unsurveyed area it is impossible to accurately estimate the extent of the drainage basin above this power site. From existing maps the area has been calculated to be about 108 square miles and is of a rocky Laurentian formation, covered by a thick growth of spruce, poplar, birch and balsam pine. There are numerous lakes throughout the basin which ultimately drain into Canyon Lake.

Run-off Records.

Previous to 1934 no measurements of the flow of this stream have been obtained. On May 9th the flow was found to be 51 c.f.s., while on September 9th it was 26 c.f.s. The summer and fall of the present year has been a period of very low water conditions throughout the district. The run-off data so far obtained are too meagre to permit of accurate flow estimates being determined from them, but estimates have been prepared, based upon flow conditions in adjacent drainage areas for which data are available, and these are tabulated as follows:

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6221, file 472-16, part 1)
There are several lakes above the power site, to which several different names have been applied, but the larger ones comprise Forest, Boulder, Corner and Sandy Lakes. These are all joined by narrow or short sluggish streams so that the group have practically the same water level as Forest Lake, and appear to cover an area in excess of 10 square miles, although this area is indefinite, no surveys having been made. A reservoir of 10 square miles immediately above the power site affords unusual opportunity for storage regulation.

In the proposed development of this power site it is intended to raise the water level above the dam from a present assumed elevation of about 106.5 to an elevation of 112.0. One foot of storage on these lakes would be equivalent to a continuous flow of about 9 c.f.s. for one year, or 18 c.f.s. over a period of six months. Since the proposed scheme of development only necessitates a flow of 25 c.f.s., it is quite probable that one foot of storage will ensure a continuous flow of 25 c.f.s. at all times.

METHOD OF DEVELOPMENT:

The proposed scheme for the development of this power site is shown on accompanying plans. Briefly stated, it provides for a concrete dam at the outlet of Forest Lake.
with a penstock 385 feet long leading to the powerhouse situated on the small island at the lower end of the channel. The forebay level will be elevation 112.0 and the normal tailwater elevation about 95.6, giving a maximum head of 17 feet. If storage is drawn upon heavily the forebay elevation may drop to 111.0, and taking into account loss of head in the pipe line of one foot, the minimum head expected will be 16 feet. Hence the power available with a flow of 25 c.f.s., under 16 foot head at 80% efficiency will be 35 h.p.

**Dam**

The dam, as proposed, will rest on rock, be of concrete construction, and will contain, spillway section, and non-overflow section, the latter containing an opening for a log chute and also a sluiceway for discharging flood waters. The dam will have a maximum height of seven and one half feet and a length of 330 feet, and is designed to withstand flood conditions. A 30-foot spillway section connects the right bank and has a crest elevation of 112.0. The non-overflow section will be constructed to elevation 115.0; the sluiceway will be eight feet wide with sill elevation of 108.0; and the log chute opening will be five feet wide, with sill elevation of 109.0. Stop logs will be provided for these two openings.

**Intake Works**

The intake works will consist of a suitable intake structure located downstream from the dam. The intake will be constructed of reinforced concrete and will extend through to the upstream face of the dam, and the base will be at elevation 105.0. As the inside diameter of the penstock is to be...
56 inch the intake works are designed accordingly. Two six inch steel channels set upright and four feet apart and extending three inches out from the face of the dam, serve as a guideway for the gate, which will be raised and lowered by means of a suitable hand worked hoist. Rails are provided to cover the intake end are supported by concrete piers extending out from the face of the dam. The details are shown on accompanying plans.

Penstock.

A penstock line, 325 feet in length extends from the upstream face of the dam to the powerhouse and passes down the shallow river channel to the island upon which the powerhouse will be located. The penstock will be supported on timbers and at the lower end on trestles, and will be 36 inches inside diameter and constructed of continuous wood stave pipe of standard construction.

Power House.

The site chosen for the powerhouse is on the lower end of the island in the lower end of the channel. The building as planned will be 18 feet by 30 feet, provision being made for a workshop above the generator room. The turbine will be set in an open wheel pit, this pit having inside dimensions four feet by six feet and raised to elevation 112.0, being covered and a manhole provided for inspection purposes. The walls of the wheel pit are to be 18 inches thick, constructed of reinforced concrete and the wheel pit will be wholly within the powerhouse. The floor will be of reinforced concrete, but the building will be of frame construction.
Tailrace.

The tailrace will be discharged into Canyon lake, the bottom of the tailrace being at elevation 90.4. Considerable rock excavation will be necessary to provide a satisfactory tailrace.

It is also desired to place a few lights around the installation.

It is proposed to install one complete unit consisting of a 30 h.p. horizontal turbine of improved type and set in an open wheel pit, and one 17½ k.w. D.C. generator which will be belt driven from a pulley on the turbine shaft. For speed regulation a suitable sized compensating governor will be installed.

It is proposed to generate at 115 volts and a single panel direct current switch board will be installed.

POWER AVAILABLE.

The power available has been estimated at 25 h.p., under minimum head conditions and as the installation is for 17½ k.w. only, a power shortage is very improbable.

MARKET FOR POWER.

The Department of Indian Affairs of the Interior Department are erecting a school along the left bank of this stream and as the site is rather isolated it is planned to use hydro power from this power site to supply lighting for the school, also power for the operation of a water system and laundry and a work shop. The water system is not only for domestic purposes but also for fire protection. It is considered that 15 k.w. will meet the power demands of this school, and the power site will provide a dependable source of power.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6221, file 472-16, part 1)
The school building is being wired for electric lighting and power, and is about 300 feet from the power house site, so a short pole line only will be required. It is also desired to place a few lights around the grounds and the power house building will be heated by electric heaters.

ESTIMATES.

The estimates given herein are based on what is considered a fair contract price and include freight charges and contractors' profit. No engineering charges are included as it is presumed that the engineering and supervision will be in charge of Departmental engineers.

It will be noticed that the cost of this development is high in view of the power required. It might be pointed out that in the advent of the Catholic Mission making an agreement to provide free labor (rough) the construction costs could possibly be reduced to the Department of Indian Affairs by approximately 25%. This saving would occur principally in concrete construction and free hauling of materials and equipment from McIntosh to the site.

The purpose of this report is to provide information regarding the installation of water supply equipment at Macintosh Indian School.
