REPORT ON WATER SUPPLY INSTALLATION FOR MCINTOSH INDIAN SCHOOL.

I - INTRODUCTORY.

At the present time the Department of Indian Affairs is constructing a school building about 14 miles from McIntosh, a station on the Canadian National Railway 169 miles east of Winnipeg. The contract for the construction work includes all plumbing fixtures and a complete cold water supply to all plumbing fixtures, to heating boilers and stand pipes, and the installation of a complete system of stand pipe and hose for fire protection, but the contract does not include the pumping equipment or intake pipe and fixtures necessary to ensure a satisfactory water supply. This report is intended to outline in considerable detail a water supply system with estimate of the cost of same, for domestic use and for adequate fire protection for the school.

II - GENERAL.

The present structure is designed to accommodate about sixty individuals, but a survey of the needs of the district in which the school is located shows that in the near future extensions may be necessary to accommodate a total of about 100 pupils. Accordingly, a water supply system to accommodate 100 pupils is now proposed. It is desired that the water supply system should serve the two purposes, domestic water supply and fire protection, to provide sufficient water for a fairly satisfactory domestic...
water service will be comparatively simple and inexpensive, but to provide sufficient water for adequate fire protection for the building will require a high pressure system and the expense will be considerable.

To provide for domestic water supply it is considered that a supply of 30 gallons per minute should meet requirements. The pneumatic pressure tank will provide storage capacity of 850 gallons.

The specifications for the construction of the school call for ten hose connections to standpipes, two on each floor. In the case of any ordinary outbreak of fire not more than four of these would be in use, accordingly for fire protection it is considered necessary to provide sufficient water to feed four lines of hose under pressure of 60 pounds per square inch. It is considered that a water supply of 250 Imperial gallons per minute under pressure of 60 pounds per square inch pressure will give adequate fire protection for ordinary fire outbreaks. In case of forest fire the building would in all probability be doomed.

For convenient operation it has been decided to place the pumping apparatus either within the school building or in an addition immediately adjoining that portion of the basement containing the laundry. It has also been decided to pump the water from Forest lake, a pipe line approximately 450 feet long being necessary. To provide for fire protection and to overcome pipe resistance, a 5" wrought iron pipe is necessary and the pipe must be laid sufficiently deep to be sufficiently protected to prevent frost penetration.

The source of power for the operation of the pumping system has, as yet, been undecided. If the Canyon
river power site, located some 400 feet from the school, is developed to provide electrical energy for the school requirements. The installation of the water system and especially the operation of the system is a simple and comparatively inexpensive proposition. If this power site is not developed it will be necessary to install fuel engines for a source of power for operating the pumps and the installation becomes more elaborate, more expensive, and operation costs will be much greater. Accordingly, in this report it has been necessary to consider the question of the water supply for the school on the basis of

(a) - Hydro power available,
(b) - Hydro power not available.

Plans for the development and estimates of the cost of the development of the power site have been dealt with in a separate report. It was pointed out in the report that it was considered quite possible to develop sufficient power to meet all present requirements of the school, but that the cost of the development was expensive considering the amount of power required.

A - HYDRO POWER AVAILABLE.

1 - INTAKE.
An accompanying plan shows the proposed location of the intake, also the location of the pipe line and the location of the school. The intake would be immediately above the dam at the outlet of Forest Lake. The 5" pipe should pass through the dam at about elevation 107 and extend upstream only sufficiently far to permit of the attachment of a strainer and gate valve.

2 - PIPE LINE.
Approximately 375 feet of 5" wrought iron pipe would be required for the pipe line to connect with the pump.
The pipe should be embedded at least three feet underground and be further protected above ground to prevent frost penetration.

3 - PUMP HOUSE.

Provision can be made to accommodate all equipment necessary in the laundry room and boiler room of the school building, thus doing away with any expense for any addition to the present structures.

4 - DOMESTIC WATER SUPPLY AND FIRE PROTECTION.

It is proposed to install a 15 H.P. motor which will drive a single stage double acting centrifugal pump mounted on the same cast iron base with the D.C. motor. The pump will have an air compressor attachment and will be direct connected to the standpipe piping and fitted with the necessary check valves. Pipe reducing down to 2" will lead from the main pipe to a 4' x 16' pneumatic pressure tank from which the water supply of the building for domestic purposes is forced under pressure of a minimum of 25 pounds per square inch. This pressure tank will be fitted with the necessary gauges, etc., and will have a working capacity of 833 Imperial gallons with a working pressure of 50 pounds per square inch. The domestic water supply system will be equipped with a suitable Cutler Hammer diaphragm pressure regulator for automatic control. In case of fire the pump feeds the hose direct at pressure required.

5 - Hydro Power Not Available.

1 - INTAKE.

The accompanying plan shows the location of the intake, the pipe line and the addition to the school building.
required as a pump house, in case no hydro-electric energy is available. The intake is at the outlet of Forest lake, but must extend out to ensure a seal over the intake. The outlet of the lake does not freeze over under existing conditions and little trouble need be anticipated with the intake.

2 - PIPE LINE.

Approximately 465 feet of 3" wrought iron pipe will be required. The pipe must be laid at least three feet underground, where possible, and protected otherwise to prevent frost penetration; particular care being taken in the vicinity of the lake shore, where rock prevents excavation.

3 - PUMP HOUSE.

The equipment necessary for the water supply may be housed in the school building, owing to lack of space and the excessive noise of the exhausts. It is proposed to house this equipment in an addition 16' x 31', as shown on the accompanying plan.

4 - DOMESTIC WATER SUPPLY.

To pump 30 gallons per minute it is proposed to install a 3 H.P. gasoline, distillate or kerosene burning engine, which would be bolt connected to a double acting power pump with a capacity of 30 gallons per minute and with an air compressor attachment. The pump will be connected by piping with a 4' x 16' pneumatic pressure tank, fitted with gauge, etc., and with a working capacity of 833 gallons with working pressure of 80 pounds per square inch. The domestic water service will be fed from the pressure tank.

5 - FIRE PROTECTION.

For fire protection it is proposed to install a 25 H.P. oil engine, which will be bolted to a single stage.
double acting centrifugal pump having a capacity of 250 Imperial gallons per minute against a total head of 120 feet. The pump will be connected to the feed pipe and also to the piping leading to the standpipes. This pump could be connected up with feed pipe from the standpipe piping to the pressure tank and thus utilized for domestic service in the event of a breakdown of the domestic service pumping equipment.

6 - LAUNDRY ROOM SERVICE

Power will be required for the operation of the machinery of the laundry room. A central shaft connecting the different laundry mechanisms could be operated by a belt connected to the 3 H.P. engine running the domestic water supply pump. However, if a small 3 H.P. engine is installed to operate a generator to supply electric lighting it should be located so as to also operate the laundry machinery.

The McIntosh Residential Indian School now under construction by the Department of Indian Affairs in Ontario, located on Canyon Lake some two miles south-west of McIntosh, Ontario. As there are at present some summer resorts along the shores of the lake, and with the likelihood of these increasing in the near future, the discharging into the lake of untreated sewage from an institution the size of the school was not considered advisable, and the following is a report of the method of treatment which is considered most suitable. Plans and profiles of the proposed works, together with estimates of the cost, accompany this report. The elevations given on the plans and profiles are an assumed datum. The top of a large boulder behind the cook-house marked in white paint being taken as 100.00.

The general method of treatment, septic tank and sub-irrigation disposal bed, was decided on after consultation with Mr. Orr, Architect of the Department of Indian Affairs, and with the officials of the Oblate Order who will have charge of the school. As the most suitable place for a disposal system lies between the front of the school and the lake and as it is the intention to construct play grounds and gardens at this point it was considered essential that no part of the works should appear above ground and that they should be free from objectionable odors. It was also desired that the system should give continuous service with a minimum of attention. Though
the type of soil is not naturally favorable for the sub-
irrigation method of treatment, being mainly a non-porous

Though the school is designed for only sixty

further extensions, to provide a system capable of taking
care of 100 inmates.

GENERAL DESCRIPTION.

As shown on the general layout Plan No. 1 it is
proposed to discharge the laundry waste directly into the
lake through a six-inch tile drain. In addition to re-

no chemicals, etc., used in washing enters the treatment
works, and is neutralized. To secure protection from frost
a tank is provided. The sewage from the toilets, baths, etc., is
carried by a six-inch tile (designated Sanitary on the plan)
to the septic tank with the dosing or syphon chamber
attached. From the syphon chamber the liquid is automatic-
ally discharged by two three-inch "Anther" syphons to
the disposal bed. The effluent enters the lake
through a six-inch cast-iron soil pipe laid by means of a

LAUNDRY WASTE.

As already stated the waste from the laundry is
not treated but is discharged directly into the lake. A
six-inch cast-iron soil pipe carries the waste from the
building to the double manhole "A". See details of
Manholes Plan No. 3, and from this manhole a six-inch
tile is laid for about fifty feet in the same trench as
the sanitary drain and then carried direct to the double manhole "A" which, as shown on Plan No. 3, has two separate chambers at different elevations, the lower receiving the laundry waste, and the upper the affluent from the septic tank. From this manhole the laundry waste is carried through a six-inch tile pipe laid through the centre of the disposal bed to manhole "C" and thence through a six-inch tile to Canyon Lake.

SEPTIC TANK AND SYPHON CHAMBER.

The sewage, other than the laundry waste, leaves the building through a six-inch cast-iron soil-pipe to the double manhole "A", thence through a six-inch tile to the septic tank. As shown on Plan No. 2 the septic tank and syphon chamber are combined and are to be constructed of a 1, 2 and 3 concrete mix. To secure protection from frost a double plank roof with a six-inch air space is provided. The septic tank itself is seven feet wide, seventeen feet long and six feet deep at the centre. To facilitate the removal of sludge the bottom of the tank slopes towards the inlet end, and a manhole is placed in the roof at this point. The affluent enters the tank through a six-inch cast-iron soil-pipe and by means of a tee and a short length of pipe is carried one foot below the sewage line, thus avoiding any disturbance to the surface scum.

From the septic tank the sewage flows over the dividing wall to the syphon chamber; two baffle boards carried one foot below the standing level of the liquid preventing any undue disturbance.
From the siphon chamber the sewage is discharged through two three-inch "Artho" automatic siphons designed to discharge under an eighteen-inch head. As the siphon chamber is seven feet square it will carry about 450 imperial gallons before discharging to the disposal beds. With one hundred inmates this will be from one-third to one-half the daily amount of sewage to be taken care of and will therefore allow ample resting periods for the disposal beds.

DISPOSAL BED.

As already stated this method was decided upon as it would give (1), Continuous service with minimum attention, and (2), Absence of any works above ground and freedom from objectionable odors.

Though the nature of the soil, which is mainly a non-porous clay, is not favorable for this method of treatment, this can be overcome by excavating to the desired depth and laying the four-inch field tile on a fifteen-inch bed of gravel.

As shown on Plans Nos. 1, 4 and 5 the bed is 120 feet wide by 100 feet long. The affluent from the siphon chamber is discharged through a six-inch tile to the double manhole "B" and from there flows through the two six-inch tile headers. From the headers it is distributed over the bed through thirty branches, each 100 feet long, of four-inch field tile, laid with open joints on the fifteen-inch bed of gravel.

RECOMMENDATIONS RE OPERATION.

Though the proposed sewage disposal plant requires less attention than any other standard method of treatment there are certain duties that are necessary to ensure successful and continuous operation. These duties are increased when the system has to operate under extreme winter conditions such as prevail in the vicinity of McIntosh, Ontario. To ensure satisfactory service the following suggestions are made:

(1) - If the system is started up during cold weather it is advisable to have as much hot water as possible enter the septic tank, thus aiding the bacterial action.

(2) - As eighteen inches of earth over the disposal bed is about the maximum depth allowable in order that sufficient air will reach the sewage, it is advisable, especially during the first winter's operation, to cover the entire bed with manure or straw. No doubt more
successful operation would be secured if this were done every winter.

(3) - As shown on Plan No. 2, an overflow pipe is provided from the siphon chamber. The purpose of this pipe is twofold, as in addition to taking care of the sewage in case the siphone stopped working, it provides an outlet for the air from the disposal bed, as it is receiving its charge of sewage from the siphon chamber. To ensure a free outlet for this air it is essential that no trap be placed in the sanitary drain between the ventilating stack in the building and the septic tank.

Sir:

In your letters of November 11th and 12th you state that the Indian Department now propose to install a large water tank on high ground above the school to provide a gravity system of water supply.

The proposal to install a large water tank on the hill is, I think, Mr. Orr's suggestion, based upon observations made by him during his inspection of the site. During my visit to the site last week I obtained the elevation of the top of this hill in relation to the school building. The top of the hill is at elevation 135.00 and the ground on the back of the school about 118.00. A level sight from the top of the hill to the school building shows that the elevation of the top of the hill would correspond to a point on the building about 5.7 feet below the eaves.

I quite appreciate that the decision to install a large tank on the cliff rests entirely with the Department of Indian Affairs, but it seems to me that there are two factors which will have an important bearing on this decision. These are: 1. Whether or not the proposed tank is to provide for fire protection as well as for a domestic water supply. 2. The cost of the tank as compared with the cost of a pressure tank, particularly as 30 h.p. can be obtained from the water power development.

From rough level notes on hand and scaling the height of the building from the plans the following are the approximate elevations of:

1 - Basement floor of school - elevation 109.00
2 - Ground elevation outside of building 112.00
3 - Top of Roof - elevation 161.00
4 - Top of Hill - elevation 135.00

A tank for domestic water supply alone, with a four-inch stand pipe feeding into the water system in the basement, would, in order to give 30 pounds pressure on the taps on the second floor, have to be 40 feet high above the top of the hill. A tank, with a six-inch stand pipe and high enough to give a pressure of say 65 pounds, for fire protection, at the ground hydrants, would have to be 124 feet high above the top of the hill, or 95 feet above the roof.

When it is considered that temperatures ranging down to 40 below zero will be experienced at McIntosh you will appreciate that the cost of constructing these tanks and protecting them from freezing will amount to quite a large sum of money. In fact, Mr. Simmons has stated that to construct a tank as outlined above for domestic water supply only would cost in the neighborhood of $40,000 or $50,000. While that same classification would have to consist of a steel supporting structure and would likely cost between $10,000 and $15,000.

In view of the above and in view of the fact that 30 h.p. will be available from the power development at McIntosh it seems to me that this power should be utilized in some manner which can be economically connected to a 20 kilowatt motor, pumping direct to the hydrants in case of fire, or through a pressure storage tank for domestic water supply, will provide by far the most economical system of water supply and fire protection, even though a small auxiliary pump of sufficient capacity to meet the requirements of the domestic water supply were installed in addition to the automatic pump connected for both purposes. The pump suggested for this purpose would throw 250 gallons in either three or four streams clear over the buildings. Both systems, that is, the large storage tank suggested by Mr. Orr, and the pressure system suggested by me, have their advantages and disadvantages. I quite realize that the pressure system is more mechanical than the other but at the same time these systems are reliable and I know from experience that they do give practically automatic operation with very little trouble.

It would appear that the Department of Indian Affairs desire to have a larger quantity of storage water on hand than the arrangement suggested in Mr. Orr's report. If such is the case I would suggest that as an alternative layout to that suggested by Mr. Orr, that a pressure storage tank, with a capacity of 1,500 imperial gallons, be supplied. If this size of tank is required, and if it is thought advisable to have an auxiliary pump, I would advise that a separate pump house be built to contain the pumping apparatus and also the 1,500 gallon pressure tank. Sir:

Re McIntosh Indian Mission School.

In order to confirm our verbal instructions of November 9th to Mr. J.H. Simmons, contractor for the McIntosh Indian School, a letter was sent to Mr. Simmons stating that the Department of Indian Affairs authorized the construction of the McIntosh dam by him on the same terms as he was constructing the septic tank, that is, on a basis of proven cost plus 10%.

The contractor was at that time rushing the work on the school in order to get his contract completed as quickly as possible. In this work, however, the contractor was handicapped by lack of transportation of building materials from the station to the site and from the source of gravel supply, which was a pit well located on Canyon Lake about half a mile east of McIntosh Station and about a half miles from the school. The gravel was hauled from the pit to the school in a barge towed by a small motor boat. Even working day and night it was impossible for this mode of transportation to haul all the materials to the school before freeze-up, with the result that when freeze-up did occur there was not a supply of sand or gravel available to start construction on the dam or septic tank. Under these circumstances, therefore, the contractor was not in a position to start concrete work on the dam and septic tank when authorized to do so.

Subsequently, a new supply of sand and gravel was secured adjacent to the site of the school and last Wednesday I received notice that the contractor was ready to proceed with the construction of the dam. On Thursday Mr. Gow left for McIntosh to supervise the continuation of the dam, but found upon examination of a portion of the river bed which had been unwatered that there were seams and shallow layers of rock through and under which water was flowing. The contractor removed the fissured rock on one side of the channel by blasting them out and solid rock and arrangements were made to remove all shattered rock in the stream bed along the dam line. On Saturday last weather conditions were so severe that work on the dam was stopped, and because of the severe weather and blizzards prevailing since, and also because the contractor was closing down on all work for the Christmas holidays, work on the dam has been stopped until January 2nd or 3rd.

The Director,
Dominion Water Power & Reclamation Service,
Department of the Interior,
Ottawa, Ont.

The construction problem is quite simple and under summer conditions would be quickly and easily handled. Under winter conditions, particularly with small masses of concrete, extra precautions have to be taken to prevent freezing of the concrete to secure proper set and bond. Likewise extra care will have to be taken in grading, compacting, and sealing the foundations prior to placing concrete or masonry. I am quite confident, however, that the dam when constructed will be entirely satisfactory, and in order to ensure a proper set and to safeguard against freezing I have shipped to Moiintosh two old Red River tents which can be kept over the work and the concrete kept warm by a couple of old camp stoves.

The seams and layers of rock revealed in the river bed were not anticipated, as the shore rock is all solid. An additional expense is therefore necessarily involved to secure a water tight seal for the dam. On the other hand, sand and gravel have been obtained closer to the site, which should to some extent reduce the cost of construction, but the saving here will hardly offset the additional expense necessary to secure proper foundations and the slower progress due to winter conditions. Under the circumstances, it is quite possible that the estimate for the dam and unwatering may be exceeded.

In reply to my wire of November 19th stating that inspection had not been provided for, you wired that Brother Gauthier had been asked to act as inspector on the construction of the septic tank and dam. Brother Gauthier received a wire from the Department of Indian Affairs asking him to give whatever assistance he could in supervising the work and checking the time. In reply Brother Gauthier wrote Mr. Orr stating that he would assist us providing he was paid full time and asked under whose authority he was to act. This matter was apparently unsettled on Dec. 9th, as you will note from the copy of letter attached, and so far as I know, is still unsettled. From the above you will realize that no check has been kept on either labor or materials in the excavation and construction of the septic tank and dam.

In order to keep a close check on all time and materials entering the dam and septic tank from this date I have instructed the contractor to cease work on the dam, with the exception of hauling the necessary sand, gravel and rock, until after the New Year, when an engineer from this office will reside on the job until it is finished.

Your obedient servant,

Sgd. C.H. ATTWOOD,

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Scott,

A detailed report with plans and estimates has been submitted by the Dominion Water Power Branch of Winnipeg, on the proposed hydro electric and water work system for the McIntosh Indian Residential School. This report contains a number of schemes all of which I have carefully examined, and discussed with Reverend Father Boyer, when he visited this office.

The first proposal provides for a water supply system and electric lighting plant operated with gas engine, without hydro electric power, and the second proposal provides for the operation of both systems with hydro electric power available on the school site.

As you are aware the Department has already decided to adopt the second proposal and the construction of the dam for the hydro electric power is now being carried out by the contractors for the building, under the supervision of an officer of the Dominion Water Power Branch, but only this part of the scheme is authorized at present and will be attended to this fiscal year. This part of the work was considered necessary in order to enable the rest to be proceeded with next spring. The project as submitted should be accepted but with modifications which will not reduce the cost of erection materially but will keep down the maintenance cost. The scheme in summary which I would recommend would consist of the following items:

A power house 30' x 18' located 325' below the dam, a distance of 300' feet south of the school building, where the hydro electric machinery is to be installed in the basement together with pressure tank, motors and pumping outfit.
MEMORANDUM: Mr. Scott.

A turbine of horizontal type, having a capacity of 30 H.P., to operate a 17 K.W. direct current generator. This generator will supply ample power to provide for an adequate fire protection, also the operating of the pumping units, lighting system, laundry, work shops, etc.

The water supply system will consist of 46" x 16' pneumatic pressure tank, which will be supplied by a centrifugal pump with a capacity of 250 gallons per minute, operated by a 15 H.P. motor. The water intake is to be located in the turbine chamber in the power house. The pump to be equipped with a device so the hose or stand pipe can be fed directly from the pump at the pressure required in case of fire.

To save the cost of maintenance it is proposed to incorporate in the above mentioned scheme the small pumping unit lately authorized as a temporary water supply. I would not suggest the installation of several hydrants outside the building on account of the high cost of such work, and the great care required to keep them in good working order. As a practical means of protecting the building from bush fires, I would recommend the purchasing of a portable engine and pump of the type used by the fire rangers. This apparatus would require the installation of one hydrant only, on the north west side of the school building, which is the only place where a reliable source of water is not available for the feeding of the pump. The cost of the hydro electric power and the pumping plant with the exception of the dam would amount to approximately $7500. The cost of the water supply including connection to the building and hydrant would be $2,500.

As a means of reducing the cost of the above mentioned work, I would recommend that all the materials required be purchased direct by the Department by obtaining competitive prices, giving the various firms ample time to submit quotations. The work could be carried out advantageously by Brother Eugene Gauthier, who is experienced in this kind of work, and willing to take charge of it without remuneration other than his wages. An inspection of the work could be made from time to time if required by an officer from the Winnipeg office of the Dominion Water Power Branch.
By proceeding in the above mentioned manner it is quite probable that a number of changes could be made during the progress of the work which would help to keep the cost of erection as low as possible.

I may add that the question of erecting an elevated wooden water tank on the cliff North of the school, has been duly considered. This tank is not necessary with the proposed auxiliary electric centrifugal pump, as before described, which can be directly connected to the stand pipes or hydrants by a few simple manipulations of switches and valves. The installation of the tank as a safer fire protection would require a frost proof construction erected on an enclosed tower, which would have to be kept heated continuously during the cold season. Furthermore, this proposal is not advisable for the reason that ample electric power will be available from the turbine which may as well be taken advantage of in this case, on account of the extremely low cost of operation.

I would recommend that a few chemical fire extinguishers be placed on each floor of the building for emergency cases. Mine would be sufficient for the purpose, and these would cost in the neighborhood of $15.00 each.

Brother Gauthier, as you know, has had charge of the supervision of the building, and is well acquainted with the requirements of this institution, and well qualified to look after the interests of the Department in the execution of the above mentioned project.

There is an item of $5,000 in the budget Estimate 1925-6. It is probable that more could be found of it is decided to proceed with his work.

DÉPARTEMENTAL ENGINEER.
MEMORANDUM:

Honourable Charles Stewart,

A report accompanied by plans and estimates has been submitted by the Dominion Water Power Branch of Winnipeg for the development of a hydro electric power plant located on the site of the McIntosh School now in course of completion. It is proposed to utilize this power plant to supply the necessary electric current to operate all machinery to be installed in this building, such as water work system, fire protection, laundry, work shops, and lighting of the buildings.

According to a survey made it will be possible to develop 30 H.P., which will be ample to provide for the requirements of this institution with practically no maintenance costs. The expenditure involved by the erection of this hydro electric power plant with the exception of the dam, which is now being built, will amount to approximately $7,200, and that of the water supply including the fire protection units will amount to $4,500. As a means of reducing the cost to a minimum it is suggested that the materials be purchased direct by the Department after obtaining competitive prices, and that the work be performed by day labour, under the supervision of one of the engineers of the Winnipeg office of the Dominion Water Power Branch. By proceeding in the above mentioned manner it is probable that a number of changes can be made during the progress of the work which will help to keep down the cost of erection.

In view of the recommendation made by the Departmental Engineer that the above scheme be adopted, I beg to ask your approval of this expenditure when funds are available from time to time.

Deputy Superintendent General.

On January 6th I left for McIntosh to take charge of the construction of the dam on the Canyon river in connection with the hydro-electric development for the Indian Residential School at McIntosh, Ontario. Previous to January a certain amount of work was done during November and December, 1924, comprising the following:

1. All earth excavation.
2. Cofferdams for unwatering the south side of the river from Station 2 + 90 to Station 3 + 25.
3. Some rock excavation from Station 2 + 90 to 3 + 25.
4. About 50 cu. yds. gravel hauled to the site.
5. About five cords of wood hauled to the site.

The cost of labor for this work was $735.00

On January 7th the section from Station 2 + 84 to Station 3 + 24 was housed in by tents over a frame work of poles and four stoves and a small steam boiler set up for heating. Owing to the extreme cold, the work was carried on under difficulties and it was not until January 16th that the section from Station 2 + 88 to 3 + 22 was completed. As the greatest care was taken to protect the concrete from freezing no trouble is anticipated from this source. It is the intention to keep this section covered and heated until the 19th to ensure the proper setting of the concrete. Though the work from the standpoint of quality will no doubt be satisfactory the cost is considered excessive. The labor cost alone, which runs about $40.00 a day, will for this section of the dam 34 feet long,
amount to about $450.00.

The construction of small works of this nature during extreme winter conditions adds a high percentage to the cost. In this case the increased cost will probably be between 33 and 50 percent. Though some conditions might justify this additional cost, the necessity of completing the dam during this winter does not, in my opinion, warrant this increase. In addition to the increased labor costs, the construction of the non-overflow section will be further increased, if carried on during the winter, owing to the difficulty of securing boulders. A large number are available at the site, but with over a foot of snow on the ground it is almost impossible to locate them. Building the non-overflow section of ordinary concrete instead of masonry construction will mean a large increase in the amount of cement and gravel required.

The suggestion therefore is made that that section of the dam from Station 2 + 60 to Station 3 + 66 be completed now and the balance of the non-overflow be finished in the coming spring. By finishing the section stated above, all work requiring cofferdams will be completed and by constructing the non-overflow section to Station 2 + 60 no difficulty should be encountered in the spring from the increased run-off. This work might be either included in the power house contract or could be done by day labor.

The moving of the bunk-house off the line of the dam will be an awkward and rather expensive piece of work and if it is the intention to construct the balance of the non-overflow section by day labor it would be advisable to have it moved this winter by Mr. Simmons while he has his men and equipment at the site.

"SCHRAMM" Double-Cylinder Engine-Driven Triplex Pump

ROAD Contractors have for some time past demanded a high pressure, heavy duty pump that would deliver water through long pipe lines with an even flow. With this thought in mind we have developed the "SCHRAMM" Double-Cylinder Engine-Driven Triplex Pump. The Engine was designed to specially meet the requirements of this particular unit. It is a horizontal, two-cylinder, four-cycle, throttle-governed gasoline motor.

The two cylinder feature makes the unit a steady running power plant with a minimum of vibration due to the alternately exploding cylinders. It also helps insure a steady flow of water. Connection to the pump is made by means of broad-faced, machine-cut gears, well guarded, to prevent accident to the operator. The direct connected feature makes a most compact and neat equipment.

The engine base, cylinders and water hopper are cast integral, and are made of close-grained gray iron of the highest quality. The cylinders are machined and ground accurately to size.
The pistons are of close-grained gray iron accurately machined and ground to a perfect fit with the cylinder.

The connecting rods are of steel. They are nicely proportioned and well balanced. The piston end of the rods are fitted with a solid bronze bushing, which is securely forced into the rod and fitted to the piston pin. This bearing is lubricated from the top of the piston by means of an oil tube running down through the bearing.

Another big feature of the engine on this unit is the bearings. They are made of a high grade babbitt metal, accurately turned and scraped, and fitted into the base. On the "SCHRAMM" Engine, we do not follow the old method of pouring the babbitt metal into the rough casting of the frame. All of the babbitt bearing shells are interchangeable and in case of excessive wear can be replaced by an inexperienced man.

All bearings have proper grooves distributing the lubricant to all points. The bearings are exceptionally broad and the shaft is large in diameter. These parts are practically indestructible.

The enclosed crank-case is also an important feature of "SCHRAMM" units. It prevents dust and dirt from getting into the cylinder and bearings, and therefore, prevents excessive wear to these very important parts of the unit.

The pump is of the same type as used in our line of single-cylinder engine-driven tripex pumps, with the exception that the cylinders are brass lined. The pistons are also of brass. This prevents both cylinders and pistons from becoming corroded, due to water laying in the cylinders when the pump is not in use. This is a feature very seldom practiced by other manufacturers of road pumps. It is specially designed with extra large valves and water passages so as to obtain low water velocity.

The valves are easily accessible. The pistons are guided by separate cross heads and are outside-packed. All bearings on the connecting rod and crank are adjustable.
Standard equipment of these outfits consist of the engine and pump mounted on steel channels, in order that it may be set alongside a stream or lake, for forcing water long distances, under high pressure, to any place where the road is being constructed.

It is also especially adaptable for irrigation work.

Where it is necessary to move the outfit about, we are equipped to furnish the machine with wheels having standard 30"x33½" automobile tires and demountable rims. In this case we can furnish the equipment with a handle for pulling about by hand, or with a draw-bar for attaching to a wagon, automobile or motor truck. This equipment is shown on the front page of this bulletin.

This particular unit is also especially well adapted for fire fighting service in rural communities. It is impossible for the smaller towns to equip themselves with a fire-fighting apparatus costing several thousand dollars, but with the "SCHRAMM" double-cylinder, engine-driven triplex pumping unit, an equipment can be had that will furnish adequate protection for only a few hundred dollars. This will make all smaller communities totally independent of the larger towns adjacent to them. For this purpose we recommend that the outfit be mounted on the rubber-tired wheels. In this case the draw-bar and handle is always furnished.

We also recommend that the outfit be equipped with the wire basket and supports as shown in the cut on page 2 for holding the suction hose and discharge hose. The outfit can then be attached to the back of any automobile, wagon or even to a motorcycle, should such a machine be available, and hauled to the fire.

Any one of these equipments will have sufficient power to haul the "SCHRAMM" outfit at high speed over even the roughest country roads. If none of these are available then the outfit can be hauled by two men. The light weight, compact construction and even balance, coupled with the fact that the wheels are equipped with roller bearings, make it easy for two men to handle the outfit.

This outfit will give sufficient water for handling a one-half inch fire nozzle, when the fire is a considerable distance from the water supply. Should the water supply be close to the fire it will be found that the outfit will give sufficient water to play two streams on the fire under high pressure and quickly extinguish same. There is always a lake, creek or even a well into which the suction hose for the pump can be thrown without any trouble.

MATERIALS TO BE SUPPLIED:

(a) Runner. The runner shall be of the latest improved type, with heavy steel plate buckets cast into heavy hub and outer band of tough grey iron, truly balanced and sound and free from blow holes and surface defects, securely keyed to the wheel shaft.

(b) Guide Casing and Gate Operating Mechanism. The regulating gates shall be of cast iron or semi-steel and shall be accurately made to pattern so as to permit of a tight fit upon one another in their closed position. The gates shall be connected by links to a cast iron regulating ring concentric with the main shaft and suited to control by compensating governor.

(c) Wall Frame of suitable dimensions and of cast iron for connection to the wheel pit wall.

(d) Quarter Turn. The quarter turn shall be of cast iron, split and provided with hand holes.

(e) Turbine Shaft. The shaft shall be of the best open shafts hearth forged steel and shall have a forged thrust collar to take the unbalanced thrust of the runner.

(f) Bearings. The wheel shaft will be supported by at least two bearings, viz: Lignum Vitae Guide and Thrust Bearing mounted on the top of the guide apparatus and adjustable by bronze screws. The ring oiling thrust bearing behind the runner is mounted on a heavy cast iron pedestal, bolted to the foundation beam and guaranteed to run without heating.

(g) Pulley. Pulley of cast iron, 18" face, and sufficient diameter to connect with a 12" pulley on the shaft concentric with the generator, which operates at 1150 r.p.m.

(h) Draft Tube. The draft tube shall be conical tube of 18 plates, 7' long. It will be riveted to a cast iron single ring bolted to the Quarter Turn.

(i) Governor Connections. There shall be provided such connections as are required for operating the gates by means of Size D Woodward Compensating Governor.

Double Suction, Horizontally Split Shell Centrifugal Pump, direct connected by flexible coupling to electric motor.

We briefly enumerate below a few of the leading features of these pumps:

**GENERAL DESCRIPTION:** The pump shell is horizontally split, the lower half containing the suction and discharge connections (flanged) and the lower half of the journals, all cast in one piece. The upper half is merely a cover, and provided with water pipes to stuffing boxes and air cock.

**IMPELLER:** The impeller is of the double suction, enclosed type, made of cast bronze, finished smooth all over, inside and out, and each one is designed for the conditions under which it is to operate. The impeller is keyed to the shaft, and further held in place by brass sleeves, screwed on to the shaft with right and left hand threads, and completely covering the shaft to the outside of the stuffing boxes.

**LABYRINTH RINGS:** So as to facilitate repairs, the impellers are provided with wearing rings of the labyrinth type.

**BEARINGS:** Bearings are ring oiled, with large oil wells and glass oil gauge. They are lined with best babbit metal, and are carefully fitted.

**BALANCING:** To eliminate the slight end thrust which is developed in double suction pumps, a balancing port is provided in the lower half of the pump shell.

**THRUST BEARING:** To take up any slight tendency to end thrust which may develop, and to hold the impeller in the desired position as regards the labyrinth rings, the outboard bearing is provided with a double thrust collar, made in the shape of a spool, the pump shaft being turned down so that it passes through the centre of the spool, which is held firmly in place by a nut and lock nut on the end of the shaft.

**STUFFING BOXES:** The stuffing boxes are provided with lantern glands, and water sealed, so that they need not be screwed up tight. Gland studs are of the hinged pattern, and glands are not split. The casting below the stuffing boxes is of the U shape, and acts as a catch basin for any water which may leak through the glands. It is drilled and tapped for a pipe connection in the bottom, to carry the drip to the drain.

**FLEXIBLE COUPLING:** The flexible coupling is made with pins engaging with rubber rings, so that it has flexibility and allows for end play of the motor.

**EXTENDED BASE:** The extended base is of substantial design, and is made up specially to suit the particular motor required.

**BELT DRIVEN PUMPS:** Any of these pumps can be made with two pedestal bearings and pulley, in place of the motor.

The yoke is a ring made of open-hearth steel, hot rolled and butt welded. Rolled steel is an ideal material for motor frames because of its high magnetic permeability, uniform structure and great strength.

Front Bracket
The brushholders are clamped to insulated rods mounted on the front bracket. The proper position of the brushes is determined at the factory and should not be changed.

Armature
The armature is wound so as to permit excellent ventilation. The coils are form wound and are thoroughly insulated. The shaft can be removed from the armature in all except the smallest motors without disturbing the windings.

Bearing
The bearings are bronze bushings in the small motors and babbit-lined iron sleeves in the larger sizes. They are fully protected from dust by end caps and felt washers. The two bearings of each motor are interchangeable. Automatic oil-ring lubrication is used.
WESTINGHOUSE direct-current commutating-pole motors represent the most advanced design in direct-current machines for general, constant and adjustable-speed power purposes; they are especially suitable for driving machine tools and for other service where the load is frequently started, stopped and reversed. Among their special features are the following:

**Great Mechanical Strength**—The frames and feet are made of forged open-hearth steel, which provides great strength and reduces the weight and dimensions. The bearings have large area, and the shafts, which are of axle steel, are unusually heavy.

**Excellent Commutation**—The commutation is practically sparkless on all loads, overloads, and speeds, and in either direction of rotation without change in the brush position. The life of the commutator is very long and brush renewals are rarely required.

**Dustproof Bearings**—The bearings are protected from the entrance of dust and are automatically lubricated so that their life is very long. They are designed to permit the motor to be used in the severest gear service.

**High Efficiency**—The efficiency is high at all loads. The overload capacity is ample for all services in which these motors are used, and extremely high momentary peak loads can be handled without injury to the motor.

**Reliability**—Beyond an occasional inspection and oiling and infrequent renewals of the brushes, these motors require practically no attention and will insure continuity of service.

Semi-Enclosed Motor

Front covers are held by latches and are easily removed, but cannot become loose or fall off under vibration.

Large Type SK Motor

Type SK motors of approximately 125 horsepower and larger have cast-steel frames. The frame, brackets, and bearings are split horizontally.

Back-Geared Motor

Back-geared parts can be supplied for motors of small and moderate capacities. The construction of the gear, countershaft, and bracket is especially strong and rigid. Gear cases can be supplied on order.

Enclosed Motor

Enclosed motors are supplied in capacities from 1 to 25 horsepower. They are dust-proof, and can be made weatherproof when so ordered. Ribs on the brackets and covers aid in dissipating the heat.

Vertical Motor

Vertical SK motors can be supplied in all standard ratings. The weight of the armature is carried by a large ball bearing which operates immersed in oil. The lubrication is automatic.

Sir:

Enclosed is a revised report on the water
supply and power installation, McIntosh Indian school.
You will note that this report provides for a change from
electric driven machinery to belt driven machinery.

This change in design was made at the
request of Ruther Bovey of the McIntosh Indian school
who requested that the plant be designed to provide for
the simplest form of operation and also to provide them
with accommodation for a carpenter shop and a blacksmith
shop.

In addition to the changes of the power
installation a considerable improvement has been made
in the general layout of the water system, and even though
the automatic features are not provided for in the present
layout the layout does, I think, provide for a simple and
easily operated system. The inexperienced attendant
should have no difficulty in watching the air gauge and
water gauges and keeping a continuous water service. The
other main feature is that all the water equipment is
housed in the powerhouse and protected from freezing con-
ditions, and the intake being under a head from the turbine
chamber will always insure water service in the school
building, even though the pump be temporarily out of order.

If the Department of Indian Affairs are not
comitted to the first layout submitted by Mr. Gow I would,
in view of the simplicity of operation by inexperienced
attendants, recommend that either alternative "A" or "B"
of the present layout be accepted. I would like to be
advised which installation the Department of Indian

REVISED REPORT ON THE
WATER SUPPLY AND POWER INSTALLATION,
McINTOSH INDIAN SCHOOL.

With the completion of the McIntosh Indian school and the installation of the heating plant and various machinery it was seen that it would not be feasible to install the pumping plant and pressure tank in the school building as stated in Mr. Gow's report, and that a separate building to house this equipment would be required. In further discussions with Father Bovey relating to the general layout and operation of the plant he asked to have the installation as simple as possible and to eliminate the use of electric motors by substituting belt driven machinery. His reason for this latter request was that the motors would require skilled attention and in case of trouble would necessitate sending an electrician from Winnipeg to make the necessary repairs, whereas with the belt driven plant he felt that the school officials could handle most of the troubles themselves. Furthermore Father Bovey stated that the original layout did not provide sufficient accommodation for machine and carpenter shops.

Accordingly I have had prepared plans showing a revised layout of the power plant and water system. From the attached blue prints of the above plans you will note that the entire installation is located in the power house and that all machinery is belt driven. With this layout it is possible to have the water supply taken direct from the wheel pit, thus...
overcoming the difficulties of freezing at the intake.

Another advantage of this change is that in case the pump was out of order water supply would still be available because the intake to the water system is under a pressure head. The increased size of the powerhouse building provides the accommodation for carpenter and machine shops desired by the school officials.

Two alternatives of revised layouts are shown on the accompanying plans. In one case a blacksmith and machine shop together with an enlarged carpenter shop is provided. The other alternative provides for carpenter shop only. Estimates with estimates of cost are submitted for approval of the Department of Indian Affairs as to which layout should be adopted.

The original layout by Mr. Gow provided for a 17½ horse-power, belt-driven from the turbine. This arrangement supplied all the lighting and the power required for motor-driven pumps and motor-driven lime kiln and carpenter shops. This design proved unsatisfactory in operation of the water system. In the present revised layout now submitted it is proposed to install the following:

Hydraulic.

No change has been made in the turbine installation, this consisting of a 24-inch horizontal runner with Woodward Compensating Governor.

Electric.

The size of the generator has been reduced from a 17½ K.W. to a 10 K.W., D.C. As the pumping plant will be belt driven from the turbine the generator only supplies power for lighting and the motor for the laundry and kitchen.
WATER SUPPLY.

The pumping plant comprises a centrifugal high lift pump with 250 gallons per minute capacity against 60 lbs. pressure; a 3" x 3" Curtis air compressor, and a 4' 0" x 16' 0" steel pressure tank. As both the pump and air compressor are belt driven it will not be possible to have automatic control. With the large capacity of the pump, however, it will only take a few minutes to pump the day's supply into the pressure tank.

The water supply will be taken directly from the wheel pit, the pump thus receiving the water under a head. The force main from the pressure tank to the school will be a 4 inch W. I. pipe protected from frost.

The main general changes are:

1 - A general improvement in the layout of the water system in that it eliminates a long suction intake and will provide a continuous water service even though the pump is not in service.

2 - The reduction in size of the electric motor and the elimination of all meters; all machines being belt driven from the turbine.

3 - In the revised scheme "Alternative A" calls for a two storey building 40' x 20'. This provides a blacksmith shop and power house on the first floor and carpenter shop on the second floor. "Alternative B" provides for a carpenter shop only on the second floor. In both these alternatives the cost of hoisting and pulleys in carpenter and blacksmith shops have been included in the estimates.
ESTIMATED COST.

From the estimates given below for this layout it will be noted that the total cost of the combined hydroelectric development and water supply system exceeds Mr. Gow's estimate by $3,500.00. A large part of this increase is due to the increased cost of the dam, which when completed will cost about $8,100.00. The increased cost of the dam is due chiefly to,

A - The large extra cost of winter construction on small work of this nature.

B - When unwatered numerous seams were discovered in the bed of the river channel. This involved considerable rock excavation to obtain proper foundations and was an unexpected contingency not provided for in the original estimate.

C - The extra height of dam and increased width of and sluice deck.

D - Increased cost of enlarging powerhouse to for installation of pumping plant, black carpenter shop.

The estimates for the two alternatives follows:

(g) Pulley. Pulley of cast-iron, 9" face, and sufficient diameter to connect with a 12" pulley on the shaft concentric with the generator, which operates at 1150 r.p.m.

The unit will be constructed for installation on steel foundation beams, which are included in this proposal.

CAPACITY

This unit will develop 30 H.P. at a speed of 356-360 R.P.M. when operating under a net effective head of 15 ft.

RUNNER

The runner shall be of the Improved Samson Type, 17" in diameter, with heavy steel plate buckets cast...
RUNNER (Continued)

into heavy hub and outer band of tough grey iron, truly balanced and sound and free from blow holes and surface defects, securely keyed to the wheel shaft.

GUIDE CASING AND GATE OPERATING MECHANISM

The regulating gates shall be of cast iron of the balanced wicket type. They shall be made accurately to pattern and be faced on the edges and narrow strips on the backs to permit of a tight fit upon one another in the closed position. The gates shall be connected by links to a cast iron regulating ring concentric with the main shaft which is operated by a lever on the gate shaft.

QUARTER TURN

The quarter turn shall be of cast iron split vertically and bolted to the guide casing with bronze stuffing box for wheel shaft. It shall be supported by a heavy draft tube ring, which is carried on the foundation beams.

WALL RING

There will be provided a wall ring for concreting into flume wall. To this ring will be bolted a flange of the extension ring, forming a water tight joint.

WHEEL SHAFT

The wheel shaft shall be of the best open hearth forged steel and shall have a forged thrust collar to take the unbalanced thrust of the runner. It will have the runner forced on up to a shoulder by hydraulic pressure and securely keyed. There will also be keyed and fitted to it the 30" x 9" generator drive pulley and the governor pulleys.
BEARINGS

The wheel shaft will be supported by three bearings - one adjustable lignum vitae thrust bearing in the flume bolted to the crown plate and supported on cast iron pedestal, and by one ring ciling thrust bearing behind the quarter turn carried on a heavy cast iron pedestal bolted to the foundation beams, and one ring ciling outboard bearing on cast iron pedestal, all to be bolted to the foundation beams.

DRAFT TUBE

A steel plate conical draft tube of 1/4" plate 7 ft. long, will be provided. It will be rivetted to a cast iron angle ring bolted to the quarter turn.

GOVERNOR CONNECTIONS

There will be provided such connections as are required for operating the gates by means of Woodward Size D Mechanical Governor, as shown on accompanying cut. This governor will operate the gates over full range in 5 to 10 seconds.

RUNAWAY SPEED

The runaway speed of this unit under 15 ft. head with gates wide open and no load on the generator will be 630 R.P.M.

PERFORMANCE

The performance of this unit when properly installed in accordance with our drawings will be in accordance with efficiency curve fig.2.

WORKMANSHIP & MATERIAL

All material and workmanship shall be first class and shall be fully equal to the best engineering practice as used on similar equipment.

Enclosed please find three copies, together with vouchers, of Mr. J.H. Simmons' statement of cost, plus ten per cent, as per agreement, for work on the concrete dam and sewage disposal plant at the Indian Residential School, McIntosh, Ontario. These accounts have been checked as closely as possible and are recommended for payment.

The cost for constructing that portion of the dam from Sta. 3+66 to Sta. 2+10, namely $4,063.28, appears high, but the work was carried on under severe winter conditions and the utmost care had to be exercised to ensure a good job. The increase in cost over that estimated may be summarised as follows:

A - The large extra cost of winter construction on small works of this nature.

B - When unwatered numerous seams were discovered in the bed of the river channel. This involved considerable rock excavation to obtain proper foundations and was an unexpected contingency not provided for in the original estimate.

C - The extra height of dam and increased width of piers and sluice gates.

With reference to the cost of the septic tank and drains the actual cost will also exceed the estimate for this work. The cost to date, it will be noted, is $1,274.99 and as it will cost $150.00 to complete the work in the spring the estimate will be exceeded by about $200.00. The increase is mainly due to part of the work being carried on under winter conditions and to the encountering of large excavation of large boulders. A small amount of work still remains to be done on the septic tank and adding about one foot to the concrete walls and placing the wooden flooring on the top. It was considered advisable not to complete this at the time as, owing to the extreme cold weather, the cost would have been excessive. Dear Sirs:-

With further reference to the matter of the 17½ K.W. Generator ordered for McIntosh School, we find that this machine is completed and was on the point of being shipped when we received your wire instructing us to hold the order up.

We are sorry that you have changed your plans because we cannot see any way to change this for a 10 K.W. machine without incurring a heavy cancellation charge.

This machine was specially made for your order and it is not of a type which we keep in stock now on account of the almost universal use of alternating current in Canada.

If we were left with this machine on our hands it is very doubtful indeed if we would have an opportunity to sell it for a number of years. Ordinarily, and in the case of standard alternating current machines such as we are selling every month, we would be quite pleased to arrange for a customer to change an order like this without asking him to accept a cancellation charge, but in view of the special nature of this machine we feel that we cannot do so in this case.

As a matter of fact we would suggest that by far the best solution of the matter is for you to take this machine as it is and instal it. The fact that it is larger than you need will not have any practical disadvantage from the engineering point of view. It will not take any more power to run it than is required to handle the load which is actually on it.

With reference to the bearings, it is not practicable to convert this machine for ball bearings. There may be some condition with which we are not familiar which renders the use of
ball bearings advisable in this case, but we cannot think of what this might be.

We do use ball bearings in certain cases, more particularly for direct connected motor generator sets and similar machines; but for any motor or generator arranged for belt drive with an overhung pulley it has been our experience that ball bearings have certain disadvantages and we cannot think of any condition under which the sleeve bearing would not be satisfactory.

We would again urge upon you the advisability of using this machine, but if for any reason you positively cannot do so we will make you a proposition involving the substitution of a 10 K.W. generator with ball bearings.

Yours very truly,

THE LINCOLN ELECTRIC CO. OF CANADA, LTD.

Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter of the 9th instant together with a copy of a letter sent to you by Mr. Atwood District Chief Engineer, of Winnipeg, advising you of the progress of the work on the hydroelectric plant for the Metchock Indian Residential School at McIntosh, Ont.

In reply I beg to suggest that you district engineer communicate personally with the Manitoba Bridge and Iron Works of Winnipeg to insure that suitable connections are made on the pressure tanks for the vertical setting as provided for in your revised plans. I wish also to state that a copy of specification and form of tender have been sent to Charles Barber and Sons of Eastford for a quotation on the turbine for the above mentioned work. As soon as this received and provided their price is lower than those already submitted I shall send you their plan for your consideration. As suggested in your letter you may obtain prices for the wood stove panstock and other fittings. We have filled in the total amount on your quotation form and have attached our specification, also approximate plan and photo showing the general lay-out. You will note that the form of specification is slightly changed to suit our standard design.

Please note that we are using a one piece cast iron runner which we have found superior to the cast-in buckets for this class of work, also that our gate operating mechanism is not of the slipring type. We use alternate stationary and moving gates which has the same effect as the speed ring which has lately been adopted by other makers. This gives us an absolute face to adjust against, making a practically leak-proof gate, and one which is very easy to adjust.

Our standard 24" turbine is rated at 28 H.P. under 15 feet of head and this is all we have guaranteed. We shall, however, overgate it to give the full 30 H.P. Our next size of turbine is considerably large for the power required.

We carry our thrust on the turbine dome with an adjusting nut. It is of lignum vitae and iron and we have found that it is just as trouble proof and more durable than an outer bearing would be. The bearings in the turbine itself are of bronze of ample area and we have found that they give the very best of satisfaction.

We trust our proposal will meet with your approval and that we may be favored with your valued order.

Sir,

Re: McIntosh Indian Residential School.

This will acknowledge your letter of April 15th stating that the Department of Indian Affairs have approved Alternative B as submitted with my report of March 30th making provision for an extension to the power house at some future date.

Referring to paragraph three, the shafting was so designed to operate the pump, motors, etc., at the speeds given in the estimates per page five of the revised report of March 30th. This is a matter however that cannot be definitely decided until the speed of the pump, generator and air compressor as ordered is known. When the speed of these machines is furnished to me I can then determine the size of the pulleys required on the line shaft, the speed of which will be governed largely by the speed of the above machines and the speed of the turbine. I had also made provision for operating the generator, pump, air compressor and carpenters shop separately by operating each pulley individually by a friction clutch.

Paragraph eight of your letter states that definite arrangements have been made with the school authorities to have the work done by day labour by the lay brothers under the supervision of Brother Gauthier. Does this mean that

(1) The lay brothers will decide upon and purchase or rent all tools and equipment and hire all labour necessary to carry out the work.
(2) The supervising engineer will not be called upon to certify to vouchers and cost of the work.

The estimate submitted with Alternative A and B were based on competitive bids and I feel sure that tenders could be received from reliable contractors within these figures. In deciding to do this work by day labour I quite appreciate that the work may be done within, or for less than the estimates cost. On the other hand however, I wish to point out that work done by day labour has in many cases exceeded that done by contract, and under the circumstances I can give no guarantee that the estimate will not be exceeded.

I presume from your letter that in addition to the power house the completion of the dam and septic tank will also be done by day labour by the lay brothers.

Before we can complete the details of the power house and order the necessary shafting, piping, etc. it will be necessary for the Department of Indian Affairs to supply this office with a copy of the specifications and blue prints of the machines ordered.

Your obedient servant,

Conclusive Evidence

In 1916, the American Society for Testing Materials began comprehensive corrosion tests of uncoated sheets in order to determine their actual measure of rust resistance. These tests were conducted in different locations under widely differing atmospheric conditions, and included the following types of materials:

- Copper Bearing O. H. Steel.
- Non-copper Bearing O. H. Steel.
- Bass Steel.
- Non-copper Bearing Bass Steel.
- Puddled Iron.
- Non-copper Bearing Puddled Iron.
- Pure Iron.

The results and conclusions are most convincing, and are recorded in full in the report of Committee A-5, American Society for Testing Materials, at the meeting of the Society at Asbury Park, N. J., June 21-24, 1921. These findings are of particular value and interest to all users of sheet metal.

The Society states that its results and observations "have now reached a point where we may definitely conclude that copper-bearing metal shows marked superiority in rust-resisting properties as compared to non-copper-bearing metals of substantially the same general composition. From which superiority we may truly anticipate a marked increase in the service life for copper-bearing metals under atmospheric exposure of uncoated sheets."

Sir,

Re McIntosh Indian School.

This will acknowledge your letter of May 12th enclosing copy of a letter from the Department of Indian Affairs regarding the employment of labour and the purchase of the various materials and equipment required for the performance of the above mentioned work.

Last Tuesday and Wednesday I met Mr. Orr, Architect for the Department of Indian Affairs, at Kenora and travelled with him to Winnipeg. On Saturday Mr. Craig met Mr. Orr at McIntosh. While at McIntosh Mr. Craig freely discussed this work with Mr. Orr and also with the Reverend Father Bayes, Superior of the Oblate Order, and Father Boyer.

With respect to carrying on this work by day labour conditions at McIntosh have changed entirely since last fall and Father Bayes and Father Boyer both stated to Mr. Craig that they preferred to have the work carried by contract of hire rather than our own labour, as at present there are no Lay Brothers available at McIntosh to carry on the works, Brother Gauthier having been transferred to other work. Upon being asked by Mr. Craig what instructions they had received with regard to carrying on this work by day labour both Father Bayes and Father Boyer stated that the only instructions received were a copy of Mr. Macdonald's letter of April 30th as forwarded to us with your letter of May 12th.

Both Mr. Craig and myself have discussed the whole matter with Mr. Orr, who, while he has not been in touch with this work for some time, appreciated the unsatisfactory position which we were being placed in by the letter of instructions on April 30th, and upon his return to Ottawa would forward these instructions to the Deputy Minister of the Department of Indian Affairs and arrange for definite instructions for the performance of the work.

In view of the fact that the Lay Brothers at McIntosh are not anxious to carry out this work there are two methods of handling the work. The first is by contract, which will involve no purchase of plant and small tools or the hiring and payment of labour and have the advantage of the contractor's organization. The second is by day labour, carried our directly by this office. To do the work by day labour would involve renting a concrete mixer and the purchase of

Ottawa, Ontario.
small tools and equipment such as shovels, picks, sledges, drills, pails, rope, block and tackle, etc., etc. It is hardly feasible to rent the small tools mentioned above as certain portions of them would be used up in the work. I am quite willing to undertake the work on either of the above methods, but prefer the contract method, but in the final adjustment of this with the Indian Department I would like to have a clear-cut understanding as to my responsibility in the matter. CONCRETE WORK AND HARDWARE.

(a) Cement - All cement used in the work shall be Portland cement and shall conform to the Standard Specifications for Portland Cement of the Canadian Engineering Standards Association, issued February, 1932.

(b) Gravel - Gravel, providing it is of quality satisfactory to the Engineer, may be used for the concrete aggregate. It shall be clean, free from clay, lime, organic matter or other impurities, and contain no stones larger than 1/4".

(c) Sand - All sand for concrete shall be clean and siliceous, and shall be a well graded mixture of coarse and fine grains, with the coarse grains predominating. It shall be free from lime, clay or other impurities.

(d) Storage of Materials - Cement shall be stored in a weather-tight building, with raised floor to ensure dryness. Aggregates shall be so stored, on platforms or otherwise, as to avoid the inclusion of foreign material.

(e) Measurement of Materials - For the proportioning of concrete, 100 pounds by weight shall be taken as the equivalent of one cubic foot. Aggregates shall be measured by volume, in suitable containers approved by the Engineer.

(f) Proportioning of Materials - All concretes, unless otherwise specified, shall be in the proportion of one cubic foot of cement to four cubic feet of gravel. The amount of water to be used shall be a minimum consistent with the workability of the mixture and the class of work being done. Concrete for reinforced work shall contain only sufficient water to allow the mixture to flow freely around the reinforcement and fill the forms at every point.

(a) Mixing and Placing - All concrete shall be mixed in a batch mixer of approved type, not for a period of time not less than 2½ minutes. It shall be transported from the mixer to the work in water-tight conveyances, and shall be deposited in place within a period of 15 minutes after mixing. During placing, concrete shall be placed on the sides adjacent to the forms to ensure a smooth, even surface. The work is resumed after a period during which the previously placed concrete has partially set, the surface of the concrete in place shall be roughened, thoroughly cleaned of foreign material and laitance, thoroughly wetted, and then painted with a neat cement mortar before the placing of fresh concrete.

All mixing and placing of concrete shall be done in the presence of the Engineer.

(b) Forms - All forms for concrete shall be sufficiently water-tight to prevent leakage of cement, and shall be of substantial character, well-braced and sufficiently strong to hold the face of the concrete true to line. Forms for the exposed work shall be smooth-plumbed to ensure an even surface. Forms may be used more than once, provided they are thoroughly cleaned of all adhering cement before being used again. The design and character of the forms shall be subject to the approval of the Engineer.

(c) Removal of Forms - Forms shall not be removed from any concrete surface except with the approval of the Engineer.

(d) Curing of Concrete - After the removal of forms, the surfaces of the concrete shall be kept moist for so long as, and in such manner as, the Engineer may direct.
(b) Steel Reinforcement - Steel reinforcement shall consist of "Steelcrete" expanded metal as specified. The minimum lay of the sheets in either direction shall be 3 inches. The steel shall be so placed and supported in position as the Engineer may direct.

(a) Finishing - At the discretion of the Engineer, the surface of the concrete shall be finished with a grout containing one part of cement and not more than two parts of sand, trowelled to a smooth and even surface.

19 - PENSTOCK.

(a) Location - The penstock will run from the dam to the intake-chamber in the powerhouse, as shown on Plans Nos. 1 and 5, and will be approximately 325 feet long.

(c) Rock Excavation - The penstock shall be so laid that no part of it shall be above the hydraulic gradient. Where necessary to accomplish this, rock shall be excavated to the required depth.

(d) Supports - Supports for the penstock shall be provided at intervals of six feet, as shown on Plan No. 5. These supports shall be constructed of logs cut at the site. The supports shall rest on sills set on bed rock.

(e) Wood Pipe Connections - The connection of the wood-stave pipe to the steel thimbles at the dam and wheel-pit shall be so made that a satisfactory water-tight joint is obtained.

20 - POWER HOUSE.

(a) Site - The power house shall be situated as shown on Plan No. 1, the final laying out of the foundations to be determined by the Engineer.

(b) Foundations - The power-house shall rest on concrete foundation-walls, constructed to bed rock, and before pouring of concrete the rock foundations shall be cleaned of all loose material and dirt. Any seams or fissures...
in the rock foundation shall be cleaned out and filled with grout, if considered necessary by the Engineer.

(a) Foundation Walls - The foundation-walls shall be constructed of concrete, 12 inches thick, as shown on Plan No. 2, and shall be built from bed-rock up to the level of the base of the concrete-floor. The walls shall be continuous around the whole base of the powerhouse except at the tailrace, where the wall shall be carried across the opening by a steel I-beam as shown. There shall also be a cross-wall, 12 inches thick and constructed to bed rock as shown.

(b) Stud Walls - All studs in outside walls shall be 2 x 6". Studs shall be built up solid at angles, doubled at openings, and trussed over openings 3 feet or more in width. Studs shall be set at 16 inch centres and all placed straight, plumb and true. Studs shall be braced until secured by floor joists overhead. Sills shall be the same size as the studding and plates same size as studding, doubled, with joints well broken. Sills shall be set level and secured to foundations with 7/8" x 10" bolts with nuts and washers upon the ends and spaced five feet upon centres.

(c) Floors - The ground floor shall be constructed of concrete, six inches thick and reinforced with # 3-4-40 "Steelcrete" expanded metal. The floor shall be made five inches thick of concrete as specified, immediately covered with a grout containing one part of cement to three parts of sand to a depth of one inch, and struck off and trowelled to a smooth, level surface. Reinforcement shall be placed and supported in position in a manner approved by the Engineer.
