Sir:

Re Hydro Plant at McIntosh, Ontario.

I am in receipt of a letter this morning, from Macaw and Macdonald, General Contractors, Winnipeg, who tendered on the completion of the hydro plant at McIntosh, stating that on the advice of their foreman they are prepared to do the work on a cost plus ten per cent basis and give a guarantee that the total cost will not exceed $5,300. This letter is enclosed.

Mr. Macaw called at this office and brought with him his estimates for the work at McIntosh explaining that his foreman, who worked on the construction of the dam last winter, had shown them through his knowledge of conditions that their estimate was quite high. The estimate of Macaw and Macdonald was revised by their foreman and shown to me amounting to a total of $6,100, and Mr. Macaw's explanation for submitting his alternative fixture was that he feared his tender as submitted would probably be considered high. He further stated that his foreman and construction gang had just returned to the city having completed a contract for the C.I.R., and as his firm had no other work to offer they thought it would be to their advantage to bid at McIntosh on a cost plus basis, giving the Department the advantage of any saving which might accrue and at the same time guarantee that the total cost of the work would not exceed $5,300. Mr. Macaw explained that this offer was made in order to provide employment and keep his organization intact.

I informed Mr. Macaw that the tenders had been forwarded to Ottawa, but gave him no information as to the number of firms who had tendered nor the amount of the tenders, and agreed to submit this letter to the Department of Indian Affairs for their consideration. I felt, however, that in submitting the letter of Macaw and Macdonald to the Department it was only fair to inform Mr. Simmons that a letter had been received offering to do the work at McIntosh on a cost plus basis with an upset price at a figure considerably lower than those received in any of the tenders, and asked him if he would be prepared to do the work on a cost plus basis, naming an upset price for the contract. In reply to this Mr. Simmons has submitted a letter indicating that he would agree to do this work on a percentage basis, namely, cost plus ten per cent, with his previous tender price as an upset price.

J. T. Johnston, Esq.,
Director, Water Power & Reclamation Service,
Department of the Interior,
Ottawa, Ontario.
Although the receipt of the revised offers from the contractors after tenders have been received may be considered irregular, the saving to the Department is, I think, of sufficient amount to warrant consideration of these revised tenders.

Although the upset price stated by Mr. Simmons is higher than that of Macaw and Macdonald I personally feel that all the tenders submitted were high and feel confident that the work can be done for less than $5,300., and in view of the fact that Mr. Simmons was the lowest tenderer I am of the opinion that he can execute the work on a cost plus basis and therefore of the utmost importance to save and if these new offers are considered by the Department of Indian Affairs I would recommend that Mr. Simmons' offer of this date be given favorable consideration, or that he at least be given an opportunity to reduce his upset price to that of Macaw and Macdonald.

Upon receipt of a decision regarding these tenders from the Department of Indian Affairs I would be glad to receive a telegram advising me of that decision so that the contract may be let and work started immediately.

Your obedient servant,

G. H. Attwood,

Sir,

With reference to the heating of the hydro-electric power house of the McIntosh Indian Residential School, the original intention was to heat it by steam, supplied from the boiler of the school. This decision was arrived at owing to the fact that a two-inch steam pipe was being laid alongside the four-inch water pipe from the school to the powerhouse to prevent the water pipe from freezing; and further that Father Dyer stated that there were enough radiators left from the school to heat the power house. On taking this matter up with the school authorities on the ground, however, it has been found that only a small part of one radiator is left and that practically all the necessary radiators and pipe would have to be purchased.

From inquiries made of the different heating firms in the city I estimate that the cost of supplying steam radiators and fittings for the building would run something over $200.00. This seems rather high for the heating equipment and as the cost for two suitable box stoves with the necessary pipe will not exceed $50.00, I suggest that the necessary authority be obtained from the Indian Department for their purchase. I have taken this matter up with the school authorities and they are agreeable to have stoves in place of steam heating.

With the near approach of winter an early reply would be appreciated.

Your obedient servant,

Director, Water Power and Reclamation Service,

Sir,

Re McIntosh Indian School
Power Development.

In connection with the contract awarded to Mr. J.H. Simmons for the construction of the hydro-electric plant at McIntosh, and which is now nearing completion, the school officials are very anxious that the balance of the work be left until next spring. The work still remaining to be done by the contractor comprises a small amount of back-filling at the dam, powerhouse and water mains, painting of the powerhouse, connecting up the penstock to the steel thimbles in the dam and wheel pit and removing the tail-race cofferdam.

In taking up the question with the school officials they state that they are strongly opposed to the remaining work being finished during the winter for the following reasons:

(1) They will not, in any case, operate the plant until next spring.

(2) With the plant not operating they fear that considerable damage would result from ice during the winter months if the plant were completed.

(3) That the powerhouse cannot properly be painted during cold weather.

(4) That with the ground frozen the remaining back-filling cannot be done as well in the winter as in the spring.

In view of the school officials' decision not to operate the plant until spring there would, I think, be some danger of the plant being damaged by ice, if completed at the present time. With reference to the painting of the building and the back-filling, there is no question that this work cannot be done properly during the cold weather.

Mr. Simmons was authorized to start this work on August 24th, 1925, and according to the contract, was to have it completed on or before October 31st. Owing to one thing and another, but principally to the lack of proper supervision by the contractor, the work has been dragging along in a very disappointing manner, in spite of repeated instructions, both verbal and written, by Mr. Craig and myself urging the contractor to speed up the work, both for his own sake as well as the sake of the school officials. There being no penalty clause in the contract, however, little notice was taken of these requests, as practically no improvement took place in the methods of handling the work.

The Director,
Dominion Water Power and Reclamation Service,
Department of the Interior,
Ottawa.

As stated above, the school officials are very anxious that all of the remaining work should be left over until spring, and to this end a meeting was arranged in this office with Brother Eugene, representing Red River College, and the contractor Mr. J.H. Simmons. It was pointed out that the Department of Indian Affairs might prefer to have the work finished up before the end of the fiscal year, that the money was now voted and that otherwise it would be necessary to place an amount in the estimates and ask for a revote next year. At this meeting Brother Eugene and Mr. Simmons estimated that the cost of completing the contract would be approximately $300.00, and Brother Eugene agreed, if the work was left over until spring, to complete it for that amount.

To overcome the necessity of asking for a revote of any portion of this contract, and in order to meet the wishes of the school authorities that the work be left over until spring, it is suggested that the sum of $300.00 be deducted from the contract price of $5500.00 and be paid to the school authorities before the end of the fiscal year, they on their part agreeing to complete the unfinished work for this sum. As the work already completed, such as the penstock, wheel-pit, etc., would not be tested until spring, Mr. Simmons is willing to have this deposit cheque of $300.00 held as a bond until the work is completed and tested by me. A written agreement would, of course, be secured from both the school officials and the contractor. It might also be stated that Mr. Simmons is quite agreeable to the proposal and would like to see it adopted, if possible.

The work yet to be done is of such a nature that it can be done by the Lay Brothers equally well as by the contractor and entirely to the satisfaction of the school authorities. If the Department of Indian Affairs can arrange for the payment of $300.00 to the school officials for the completion of the contract before it is actually finished and the final payments to the contractor as per the suggestion outlined above I feel certain that the work can be completed to entire satisfaction of the school authorities and the Department. Holding the contractor's cheque for $300.00 will, I think, be ample security for the Department, as a bond, that the work already performed by the contractor has been satisfactory.

It might be pointed out that the school officials have been put to extra work and expense due to the delay on the part of the contractor and are very anxious to see him off the job and finish what work there is to do themselves.

Your obedient servant,

Memorandum.

Re - McIntosh Indian School Hydro-Electric and Water Supply Installations.

On August 24th, 1925, a contract for completing the hydro-electric and water supply plant at the McIntosh Indian School was awarded to Mr. Simmons. Previous to this, part of the dam had been built and all other equipment purchased, with the exception of the shafting and pulleys, electric switch-board and wiring, pipes and fittings, etc. The contract awarded to Mr. Simmons comprised the:

- Completion of the dam.
- Building the power house.
- Laying the penstock.
- Laying the water supply system from the power house to the school.
- Poles for power line to school building.

Though the contractor started the work during the last week of August progress was exceedingly slow, with the result that after five months the following items still remain to be done:

- Connecting up of the penstock to the dam and power house.
- Removal of the tailrace cofferdam.
- A certain amount of back-filling.
- Painting of the building.

The main cause of this delay was the lack of proper supervision by the contractor, together with the fact that the contract contained no penalty clause for non-completion on the specified date, October 1st. Though the contractor was instructed a number of times, both verbally and by letter, to make better progress, very little improvement in the handling of the work took place.

With reference to the completion of the remaining work to be done under Mr. Simmons' contract, a suggestion put forth by the Lay Brothers, to leave this work until spring has been taken up by me in my letter of January 16th.

The installing of the machinery, shafting, etc., is not included in the general contract, as by an arrangement with the Lay Brothers this work is to be done by and under their supervision. The contractor, however, was to
supply as an extra any unskilled labor required for the installation of the machinery. To date all the heavy machinery has been installed. There only remains the setting of the shafting, switch board, electric wiring, etc., and in view of the fact that the school officials have decided not to operate the plant until spring, the work of installing this equipment will naturally be carried on at their convenience.

The cost to date and the estimated amount necessary to finish the work are shown on the attached sheets. The items shown under the heading "Paid by Department of Indian Affairs" are those of which we have record in this office. Possibly other payments have been made of which we have no record, but in that case those amounts are shown under the heading "Amount Needed to Complete Work".

In addition to the statement of cost there is also enclosed a copy of "Estimate of Cost" submitted with my letter of July 22nd.

John Craig

Dear Sir:

On Friday last you informed me that the Department of Indian Affairs, in a letter dated February 6th, had no objection to me subletting to the Oblate Fathers the balance of the work yet to be done on the Hydro-Electric and Water supply installation at McIntosh upon the understanding that the subletting of the balance of the work does not release me from full responsibility for the satisfactory completion of the work, and further that my security deposit cheque of $500.00 shall be retained as a guarantee until the work is tested and accepted. I agree to the above conditions.

On February 26th an agreement was entered into between the Oblate Fathers and myself whereby they agreed to complete the remaining portion of my contract to your satisfaction. It was mutually agreed that the sum of $300.00 was sufficient to complete the work and I understand that this amount is to be deducted from the contract price and a certificate prepared covering the balance due under the contract.

As only one payment has been made on this contract I would appreciate having the certificate prepared and submitted to the Department of Indian Affairs at the earliest possible date.

Yours very truly,

J. H. Simmons

February 26th 1926.

It is hereby agreed between J. H. Simmons, Contractor for the construction of the hydro-electric development at McIntosh, Ontario, and the Oblate Fathers, that the contractor sublets to the Oblate Fathers the balance of the work to be done under its contract with the Department of Indian Affairs dated August, 1925, to complete the said development, and the Oblate Fathers agree to complete the work to the satisfaction of the District Chief Engineer of the Dominion Water Power and Reclamation Service, resident at Winnipeg, Manitoba, on a basis of actual cost plus a commission of $50.00.

It is further agreed by the said parties that as a basis of cost for the completion of the said power development that the time of Brother Eugene shall be paid for at a rate of 85 cents per hour; That of Brother Adolph at a rate of 75 cents per hour. That the use of team and driver shall be charged for at a rate of 65 cents per hour and that any other labor required, or expenses incurred to complete the contract by the Oblate Fathers shall be charged for at actual cost.

Payment for the completion of this work shall be made upon the presentation of the final account accompanied by a certificate of completion from the said District Chief Engineer of the Dominion Water Power and Reclamation Service.

Contractor: [Signature]

Oblate Fathers: [Signature]
Sir,

This will acknowledge your letter of Feb. 10th, enclosing a copy of a letter dated Feb. 6th from the Department of Indian Affairs, in which Mr. Simmons offers Mr. Simmons to sublet the remaining portion of his contract for the hydro-electric development and water supply installation for the McIntosh Indian School, to the Oblate Fathers.

Following this authorization, a meeting was arranged between Mr. Simmons, the contractor, and Brother Eugene, representing the Oblate Fathers, when an agreement was made for the subletting of this work. A copy of this agreement, signed by Father Beysa, Superior for the Oblate Order for this district, and Mr. Simmons, the contractor, is enclosed, together with a copy of a letter from Mr. Simmons to me, whereby he agrees to sublet the work under the prescribed conditions.

The agreement between Mr. Simmons and the Oblate Fathers is designed to protect the Oblate Fathers from any loss, and though the tentative estimate for this work was $300.00, the Oblate Fathers actually do the work at cost plus a fixed commission of $50.00, this amount being 10% of the estimated cost.

With the above arrangement completed an estimate has been prepared, two copies of which are enclosed. As will be noted, the $300.00 is deducted from the contract price of $500.00 and the amount due is the balance less the amount paid on Estimate No. 1 together with $47.33 for extra work done by the contractor.

The only item in the extras which was not connected with the contract was the item of $47.00 for repairing a small leak at the steel thimble in that section of the dam which was built in January, 1925. The leak was probably caused by a certain amount of freezing of the concrete before it was properly set.

You will note Mr. Simmons requests payment of the balance due on the contract at an early date, and in view of the work done and also that Mr. Simmons's security cheque for $500.00 is to be retained by the Department until final approval of the work, it is recommended that this payment be made to Mr. Simmons at an early date.

Your obedient servant,

'SGD' C.H. ATWOOD,
District Chief Engineer.

Dear Sir:

The following letter has been received from Mr. A. E. Fraser, District Warden at Fort William.

"I beg to report that in connection with the new Indian school that was built at McIntosh, a dam was built on the south Bay of Canyon Lake, to dam up the water for power purposes for this school.

It is my opinion that this matter should be taken up with the Indian Department at Ottawa, and arrangements made for immediate construction of the fish-way, as otherwise, the natural spawn of these fish will be wasted every Spring.

MEMORANDUM:

Re McIntosh Indian School

Power and Water Installation.

On hearing from Mr. J. R. Bunn, Inspector of Indian Agencies, a short time ago that there had been a fire in the McIntosh Indian School, Mr. Mooney who was at Sioux Lookout at the time, was instructed to visit McIntosh and make a personal inspection of the power plant with special reference as to how satisfactory the water supply had been during the fire.

The fire, it appears, had occurred in the laundry of the school and before any extensive damage was done was got under control. The chemical fire extinguishers were used until the centrifugal pump could be started when more than a satisfactory supply of water was obtained which quickly put out the fire. Rev. Father Perrault, Principal of the school, stated that he was more than satisfied and that with the equipment a stream of water was easily thrown over the school buildings.

The sewerage system appears to be working quite satisfactorily, the grounds in front of the school having now been graded and planted with potatoes, with practically nothing showing that a sewerage system had been installed.

The hydro-electric plant is giving entire satisfaction and even with the high water experienced no damage has been done or inconvenience occasioned in the operating of the plant. The 36" wood stove penstock was found in good condition, though it will be advisable to have this painted with a suitable tar paint, as otherwise its life will be considerably shortened. The painting should be done during this season as soon as the stage of high water has passed.

While at the school Father Perrault informed Mr. Mooney that they were quite concerned over the fact that due to the high water on Forest lake the water had started to flow through an old high water channel into Canyon lake. As shown on the attached sketch this channel is about half a mile west of the school. Mr. Mooney made an inspection and reports that this channel had been completely silted up and overrun with brush previous to the high water on Forest lake. This spring the lake was evidently high enough to cause the water to flow over the silt-filled channel with the result that the earth and silt eventually was washed away. At the time of Mr. Mooney's visit the channel was about 2'9" wide at the entrance, eventually widening to about 50' at a rock ledge approximately 800' from the entrance. The depth of water flowing through the channel was about 3' at the opening and about 1' at the rock ledge, where the velocity was quite high.
From information obtained it appears that the flow through this high water channel could be stopped by the building of a small dam on the rock ledge at the narrow section of the channel. Mr. Mooney states that at this location the ground on the south side is quite high and that though on the north side there occurs much loose ground gradually rises and there would be a small area only that might be flooded by the construction of a dam at this point. With the dam 60' wide a timber crib earth filled dam about 60' long and 3' high should be sufficient to meet the requirements. It might be advisable to have the upstream side sheeted with rough lumber in order to stop any possible washing away of the earth fill.

As already stated, this channel had been previously filled with silt and completely overgrown with bush and even with the high water of last year when water was wasting over the spillway some 3" or 4" deep no leakage occurred through this channel.

The accompanying photographs show the entrance to the high water channel, the narrow section at which it is suggested that the dam might be erected and certain views of the hydro-electric development at the school.

MEMORANDUM:

- Mr. Attwood -

Re: McIntosh Indian Residential School.

A memorandum dated July 5th was forwarded to Ottawa re McIntosh Indian School power and water installation in which was recommended the painting of the 36-inch wood-stave penstock. The dam is an old high water channel between Forest and Canyon lakes. This channel was overgrown with trees and bush and filled with silt. The exceptionally high stage this summer of Forest lake was sufficiently high to start water flowing over the top of this natural dam of silt and eventually swept it away with the result that a considerable amount of water is flowing through the channel into Canyon lake. As the control of the channel is about one and a half feet below the spillway level of the dam the storage on Forest lake will be lowered by this amount.

In reply to this memorandum the Department of Indian Affairs requested that estimates of cost be furnished covering the work recommended and also an estimate of the cost of constructing a fishway in the dam to allow the fish to go up to their spawning grounds. This fish-ladder the Department stated has been reported by the Provincial Game and Fisheries Department to be absolutely necessary.

Below is given an estimate of cost of the above items:

Painting 36-inch Wood-Stave Penstock.

This work comprises the painting for preservative purposes of the 36-inch wood-stave penstock running from the dam to the powerhouse. It is proposed to apply one coat of hot creosote oil and after sufficient time has elapsed to allow the more volatile oils to evaporate to apply two coats of hot creosote paint prepared by the Sherwin-Williams Paint Company and sold under the trade name of "Rhonal". This treatment of hot oil and then painting with a tar-creosote paint follows the best practice for this class of work and it should be good for the next five to eight years, when the penstock should again be similarly treated.
The estimated cost is as follows:

16 gals. creosote oil @ 80¢ ... $12.80
18 gals. Ebonal Point @ $1.60 ... 28.80
Labor & Brushes ................. 50.00

$91.60

It is recommended that this work be done at an early date.

Damming High Water Channel.

In the former memorandum it is suggested that the high water channel could be stopped by the building of a small dam some 30 feet long across the foot ladder in the narrow section of the channel. This was based on the short inspection made by Mr. Mooney at the time of his first visit. Following the request for an estimate of this work a survey was made which shows that in order to avoid excessive flooding the most suitable location for the dam is a short distance below the entrance from Forest lake, as shown on the accompanying plan.

The dam proposed is a clay filled timber dam, two and a half feet maximum height and some 200 feet long. As there is an abundance of timber at the site and suitable clay available the type of dam proposed is, under the circumstances, the cheapest in cost.

As shown on the accompanying plan the dam consists of two rows of upright timbers driven firmly in the ground, against which are fastened horizontal timbers. The space between these is then filled with clay. In the following estimate of cost it is assumed that the work is carried on under the supervision of Brother Adolph, now resident at the school. It is also considered that the work should be completed in two weeks.

Foreman - Bro. Adolph - 12 days @ $7.00 = $84.00
1 lumber man - 12 days @ 5.00 = 60.00
5 Indians - 12 days @ 20.00 = 240.00
Tools, spikes, etc. - 100.00

$484.00

In view of the present power requirements of the school the need of stopping the flow through this high water channel is not considered immediately pressing. As stated above, the control of the high water channel is 110.5 which reduces the head of the dam to 110.5 and reduces the head from fifteen to thirteen and a half feet and the storage capacity one and one half feet. Even with this reduction in head and storage the power available is in excess of the present power demands and unless there is an exceptionally dry season it is not probable that the school will suffer from any shortage of power.
Fish Ladder.

To install a fish ladder at the McIntosh dam that will enable the fish to pass from Canyon to Forest Lake will be quite expensive. The distance between the two lakes is some 400 feet; the channel connecting them being a flat rock from 70 to 100 feet in width. In a channel of this nature practically no pools occur throughout its length and it will not be necessary therefore to connect the lakes by means of a fish ladder some 400 feet long. This ladder would run from the spillway of the dam at the outlet of Forest lake down the right side of the protrud to Canyon lake. It is estimated that such a ladder, three feet wide and some 400 feet long, with the necessary chambers and baffle boards, will cost between $1,500 and $2,000.

In view of the high cost of installation at this development it might be advisable for the Department of Indian Affairs to again take up with the Ontario Department of Fisheries the necessity of a fish ladder between these lakes. It might be pointed out that before the present dam was built there was an old rock filled timber dam at the outlet of Forest lake with a log chute running from the dam to Canyon lake. This chute was some 300 feet long with a high gradient, the water flowing through the chute at a high velocity. No channel other than the chute was provided and with the high velocity of the water and with a smooth stretch of 300 feet it is doubtful if many fish were able to pass from Canyon to Forest lake by means of it.

Possibly the Ontario Department of Fisheries could suggest a cheaper installation than the one outlined above. In any case it will be advisable that plans of the type of fish ladder approved by the Ontario officials be obtained.

Referring to our conversation yesterday in regard to depth of water in Calumet Connecting Canyon Lake with South Bay of same lake about one half mile west of Redstone Station on Hall Road, Ky., mileage 83.5. I beg to state briefly the agreement made between the Nat. Trans. Co. and the Ontario Government at the time of Construction.

The writer was Division Engineer (51) District "F" at time of construction and planned to cross this two bay of Canyon Lake with a rock fill to be taken from the adjoining mts. Calumet, with a 10 ft. arch.
Calvert at the East End.

The Iron Works of Goddardian over the river limits the logs which had to come out that way and he registered a block with the Ontario Government about our feeling the Bay with rock.

The Ontario Government thereupon demanded that we bridge the gap, which would have meant a span of between two and three hundred feet. (I do not recollect the exact length) The depth from water level to rock bottom being about 85 ft.

After considerable correspondence between the Ontario Government Dept. of Mines Lands & Forest (I think) and with the office of Chief Engineer Nat Trans by Ottawa, or with Major Hodgins District Engineer Kenora, it was shown by the Railway that a very material saving could be made by being allowed to cut the rock for the
fill, which would otherwise have been wasted—and an agreement was finally come to whereby the railway was allowed to make the rock fill, putting in a 10 feet arch culvert and excavate rock on the east side of the bay so as to gain a minimum depth of three feet below low water level.

This arrangement was made as nearly as I can recollect in 1907 or 1908, and the correspondence and plans relating thereto should be on file with the Dept of Roads, Mines & Streets. MEMORANDUM:

- Mr. Attwood -

Re Alleged Flooding on Forest, Whitney, Indian, Alexander and Boulder Lakes.

The writer made an inspection on August 3rd and 4th of the conditions pertaining to the above mentioned lakes as a result of the construction of the dam by the Department of Indian Affairs at the outlet of Forest Lake. Inquiries were also made of those individuals whom it was suspected were responsible for complaints made to the Ontario Government as to their views on the situation. The inspection covered an examination of the shore line of Forest, Whitney, and Indian Lakes, Alexander and Boulder Lakes not being examined as conditions surrounding all these lakes are similar.

Prior to the construction of the dam at the outlet of Forest lake the water level of these several lakes was about elevation 107.0 (assumed elevation) with a maximum flood elevation of 109.5. With the construction of the dam it was intended to raise the level of these lakes to elevation 112.0 and present 112.6. During the flood conditions of 1927 the water level rose to 113.0, but on August 4th of this year the water level was 111.3. In consequence of the raising of the natural level of these lakes some five feet there has resulted more or less flooding along the shores of all these lakes, although generally speaking the shores are rocky, fairly steep and the flooded strip consequently narrow. The standing timber along the flood line has been killed and in places is uprooted and detracts from the appearance of the shore line. Certain sand beaches have been flooded but new ones are being formed.

There is no land bordering these lakes in private ownership and there is only one camp on the lakes, this being the property of Mr. Charles Byrnes of Winnipeg, but Mr. Byrnes has no title to the land where his camp was. Mr. Byrnes was questioned by the writer and was quite emphatic on the following points relating to the increased lake level.

1 - No individual, other than himself, had any interest from the campers' viewpoint in these lakes, he was not complaining and had made no complaints, although he had been forced to move his camp to higher ground, clear the killed timber from the shore and was put to considerable expense with docks.
2 - Fishing was not adversely affected by the increased level of the lakes, the fishing has been getting poorer and poorer for the past ten years due to the permitting of commercial fishing at times in these lakes.

3 - These lakes have very little scenic value and are not favorable for campers so that flooding of the old shore line adversely affects no one.

The writer believes that any complaints made to the Ontario Government come from a few campers on Canyon Lake, which lake lies a mile below the dam at the outlet of Forest Lake. These campers did not take kindly to the establishment of an Indian School in the vicinity. For years these campers have seen the fishing getting poorer and poorer until today fishing on Canyon Lake is practically finished. These campers, principally from Winnipeg, have blamed all their ill will on the establishment of the Indian School and also to the construction of the dam. This Department is not concerned whether the school attracts the parents of the Indian children to the district, whether the Indians are fishing with nets and killing all the game in the district. The school was established with the permission of the Ontario Government and that Government has its own laws governing the protection of game and fish.

The dam at the outlet of Forest Lake was built without a fish ladder. However, during the open water seasons of 1927 and 1928 there has been a natural outflow channel from Forest Lake which gives fish free access from Canyon Lake to the lakes above. This channel will probably be closed in the future but even so, it would not appear necessary to go to the great expense involved in placing a fish ladder in the dam in order to permit suckers to reach the lakes above since there are practically no other fish left in Canyon Lake.

Assistant District Chief Engineer.

Sir,

You will remember that on July 4 last you wrote to the Department of Indian Affairs regarding complaints received in your department as to injury alleged to have been caused by the raising of Forest, Whitney, Indian, Redden and Boulder lakes, due to the construction of a dam by the Department of Indian Affairs at the outlet of Forest Lake. This letter was referred to this department for attention and on July 12 I wrote you stating that Mr. Attwood, our District Chief Engineer, at Winnipeg, had been asked to make an investigation of the matter and submit a report. The report of Mr. Attwood and his chief engineer has been received and a copy is enclosed herewith. This report states that there is no land bordering the lakes in question which is in private ownership and there is only one camp on the lakes affected by the raising of the water level, the owner of which makes no complaint of material injury.

Since receiving this report I have also seen the correspondence between the Department of Indian Affairs and the Department of Lands and Forests at Toronto regarding the purchase of land for the school site and the references made to the development of water-power in connection therewith. Amongst this correspondence there is a letter from Mr. McLean, Assistant Deputy and Secretary of the Department of Indian Affairs, dated August 31, 1924, which quotes certain extracts from the report prepared by Mr. Attwood at the request of the Indian Department on the proposed scheme for the development of water-power at the outlet of Forest Lake. The extracts show that it was intended to raise the level to some extent and so obtain a certain amount of storage to provide dependable power. Mr. McLean replied to this letter on September 5 of the same year in which he is quoted as saying there seems to be no reason why a sale of the land referred to should not be carried out to the Indian Department for the purposes of the Indian school, which seems to imply that the scheme proposed in Mr. McLean's letter of August 31 had been sanctioned by your department.

Mr. Attwood in further correspondence which we have had with him states that it was his understanding at the time surveys were made that a certain amount of flooding would necessarily be caused by the construction of the dam and his plans were prepared for several feet of storage on all these upper lakes, these being the plans referred to in Mr. McLean's letter of August 31, 1924.

Mr. L.V. Rokke,
Surveyor-General,
Department of Lands and Forests,
Toronto, Ontario.
Mr. Attwood further writes in regard to this matter—

"Many years before the school and power plant was built at McIntosh there had existed a dam and log chute at the outlet of Forest lake. This dam raised the level of Forest lake and the adjoining lakes some two or three feet or more above its natural level for the purpose of creating storage and having water available for the log drive and passing the logs from Forest to Canyon lake. In other words this old log dam raised the water level of Forest and adjoining lakes above normal conditions. In building the new dam raised the water very little above the previous levels.

The power site would be of little or no use without some measure of storage. The storage and lake levels now maintained does not damage private property on any of the lakes above and only damages a small fringe of timber at places around the lakes. The school authorities could not afford to clear timber off the flooded area.

The Indian Department have invested a considerable sum of money at this point for the education and betterment of conditions among the Indians in the region. The Oblate Fathers are running the school and under their charge are dorming between 100 and 125 pupils which were being trained and instructed with the ideals of a better livelihood by the Oblate Fathers. This is a cause that is worthy of support, but I happen to know that there are some few individuals in the district who are trying to raise as many difficulties as they possibly can for the school authorities."

From the foregoing explanation I think you will agree that the Indian Department in carrying out the power development has acted in good faith and has not gone beyond a reasonable interpretation of the permission given by your department. The power development is necessary for purposes of the school and is not being used in such a way as to materially affect any private interests.

Your obedient servant,

J. T. Johnston,
Director.

Sir:

I made a personal inspection of the dam at McIntosh about a week ago and as a result have made the necessary arrangements for the repairs to the structure.

Mr. Wallace has requested that we lower the water in the lake before the end of August in order that he may have ample water to float his ties and sluice them through the dam. Rev. Father Perrault, Principal of the McIntosh School, also informs me that he will not be able to secure Indian laborers until about the middle of August, and under the circumstances a start cannot be made on the repairs much before September 1st.

While making an inspection of the dam I also made an inspection of the overflow channel to the west. The matter of blocking this channel was referred to you and to the Indian Department a year or so ago when Mr. Craig furnished a plan with suggested means for blocking the overflow on this channel.

With the water lowered next week the Department will never have a better opportunity to block this channel as cheaply as it can be done when the repairs to the dam are underway. In making an examination of this channel I have devised a much modified scheme to that suggested by Mr. Craig which in my opinion will be quite effective and considerably less. One of the objections to Mr. Craig's scheme was the securing of clay fill for the timber crib at reasonable cost. I estimate that the cost of the work will be $50.00 for the general laborer for labor or approximately $300.00 altogether, and would like to have the authority of the Department of Indian Affairs to proceed with this work when repairs to the dam are underway.

"Many years before the school and power plant was built at McIntosh there had existed a dam and log chute at the outlet of Forest lake. Summary of the Negotiations between the Department of Indian Affairs and the Ontario Department of Lands and Forests for purchase of McIntosh School Site, from material supplied by the Department of Indian Affairs.

The first communication from the Ontario Government in the correspondence relative to the application by the Indian Department to purchase lands for the McIntosh Indian residential school which mentions the water-power appears to be that of May 10th, 1924 from Mr. W.C. Cain, Deputy Minister of Lands and Forests, in which he states,-

"If there is a water power located on these lands the question of the development and disposal of this power will require to be considered and such conditions would be made to apply to the same as would seem reasonable."

In a letter of May 19th from Mr. Rorke, Director of Surveys, to Major Robertson, Mr. Rorke says,-

"Water Powers on Crown lands which will develop 150 horse-power and over are subject to the regulations respecting the disposal of water powers and unless 150 horse-power are dealt with on such terms and conditions as the Minister of Lands and Forests may deem advisable and in any case full information regarding the power is required before an application is considered."

Following this notification that full information would be required, the Department of Indian Affairs wrote under date August 1st of the same year as follows:-

"As previously understood it is of course expected that permission will be granted to the Department to use the small water power on the stream connecting Forest and Canyon lakes. The Department of course does not propose any particular development at this point as power is required merely for local use in connection with the school, such as lighting, water supply, pump etc. A report on this power has been made by C.E. Andrews, Chief Engineer of the Dominion Water Power Branch, Department of the Interior. For your information I submit the following extract from his report,-

Possible Power

Under the maximum regulated head of 17 feet and the estimated low-water flow of 14 c.f.s., the power available at the site is 22 h.p. By the use of the storage, however, it is estimated that the
minimum flow may be increased to 25 c.f.s., although the head will be decreased as the storage is used until it is 14 feet. Under these conditions the estimated minimum power available is 32 h.p.

Use of Power

The amount of power available is sufficient only for small local uses such as lighting, pumping for water supply, sawing wood, etc., where it is at present not used at the site, but it is proposed to establish there a small Indian mission-school, for the purpose of which the power could be very advantageously employed."

This letter was acknowledged by Mr. Cain in the following terms on September 5th:

"Your letter of the 21st ult. in reference to the application of your Department for a parcel of land in Smellie township, and west thereof, district of Kenora, only reached this Department on the 2nd inst. and the plans referred to in your letter were duly received and the necessary declarations as requested made by Duncan Scott, Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, have been placed on file.

There seems now to be no reason why a sale of this land should not be carried out to your Department for the purposes of the Indian School. The total area involved is 325.36 acres and the purchase price at $5 per acre, $976.08."

That is to say, the Deputy Minister apparently was satisfied with the information received in regard to the water-power, which information clearly showed that it was the intention to raise the natural level in Forest lake.

The Order in Council authorising the sale of the land in question was passed on the 2nd October, 1924, receipt of which was acknowledged by the Department of Indian Affairs on November 7th, and in order that there might be no misunderstanding with regard to the rights of the Indian Department as to the water-power proposed to be used for school purposes, the latter was directly drawn to the attention of the Deputy Minister of Lands and Forests in the letter of that date, as follows:

"It is also noted that in your description you have left out the portion excepting the connecting waters between Canyon Lake and Forest Lake. It appears that no reply was made to this letter. In the absence of such reply the Indian Department naturally concluded that the development of the water-power might proceed in accordance with the proposal submitted to the Ontario Government on August 21st, 1924.

Possible Power

Under the maximum regulated head of 17 feet and the estimated low-water flow of 14 c.f.s. the power available at the site is 22 h.p. By the use of the storage, however, it is estimated that the

Water Power Development at the McIntosh Indian Residential School,
McIntosh, Ontario

History of Development.

In 1924 the Department of Indian Affairs decided to erect a residential school for Indian boys near McIntosh, Ontario, the school when completed to be conducted by the Roman Catholic Missionaries of the Archdiocese of Winnipeg, Manitoba and Northwestern Ontario. The site selected bordered on Forest and Canyon lakes on provincial Crown lands. Application was made to the Ontario Department of Lands and Forests for the lands selected, and after some exchange of correspondence, an area of about 350 acres was sold to the Department of Indian Affairs under authority of an order of the Executive Council dated October 2nd, 1924.

One of the chief reasons for the selection of the site chosen was the existence of a natural water-power due to the difference in level between Forest and Canyon lakes. The Mission authorities were most anxious to have this water-power used to supply the electric energy needed at the school for lighting, pumping water and general purposes and the Indian Department agreed to pay for the cost of developing the power so as to provide a dependable supply which could be readily maintained and operated by the school authorities.

In order to carry out the development, the Indian Department requested the Director of Water Power and Reclamation of the Department of the Interior to have surveys made and plans and specifications prepared to determine the extent of the power and the best method of development. This was accordingly done, the plans submitted were approved and work was begun in November 1924, but owing to the difficulty of constructing the concrete dam in winter and to other unavoidable delays, the development was not completed until June 1926.

The intention of the Indian Department to develop this power site was communicated to the Department of Lands and Forests and the method of development by which it was proposed to raise the natural level of Forest lake about three feet in order to maintain a dependable flow of 25 c.f.s. was described by Mr. J.D. McLean, Assistant Deputy and Secretary of the Indian Department, in his letter of August 21st, 1924 to the Deputy Minister of Lands and Forests.

No objection was taken by the Department of Lands and Forests to this proposal and the development was carried out in good faith by the Indian Department solely for the benefit of the Indian schools. As was pointed out by the District Chief Engineer of the...
Dominion Water Power and Reclamation Service in submitting his report on the proposed development, a fuel generating plant giving an equal amount of power could have been installed at much less cost, and the water-power development was decided upon only on account of the urgent requests of the Mission authorities.

Description of Development.

The water-power development at the McIntosh Indian school is situated on the short stretch of river separating Forest and Canyon lakes, the natural head available being about 11 or 12 feet. During earlier years a timber and rock dam was built across the outlet of Forest lake to assist in lumbering operations by raising the lake level, and the dam is in Forest lake and the connecting lakes above it has thus been raised above the natural level at intervals for a number of years past.

In the plan of development as carried out, the assumed natural high water level of Forest lake was raised a maximum of 2.5 feet, partly to obtain storage to give a continuous supply of water to the reservoir, also to obtain a sufficient depth of water at the intake to the penstock and so avoid expensive rock excavation which would otherwise be necessary to ensure a seal at the intake structure. The maximum head available is about 17 feet, the minimum 14 and the power available is 33 horse-power.

The works as constructed consist of a concrete dam about 10 feet high at the highest part and 330 feet long on rock foundation with spillway and non-overflow section, the latter containing an opening for a log chute and a sluiceway for discharging flood waters; intake works, wood slave penstock 3 feet diameter, and 312 feet long, power house 20 X 25 feet with workshop above, and tailrace, details as shown on the accompanying plans.

The machinery in the power house consists of a single horizontal turbine, 30 B.H.P. under 15 feet head at 450 R.P.M. with Woodward governor supplied by Boving Hydraulic and Engineering Company of Lindsay, Ontario; D.C. generator, 17½ K.W. belt driven from turbine supplied by Lincoln Electric Company of Toronto, Ontario; switchboard and accessories.

REGULATIONS RE WATER POWERS.

1. These rules and regulations shall not apply to water privileges which in their natural condition at the average low stage of water have not greater capacity than 150 horse power.

2. In granting or leasing, otherwise than under these regulations, any Crown Lands upon which a water privilege is situated, or which may be flooded or overflowed in consequence of the development and utilization thereof, the said privilege shall be reserved to the Crown, together with such an area of land in
connection therewith as shall in the opinion of the Minister be required for the proper development of the same, and the construction of all necessary dams, weirs, tunnels, races, flumes, sluices, pits and other structures or works, and the erection of buildings and plant for the employment and utilization of such privilege and storing of lands and yards therefor therewith; and there shall also be reserved in each such grant or lease, the right to flood any portion of the lands so granted or leased upon compensation to be made to the owner or lessee thereof by the person or persons to whom such privilege shall afterwards be leased; and the said water privilege, land and right so reserved shall form a separate property and may be dealt with as hereinafter provided.

3. The right to lay out and use such roads as may be necessary for the passage to and from such water privilege or land shall be reserved in all grants or leases of contiguous or adjoining lands.

4. The applicant for a water privilege situated on Crown Lands shall file in the Department of Lands, Forests and Mines, a plan and field notes by an Ontario Land Surveyor of survey thereof; and also a report by a competent engineer satisfactory to the Minister showing:

(a) The location of the water privilege applied for, and a description of the land required in connection therewith.

(b) The height of the fall or rapid, the volume of water at the average high and low stages of same, the estimated capacity in horse-power of the fall or rapid in its natural condition at the average low stage of water, the height of the dams or weirs (if any) which it is proposed to construct, and the increase in the level of the water which such dams or weirs will bring about.

(c) The plan by which the applicant proposes to develop the water privilege, showing the dams, weirs, tunnels, races, flumes, sluices, pits and other structures or works which it is proposed to build or make in connection therewith, the estimated cost thereof, and the form in which the power is to be used or transmitted, that is, whether by direct energy, electricity, compressed air, etc.

(d) The land or lands which would be overflowed or otherwise affected by the raising of the water or the construction of the dams, weirs, sluices, races or other works in connection with the development or use of such water privilege, and the owner or owners thereof.

The applicant shall also show the nature and location of the business, plant or manufactory in connection with which it is proposed by the applicant to utilize the water privilege, and the number of horse power which the applicant proposes to develop and utilize, and shall furnish proof satisfactory to the Minister that the privilege so proposed is required for the applicant's own mechanical or industrial purposes or to supply an actual or anticipated demand for power in the neighbourhood of the privilege.

Provided that the Minister may dispense with the requirements of any of the preceding clauses of this regulation in case the information plans, etc., required to be furnished are already in the possession of the Department of Lands, Forests and Mines.

5. If so required by the Minister, the applicant shall furnish at his own expense all such measurements, plans, specifications, descriptions, levels, profiles, elevations and other information as he may deem necessary for the proper consideration of the application; and the applicant shall also, if required, submit to the Hydro-Electric Power Commission of Ontario the plans and specifications showing the proposed works for the development of the said privilege, and such works shall not be proceeded with until the said Power Commission has approved the same.

6. The applicant shall submit such proof of his financial standing and ability and intention to develop the said water privilege as shall be satisfactory to the Minister.

7. Before the lease of a water power is granted the Minister may require the applicant to deposit with the Treasurer of the Province a sum of money to be named by the Minister, conditional upon the carrying out of the works of construction and development specified in the lease within the period therein named; such sum to be returned to the lessee upon the due fulfillment of such condition, otherwise to be forfeited to His Majesty the King for the use of the Province of Ontario.

8. Upon compliance with the foregoing regulations and upon approval of the application by the Minister in writing he may order a lease of the water privilege to be issued to the applicant upon such terms and conditions and at such rental as may be fixed by the Minister. The rental reserved by any such lease or any renewal thereof shall be payable yearly in advance.

9. No such lease shall be granted for a longer term than twenty years, but the lessee shall have the right of renewal of such lease for two further and successive terms of ten years each upon such terms and conditions as may be agreed upon or may be fixed by the Minister.

10. The right of timber owners and others to drive their logs or timber down any river, stream or other body of water, as now by law established, shall not be interfered with, lessened or restricted by the granting of any such lease; and if any dam, weir or other structure is erected or built in connection with the development of any such privilege, within the object, intention or effect of damaging the water or impeding the flow thereof, full and proper provision, as now by law required, shall be made by the lessee for the safe and convenient passage of logs and timber over and through the same.

11. The lessee under any such lease shall not destroy or obstruct the navigation of any river, stream or body of water.
previously navigable; but shall provide such locks, canals, passages and other means as may be necessary for the proper and safe surmounting or passing of any dam, weir or other work made or erected by the lessee, and as may be required for purposes of navigation by the Government of Canada.

12. In addition to any other conditions or provisions required by the Minister, the lease shall contain conditions and provisions to the following effect:

(a) Requiring the development and use within a period or periods to be named in the lease of a specified quantity or quantities of power or energy, estimated in horse power.

(b) If the quantity of power required by the lessee to be developed within a period or periods therein named is less than the full capacity of the said privilege, upon report being made by the said Hydro-Electric Power Commission to that effect, and also that there is a bona fide demand for power which can be supplied therefrom, the Lieutenant-Governor-in-Council may, by Order-in-Council, require the lessee to develop the said privilege to its full capacity or to such other extent as he may deem proper or requisite within a period or periods of time to be named in the said Order.

(c) For the use by other parties than the lessee of surplus or unused water or power not required by him for the purposes of his business, plant or manufactory, on such terms as may be agreed upon.

(d) Failing an agreement between the parties concerned as to the rates or conditions for supplying power by the lessee to any person, company or corporation, or by any person, company or corporation receiving power from the lessee, and any other person, company or corporation, either party may submit the matter to the said Power Commission, and any Order made by the Lieutenant-Governor-in-Council upon report thereon by the said Power Commission fixing and determining the said rates and conditions shall be final and conclusive and binding upon all parties concerned.

(e) In case of submission to the Hydro-Electric Power Commission as in Paragraph "(d)" herein mentioned, the said lessee on being so required by the said Commission shall produce all books, accounts, records and statements verified by affidavit, showing the cost of constructing, equipping and maintaining the works for the development of the said privilege and delivering the power therefrom.

(f) Upon complaint in writing being made that any municipal corporation is granting bonuses by supplying power, light or heat below cost to manufacturers or others, whether the said corporation is in possession of a water privilege or is receiving power therefrom from or through such lessee, the Lieutenant-Governor-in-Council may refer the matter to the said Hydro-Electric Power Commission, who may dispose of the same in manner provided by Chapter 15 of the Ontario Statutes of 1906, or any amendment thereto.

(g) For the purpose of ascertaining the quantity of power actually developed or capable of development from any water privilege, or the amount of rental payable under a lease thereof, the said Power Commission, or any engineer appointed by it for that purpose, shall have free access to all parts of the works and all books, plans or records bearing on the quantity of power, and may make measurements, take observations etc., and any calculation as to the quantity of power so developed or capable of development made by the said Commission or by such engineer shall be binding upon the lessee.

(h) The power and authority to acquire water powers and works by purchase, lease or otherwise, or without the consent of the owner thereof conferred upon the said Power Commission by Chapter 15 of the Statutes of Ontario of 1906, shall be exercisable by the said Power Commission in respect of any water power leased under these regulations or any works connected therewith.

(i) During the construction of the works for the development of any water power, the said Power Commission or any engineer appointed by it for that purpose shall have free access to all parts of the works for the purpose of inspecting the same and of ascertaining that the construction thereof is in accordance with the plans and specifications approved by the said Power Commission.

(j) For the erection and maintenance by the lessee of a durable and efficient fishway when so required by the proper officer or authority in that behalf.

(k) During the continuance of the lease, the lessee shall keep and maintain all dams, weirs, tunnels, races, flumes, sluices, pits and other structures and works necessary for the development and use of such privilege in good repair and condition, and shall not wilfully or otherwise injure or destroy the same or any part thereof, but at the expiry or sooner determination of the lease, shall leave all such structures and works in good repair and condition, reasonable use and wear thereof and damage by fire and tempest only excepted, and so that their subsequent usefulness shall not be lessened by any act of the said lessee.

(l) At the expiry or sooner determination of the lease, the water privilege shall revert to and become the property of the Crown as fully as if no such lease had been granted together with all dams, weirs, tunnels, races, flumes, sluices, pits and other structures and works made or erected by the lessee in connection therewith, and all buildings erected on land covered by the lease, but the lessee shall be allowed a reasonable time to be fixed by the Minister in which to remove all machinery employed by him in the development and use of the privilege, failing which removal, such machinery shall become the property of the Crown. Provided that where any such buildings or structures are of a permanent
character and necessary or useful for the proper development or utilization of the water privilege, the Lieutenant-Governor-in-Council may upon report in that behalf by the said Hydro-Electric Power Commission pay the lessee by way of compensation therefor and purchase thereof such sum or sums as he may deem proper upon the same being appropriated for the purpose by the Legislative Assembly of the Province.

(m) The lease shall at all times be subject to any general regulations thereafter made by the Lieutenant-Governor-in-Council affecting the construction and operation of works for the development of water privileges or the supply of water therefrom.

13. The Lieutenant-Governor-in-Council may cancel any water power lease issued under these regulations for non-payment of rental within 90 days after the same is due and payable, whether the same shall have been demanded or not, or for failure by the said Power Commission to perform the conditions as to construction of the works for the development or supply of power have not been complied with, or that at any time after the water privilege has been developed, either in whole or to the extent to which the lessee is bound or required to develop the same, the lessee has continuously failed or neglected for the space of one year effectually to develop and maintain the said privilege, either for his own use or that of other persons, unless hindered by unavoidable accident, or that the lessee has failed or neglected to comply with any of the conditions of the lease or any Order-in-Council respecting any matter or thing arising under the lease concerning which an Order is made; and publication of any Order-in-Council cancelling such lease shall be deemed proof that the same has been duly and lawfully cancelled. Provided due notice shall be given a lessee before such cancellation in order that he may have an opportunity of being heard, should he so desire.

14. Where a water privilege is applied for by a municipal corporation for the purpose of supplying water, power, light or heat for the use of the inhabitants of the said municipality, the Minister may issue a lease of said privilege to such corporation if otherwise entitled to receive and hold the same under special terms and conditions as may be recommended by the said Power Commission, and at such rental as he may deem proper.

15. The word "Minister" in these regulations shall mean the Minister of Lands, Forests and Mines or any Minister of the Crown personating the offices of the Minister of Lands, Forests and Mines in his absence or during a vacancy in that office; and the Minister may refer to the Hydro-Electric Power Commission of Ontario any application for the leasing of any water privilege or any matter arising out of such application or any lease made in pursuance thereof, whether hereafter or heretofore issued, for consideration, investigation and report.

16. No water power lease shall be valid or effective unless the same is issued under the Great Seal of the Province, and is signed by the said Minister.

Memorandum,

In conference with Mr. L.V. Rorke, Surveyor General and Deputy Minister, Department of Surveys, regarding unlicensed development of the water power for the McIntosh Indian school between Canyon and Forest lakes, it was tentatively agreed, subject to confirmation by the heads of the Departments interested.

(1) This Department would be willing to pay the annual rental demanded of $1.00 per horse power for the power development, which at the present development of power available of 25 horse power is equivalent to $23.00 per year.

(2) This Department admits its liability to compensation for the flooded lands, the provincial rate for which is an annual rental of 10¢ per acre.

(3) This Department is also liable for timber dues on timber damaged by the flooding.

(4) It is the responsibility of this Department to provide by survey or other means data which will enable a calculation to be made of the extent of the lands flooded.

(5) The Province to permit the Department to have a reasonable number of years to arrange for the removal of the timber and undue stress is not to be made on the removal of the very small stuff and this will particularly apply towards the upper ends of the lakes affected and the Province will not demand that the timber be cut to a ground stump but will be satisfied for it to be removed during the winter by cutting it as closely as practicable to the ice level. Underbrush and stuff which is not suitable for putting into use is to be disposed of in such a manner as will not permit it to be turned into floatage in the lakes and streams, but such of it as is in proper condition for so disposing is...
to be piled on the ice and burned before break up; the remainder to be piled on the land and as soon as it is sufficiently dry to be burned in such a manner and under such supervision as will not endanger forest growth.

In discussion as to the nature of the survey which would be required to supply the information in article numbered 4 above, I first succeeded in getting Mr. Rorke to agree that his Department would not insist on an actual survey of the present water line but that a traverse of the exterior line of flooded vegetation, with occasional offsets to the line of the present water level would be considered sufficiently accurate to estimate the acreage of flooded lands. After further discussion, Mr. Rorke agreed that as his Department would not require a very strict accuracy in the calculation of the area flooded but that a reasonable approximation would be satisfactory, he conceded that if sufficient information could be obtained from aerial photographs, no other survey would be required. Finally it was agreed that should sufficient information not be obtained from the aerial photographs, it would be considered satisfactory for a surveyor appointed by the Province to be accompanied by a representative appointed by this Department, to cruise the shore line of the flooded area, and by means of hand level information obtained on this cruise to prepare sketches which would enable an estimate to be made of the flooded area, the expense of this to be borne by the Department of Indian Affairs.

It will be seen that Mr. Rorke was very reasonable in making these concessions, and it is considered that his Department could have insisted on a traverse along the line of the present water level which I am quite sure would cost the Department over $2000.00. His concession in agreeing to a winter traverse on the ice, with offsets, would reduce this cost to approximately $1000.00. The cost of the cruise finally agreed upon will probably not be in excess of $500.00 and should the aerial photographs, copies of which I am now obtaining from the Civil Government Air Operations Branch, contain sufficient information to convince Mr. Rorke that further survey is unnecessary, we will of course escape any expenditure in this connection, other than the cost of the prints which will be about $2.00.
of the district which were taken in June 1928 support the contention of this Department that the banks of the lakes and streams in the area affected are for the most part of a steep or rocky nature and as a result, except in a few localities, the construction of this dam has affected only a few feet in width of the shore line, that a sufficiently accurate estimate could be obtained by having the district carefully cruised by an Ontario Land Surveyor. It was considered that this surveyor could make a sufficiently accurate estimate by means of sketches estimating the average width, amplified in any places where the areas flooded are of considerable extent by measured offsets and such hand level information as might be considered necessary, it being considered that a continuous chained or transit survey was unnecessary under the circumstances.

It is further understood that you suggest that this cruise will be performed by an Ontario Land Surveyor appointed by you, accompanied by a surveyor or engineer appointed by this Department and that this Department will defray the expense in connection with this cruise. On further consideration, this Department is not only willing to accept these conditions but is willing to accept the results of such cruise made by the Ontario Land Surveyor appointed by you and acting under your instructions without appointing a departmental representative to accompany him.

In connection with the discussion of the subject matter of Condition 5, it is understood that this Department expects to have a number of years in which to remove the timber from the flooded area and that your Department will assist its removal during the winter season and will impose convenient conditions as possible in connection with the raising of the stumps and brush removal.

As it is understood that a considerable portion of the area is in a district which your Department has not as yet surveyed, I am forwarding for your information and use in connection with the proposed cruise six blueprints of the outline of the lakes affected, on a scale of 40 chains to the mile, as obtained by an aerial survey in June 1928. Should it be necessary, I could also arrange to supply you with copies of the aerial photographs of that district which Mr. Watson has already shown you.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Mr. Orr,

Re McIntosh Indian Residential School.

As I discussed with you personally, both here and in Ottawa last year, repairs are required to the edge of the sluiceway section of the dam at McIntosh. It was our intention to have this repaired last year but owing to the difficulties which might have been encountered with one Mr. Wallace, a lumberman operating on the lakes above, and having in mind that your Department had the matter of obtaining a license or authorization for this development up with the Ontario government, the matter of repairs was left over until next spring.

Mr. Wallace is cutting about 100,000 railway ties along the lakes above the dam and will doubtless close the dam at the time of the spring break-up in order to raise the level of the lakes to facilitate the running of his ties into West Lake. It is almost a certainty that there has been increased deterioration of the concrete in the vicinity of the sluiceway and log chute during the present winter. Any increased head against the structure might endanger the whole dam so it is very essential that Mr. Wallace be prevented from accomplishing his purpose.

To carry out the repair work to the dam it is probably essential to obtain the license for this development between now and spring. If this is not obtainable between now and spring it is necessary to secure authority to make such repairs as are necessary to ensure stability of the structure and such authority should include such measures as are necessary to prevent any interference from Mr. Wallace in the successful carrying out of the work.

I would point out that if authorized I would have the repair work commenced and completed soon after the spring break-up so that a considerable portion of the early summer run-off could be conserved. This policy would ensure to Mr. Wallace ample water for his operations as I understand he does not wish to pass ties through the dam before July 1st. He has however shown no inclination to cooperate with the authorities at the school, but to the contrary he has at times sent a gang of employees to the dam and closed the sluiceway over the protest of the Principal of the school, and doubtless will do so again unless prevented.

R. B. Orr, Esq.,
Architect,

Dear Sir,

A short petition has just been drafted and will be mailed to you in due course, in connection with the blocking of the waterway between Little Forest Lake and the South Bay of Canyon Lake near McIntosh, Ontario, at a point where the Indian School is erected. When this dam was constructed a few years ago, no provision was made to take care of the game fish in these lakes, during spawning seasons, with the result that many of them travel to this dam in the spawning season and being unable to get through from one body of water to the other, are either caught by Indians or natives or die in the attempt to get through. At the present time, it is understood that an application is before the Department, presumably from the Indian Department at Ottawa, requesting that repairs be made to the present dam. Would it not be an opportune time to have a fish ladder erected over or through this dam or a satisfactory runway made through, so that fish could navigate the stream at all times, but more especially during the spawning season.

Then there is the question of a right-of-way across this Portage. I would like to point out that this is the only portage connecting Canyon Lake with Forest, Whitney, Edwards Bladder, Boulder and Little Boulder lakes to the sougah and as matters are at present, we are looked on as trespassers by the Indian School authorities, when we travel over this Portage, therefore, I would suggest that you take the matter up with the proper authorities and arrange if possible, for the Government to reserve a strip of land along the creek on the South side, to be used by Lumbermen, Tourists, etc., in travelling between the lakes herein referred to.

Several Inspectors have been shown this situation when at McIntosh but to date nothing has been done that would help to conserve the fish in these lakes. If there is any further information required by you do not hesitate to communicate with the writer. Trusting this matter will have your earnest attention and that we will hear favorably from you in the near future, I am.

Yours sincerely,

(signed) A. W. Lewis.

Sir,

Following your instructions dated February 10th 1930 to make an inspection and report in reference to the lake shores affected by water power development at the Indian School near McIntosh, Ontario, I beg to state that I left Sault Ste. Marie on March 1st, and arrived at McIntosh the following day.

To save time and long walks I had with me a light camp equipment for 3 men to travel the lakes, and acquired the services of an Indian at McIntosh to assist me in packing this outfit on a toboggan. On the evening of March 3rd the Crown Timber cruiser overtook me on Boulder Lake.

Near the Indian School I found a dam of concrete construction, having a length of about 300 feet, which included a spillway at the South end, 45 feet long. The crest of the dam above present water level is 4.5 feet, and the top of the spillway measures 2.5 feet above present water level. Almost adjacent to the North end of the spillway is a gate 8 feet in width, and a few feet North of gate is a log sluice 5 feet in width. Following Northerly along dam from log sluice is a penstock opening, 3 feet in diameter. The end of penstock at head of dam is bedded one foot below surface rock, leaving the top of penstock one foot below the present water level. The depth of water about the gate, sluiceway and penstock is 3 feet.

To arrive at a height of mean flood level that this dam has made from the date of operation, I believe that it was necessary to observe the present water level conditions of lakes in this vicinity, other than those affected by damming. While travelling on the railway to McIntosh I saw many lakes, and it appeared to me that the present water level was from 3 to 4 feet below high water mark. This condition is similar or Canon Lake which takes its waters at the dam from Forest Lake. The high water mark on Canon Lake, which could be seen distinctly in many places, measures 3.5 feet above present water level.

The lakes affected by the dam are, Forest, Whitney, Edward, Alexandra, Bladder and Boulder; also a creek which drains Moose Lake and flows in an Easterly direction for a distance of about 2 miles to Bladder Lake.

At a point on Forest Lake, about half a mile Westerly from the dam, is a rapid, and I am told on good authority that this rapid had a fall of one foot before dam construction. The dam at present is holding back water to barely flood this rapid out, although there still remains a noticeable current here.

Along the Northerly shore of Forest Lake, a distance of about half a mile, from the dam, a by-pass was noted, having a width of about 8 chains. If water was raised another foot above its present level it would make its way to Canon Lake.

Taking into consideration the length and height of the spillway, and the slow gradual rise of cleared land at the end of the spillway, together with the by-pass to Canon Lake, I doubt very much if the dam could hold back water to its total height of 4.5 feet above the present water level.
While travelling the lakes in question, I worked on a 5 foot contour, but was unable to find any traces of tree destruction caused from floods at this elevation. Any tree destruction was found at an elevation of 3.5 feet above present water level, which elevation corresponds with the high water mark of these lakes.

Noted on my plan which accompanies this report are flooded areas due to the effect of high water periods. These areas are swamps and of no agricultural value.

The blue line indicated on plan is a contour 3.5 feet above present water level, and along this contour very little destroyed timber from flooding was found. In a distance of about 60 miles of shore line there would not be more than 500 cords of pulpwood, and some red pine, and cord-wood.

My opinion is, that without the dam the timber along the beaches and around the inner edges of the swamps, would be affected by spring floods, and that this natural condition would not as a rule, kill tree growth, but if water is held by damming, and becomes warmed, it has a tendency to affect the bark by scalding and therefore kills the tree. Flooding of timber in the late fall of the year and water freezing about the tree will also prove disastrous to tree growth.

The present water level conditions of the lakes and at the dam appear to be of sufficient volume to operate the power system for the Indian School, but for logging purposes more water may be required.

About 50 per cent of the shore line of these waters is high bare rock the balance consists of clay and sand shores, and along this in many places, there would be an area equal to about 24 acres affected, together with an area of 399 acres of low lying...
land, making a total area of approximately 423 (four hundred and twenty-three) acres of land affected by the holding of water at the dam above a height of natural water conditions.
