Memorandum: Mr. D. B. Gow.

Re: Dam of Hydro-Electric Plant at McIntosh Indian School.

In accordance with your verbal instructions, the writer visited the Indian Residential School near McIntosh, Ontario on May 29th and inspected the hydro-electric plant at the outlet of Forest Lake that supplied the school with electric light and power. The dam, penstock and powerhouse installation were all examined as closely as conditions permitted and photographs were taken to show existing conditions at sections of the dam where repair work appears necessary.

This hydro-electric plant was constructed in 1925. The main section of the dam, including the log chute and sluiceway sections, was constructed in January and February under severe winter conditions and admittedly the concrete work was poor, although a very rigid structure was poured. During 1930 it was necessary to make repairs to the dam along the non-overflow section to stop seepage under the structure and also to reconstruct eroded sections on the side walls of the sluiceway and log chute openings.

The accompanying plan of the dam and sections has shown on it those areas of the structure where deterioration is such as to necessitate immediate repair work. The accompanying photographs show in part the wearing away of concrete. Damage is most marked at the sluiceway and log chute; due principally to frost action, also to erosion, etc. Although the downstream face was damp near the base, over a considerable area there was no distinct flow through cracks except at a construction joint. Some seepage was evident at the rock near the middle of the non-overflow section of the dam at 2'00. However, there seems to be enough percolation to cause continued destruction of the downstream face of the dam by repeated action of water during each winter season. A few minor cracks have occurred, most likely due to expansion, over the length of the dam, but they do not cause leaks and appear to be of little consequence. Repair work done in 1930 to seal off leakage originating along the upstream base of the dam, has evidently permanently stopped most of the seepage on the shore ends.

The water worn areas of the sluiceway and log chute abutments and dividing pier show the most important deterioration. Water worn areas, however, repaired in 1930, seem to have reinforced sections mostly sound but as the sluiceway were wide open during the inspection, this could not be fully observed. The concrete has so broken away around the slots that stop logs roll and cannot be placed in effective
position. Deterioration in view was mainly of the original concrete which was placed in severe winter weather.

The intake gate has not been operable for three years on account of being jammed. This is believed to be due to concrete being broken unevenly off the upstream face of the dam, on which the gate slides, causing a rough surface over which stops movement of the gate. The worm drive mechanism was broken in an attempt to close the gate and a strong lever was rigged up by the power house operator, but all efforts to move the gate were fruitless. The operator is unable to close off the flow at the turbine as the gates there will not now close sufficiently to stop flow enough for reduction of pressure at intake gate.

The pipe line, while not a part of the dam, should be reported on as it was brought to the writer's attention that rotted places had developed in the wood. These were one half inch deep, three to four inches wide and six to ten inches long in at least sixteen places, all observed in the upper part of the pipe and in the creosoted area. At only two places was water spouting out and this was around a butt joint in the creosoted area on the side of the pipe. It should be observed that the pipe outside is about 300 feet long and last feet of the upper end was painted with special creosote paint and this action only contains the rotted areas. The lower 120 feet is also cut in the open and shows some seepage, at butt joints mainly, while the pipe within the powerhouse seems to be in perfect condition.

The turbine was reported to have lost its best regulative characteristics and some of its power but it is still sufficient to supply the ordinary requirements of the school. It has been found that the wicket gates on the turbine could not be closed.

REPAIRS RECOMMENDED:

1. SLUICES: In view of the repeated breaking down of the water-worn areas, it is considered advisable to install 12" steel channels for the sections upstream from the stop-log slots up to the face and 6" angles on the downstream corners of the slots. These would be drilled and anchored with concrete filled behind in the broken away and adjoining faulty areas. This protection should stop destructive action where, where breaking down most probably begins. The lower wells of the sluices showed deterioration above patched places so that it will be advisable to break away well above water line and place a facing of reinforced anchored slabs from the downstream side of slots and around the ends of the pier and abutments.
2. INTAKE GATE:
This may be best provided with smaller channel guides fixed by countersunk bolts to the present slides or side channel guides. Concrete in the area about the gate should be cut away and refaced, leaving operating clearance for the gate. Operating gears for gate movement require replacement.

3. SPILLWAY:
Upstream face should be repaired with 4 inch slab for distance of at least 10 feet as deterioration has occurred to depth of four inches. The whole downstream face should be cut away to within eighteen inches of top and reinforced concrete slabs anchored in place, sealed at upper edges by expansion joint filler.

4. NON-OVERFLOW SECTION OF DAM:
Upstream face should be repaired with 4" slab to 20 feet from log chutes. Reinforced concrete slab on downstream side is not considered necessary at present as probably backfilling from the north end to near the pipe line thimble with underdrainage provided by tile, would stop most of the deterioration. Pressure grouting by holes spaced at 6-foot intervals should be tried next in order to determine if in this way the dam can be made less permeable.

5. PIPE LINE:
This will require galvanized plates and caulking at each rotated angle. It is claimed the life of the pipe would be considerably lengthened by providing a roof over it; however, this work could be done at any time the dam is closed. At the same time some of the saddle timbers could be replaced. The extent of the rotting of these could not be determined on account of depth of water around pipe at time of inspection.

6. THE TURBINE:
This has run almost continuously for eleven years and it is found the water cannot be stopped running through. The cast iron spindle and bearings are probably in need of repair but cannot be inspected until the intake is closed.

COSTS:
Estimates for this type of work are not readily accurately determined as the actual overlay for material is relatively small and a great deal depends on the indefinite cost of coffin-damming transportation of equipment and material. Repair work in 1930 was done on a similar area of the same dam and cost ran up to $700.00 exclusive of engineering supervision. The present plan is to
COSTS (Continued) use more steel and concrete and it is expected that total costs will be higher than they are now $800.00 should be provided for the work outlined. Details of material needed are appended.

J. T. ROSE,
Water & Power Engineer, Grade II.

Dear Sir:

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 15th instant, authorizing the repair work to the hydro-electric plant of the McIntosh Indian School at the outlet of Forest Lake.

The pressure of other work made it impossible for this office to maintain an engineer on this job continuously, so I planned to recommend that Brother Gauthier be placed in charge of the work. He has had a lot of construction experience and has been on jobs under our direction before, and as his headquarters are at the McIntosh Indian School, he is very familiar with the extent of repairs required. I have discussed the work with Brother Gauthier and he is decidedly of the opinion that our estimate of the cost of the work is greatly underestimated. In common with other lakes in that region, recent heavy rains have raised the lake level greatly, materially increasing the difficulty of unwatering the section of the dam to be repaired. He states that fairly heavy cribwork, with regular cofferdam construction, is essential, and we know that such work is costly and always uncertain. He also states that for over two years they have been unable to close the headgate so as to get at the turbine installation and that many parts of the turbine are worn and must be replaced or rebuilt. The condition of the turbine is apparently more serious than we had figured on. The penstock work is urgent and the repair work rather extensive.

It is apparent that the $1000.00 available for the work will not be sufficient. In fact, it will be advisable to have $2500.00 available for the work to be carried out satisfactorily. The light cofferdam construction we had figured on will not now be possible or advisable.

T.S. Mills, Esq.,
Chief Engineer,
Engineering and Construction Service,
Ottawa, Ont.
I regret that it becomes necessary to ask for more money for this job, but Mr. Rose was not fully advised as to the condition of the turbine and at the time of his inspection low water conditions prevailed and the outlook was for lower water conditions. As the work cannot be accomplished with the funds available we would ask that expenditures up to $2500.00 be provided for before work is initiated.

Yours truly,

(sgd.) D.B. Gow

District Chief Engineer.

Memorandum of an inquiry into the cause and circumstances of the death of Isaac Fisher, pupil No. 81, of the McCreedy Indian Residential School at Birch Creek, who died at Birch Creek School (place) on 11th Feb., 1936.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 17th instant, enclosing a petition from the South Bay Indian Council desiring the Department to appoint a male teacher for their school in place of Mrs. Charles J. Dear Sir,

I beg leave to draw your attention to some facts concerning the Indian schools situated at Roman Catholic missions on Manitoulin and the north shore of Georgian Bay. Many of these, notably the ones at South Bay, Wikwemikong, West Bay, Sagamok and Sheshogwaning, are situated in remote places, far from white settlements and distant from railway communication. It was always difficult to secure teachers with even a small degree of skill for these schools and I will admit that the salaries paid some persons who 'kept school' in these places were quite equal to what they earned.

In August Rev Fr Paquin induced the ladies who have charge of the Industrial school for girls at Wikwemikong to also take charge of these five schools. I have inspected them twice since then and have no hesitation in saying that they are doing well. It is not alone nor even chiefly that the children have acquired book knowledge but more important still, the influence of these ladies has been a civilizing one. They have taught their pupils cleanliness and industry, - or at least have made a good start in that direction for neither of these are subjects in which the Indian makes rapid progress. The girls have been taught plain sewing and other elementary branches of domestic science. The material for this purpose has been provided by the teachers at their own expense.

Dear Sir,

In my capacity of Superior of the Indian Missions of the Manitoulin Island, having the responsibility of the Indian Day Schools located therein, I feel bound to call the attention of your Department to the insufficiency of the salary to its teachers. The teachers at Sheshegwaning, South Bay, and Wikwemikong receive a salary of $200.00. The teachers at West Bay and Sagamok receive a salary of $250.00. These salaries were fixed long ago, when the cost of living was lower than now, when teachers could be had for a lower salary than now, and for teachers of inferior capacity, mostly Indians or Half-Breeds of no training. And your Department must remember what trouble there was in keeping those teachers at their post for any length of time, and what poor results were obtained. It is all different now. The present teachers, as the Inspector Mr. Prendergast must have reported, are ladies of education and training and are doing very good work. No competent teacher can be hired at present for less than $300.00, and to teach in districts affording all the comforts of civilisation. Nothing but a much higher salary would induce them to go and bury themselves among an uncongenial population for ten months, and in an out of the way place, lacking every comfort and convenience. Now that we have teachers willing to do this hard work,

It is but just to pay them an adequate salary. I may add that this voluntary exile of ten months year after year, is made possible for these ladies only by keeping a companion with them; hence the cost of living is made double.

For the reasons alleged above, I respectfully but earnestly request your Department to take such steps and exert such influence as will be necessary to have the salary of the above mentioned teachers raised to the sum of $300.00. If you allow me to make comparisons with salaries paid elsewhere, you will readily see the justice of my request. I find in the general Report of your Department for 1902, that the teachers at Naughton with an average of 4 pupils, at Port Elgin with 8 pupils, at Sheguianah with 7 pupils, at Buzwah with 6 pupils, at Cape Croker with 7 pupils, at Christian Island with 11 pupils, at Sidney with 10 pupils, receive a salary of $300.00. Dear Sir,

In answer to yours of July 31st, I beg to state that Miss Leman, supposed to have been nominated by me as teacher of the South Band school is altogether unknown to me. She was mentioned by name to Mr. Agent McLeod, so as a misunderstanding.

In fact Miss Delhamel is supposed to take the South Bay School exchanging places with Miss Leman. The reason is that Miss Delhamel having been as many years in that lonely village of Winnemikang and having met with some success with the Indians of that place in the past year wished for a change. Some of whom that Miss Leman gets along better with. The Indians of that band, Mr. McLeod says must have notified the Department of the change.

As for the Winnemikang school, the sooner the Department can arrive at a decision if the school is to be kept open or to be closed the better it will be. I am afraid I'll have difficulties to get a good qualified teacher at this time, in case the school is to open. Some of the children of the place have applied to enter the Hamlet here. Individually, we will refuse those who can easily attend their school if it is to close. I sent to Mr. Agent McLeod a complete list of all the school age children with their approximate distance to school and their aptitude to go. The average last year was 10, but it was due to six that were boarding at the school. My opinion is that without...
Indians at the school, the average would be about 5. The Indians of that place are living on their farms. Very few families are close to the school. In my past I am in favor of day schools where it can be had.

Sir:

I have the honour to report that Miss Priscilla Lavallee, teacher at the South Bay Indian School, has informed me that she has had an offer of $550.00 per annum to take charge of a White School, and if the Department does not raise her salary to that rate she will resign at the end of the current quarter.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Scott,

Agent Lewis forwards a Resolution of the South Bay Band approving of an increase in the salary of Miss Priscilla Lavallee from $500 per annum and bonus to $700 per annum and bonus, or total combined salary and bonus of $850. Miss Lavallee has had no prior experience in Indian schools and took charge of the South Bay School on the 1st of September, last. She has no professional qualifications, but has taught 5 years in white schools, and the Inspector states that she is a very satisfactory and capable teacher.

There are 25 children on the Reserve of school age; 13 only being enrolled at the time of the Inspector's visit in September last.

Mr. Lewis states that Miss Lavallee now has an offer of $850 per annum to take charge of a white school, and if he cannot pay her immediately to that amount she intends to resign at the end of the current quarter. The Indians are very anxious that she should stay, and passed the Resolution mentioned above to pay her salary from the Band Funds. This Band has very little interest at their credit and they will receive no interest distribution this fall. At present the $500 salary which she receives is paid from Band Funds, and if the increase asked for is allowed it would have to be provided from our vote for Indian Education.

The Agent states that as this is a very isolated place for a teacher, and, as she has to live among the Indians, it would be difficult to secure a qualified teacher to replace her, and he approves of increasing her salary to $700 per annum, or allowing her a bonus of $150 paid to teachers of Indian schools. He states that there is quite a noticeable improvement in the work of the pupils in the classroom during the time Miss Lavallee has been in charge.

I would recommend this request for an increase of $200 in salary to your favourable consideration, and if it is allowed it should be paid from the appropriation for Indian education and to date from the time of her appointment, September 1st, last.

Sir,

May I ask one or two questions relative to the property of Residence & School, in Indian Reserves.

(1) The Indians here seem to have the idea that, as so much of their money is spent on school & house, a teacher is bound to consult with the council before filling up a requisition for supplies. There is no space on the requisition form for the council to sign, or even give their approval.

(2) That individuals may come on school property and take what lumber they require, because they have paid for it; this was done a couple of days ago; an outhouse was damaged & lumber stolen. A teacher cannot be responsible for property under his charge unless he has some means of protecting that property properly.

(3) That there is a certain rough element here, who go about doing all the damage they can, one day evening, whilst at supper, a large stone was aimed at the house in the dark.

That, because I take in boarders of the unceded band, there being no boarders in the South Bay Band, there is a great deal of slander going on, all falsehoods.

I wish to state clearly that I have as many, perhaps more, unceded band in my school, and that it is absolutely necessary for me to board these children in order to get them to school; they live 4 miles away. In addition, I am helped in the house, and I am about to coach a boarder for the Entrance Examination; this will be the first Indian pupil from this Reservation.

I may also state that the South Bay Band had many opportunities to board with me; they living only 2 miles away.

The councillors of the Unceded Band compel their children to go to school, while the South Bay Band are very lax indeed in this respect, and there is no one appointed to enforce the attendance.

I am very successful as Mr. Lewis can testify, but the chief of the South Bay Band should be notified as to the future conduct of his own band, and not come to the teacher to demand an explanation as to how certain articles for schoolhouse are obtained by whose authority. I am quite willing to remain on here, as I simply love my work & all the children under my charge.

May I expect an early answer?

Your Respectfully,

William H. Floyd, B.A.
I have commenced an English class for the winter evenings, twice a week, in my house, for all ex-pupils. I am choir-master at the church, and have altar boys instruction at my house every Friday evening.

I have given prizes for good work done, in the shape of money, to pupils of this band; in short I have sacrificed a comfortable home-life in a town or city, with a good school, and club, friends, etc., etc., to come here.

Truly then, this is more of a missionary life than anything else, and I am working, strictly, with the pupils of this mission.

They say that too much money is being spent on this school and house, but I may add that I have not even lead pencils to give my pupils to write with; I have only 6 for 16 pupils.

They have been to me to complain of the agent here, and to accuse him of spending their entire money for his own uses.

You will see from the above that, although I am willing, and have promised to stay here, some kind of protective measures must be taken, my relations with regard to the chief, clearly defined, and a promise of future conduct from members of this band.

Sir,

I beg to submit the following for your consideration and further action.

The Indians are demanding an explanation as to how the money is spent, and as to who pays for the furniture lately granted by the department. They consider that I should get permission from their chief and the council before getting any supplies. Furthermore, they require me to place myself under their chief to obey any and all of his commands, as though I was myself an Indian. I am not wanting in humility, but I decline to receive orders from anyone but the department through its agent, Mr. Davis here.

They are jealous of the unceded band here, and as I have the majority of unceded pupils in my school, I must do my duty to both bands as required by my superior.

That I am boarding four pupils of the unceded band is justifiable in view of the fact that these pupils live four miles from the school, and eight miles from the nearest school in the other direction. I, therefore, secure their attendance in this way.

I should, however, refuse to live in such a large house without company of some kind.

I have investigated the past record of this school and have spoken to Miss Lavallée, who taught here last year, and I find that every teacher gets his or her share of persecution from the South Bay band.

The members of this band have lately stolen lumber, and broken up the interior of a poultry house used by past teachers, and wanted me to do so myself; when traced, they simply state that they are paying for everything on school property, and are therefore entitled to loot, ad libitum.

The Unceded Band have begged me to stay on here as teacher, as their children are making such rapid progress in English.

I may add in closing, that I have 12 Unceded pupils, and 11 South Bay band pupils on my register at present.

My policy has been to do everything possible to help these people, I have even been called to visit sick babies of the South Bay band.
I have commenced an English class for the winter evenings, twice a week, in my house, for all ex-pupils. I am choir-master at the church, and have altar boy's instruction at my house every Friday evening.

I have given prizes for good work done, in the shape of money, to pupils of this band; in short I have sacrificed a comfortable life home-life in a town or city, with a good school, and club, friends, etc., etc., to come here.

Truly then, this is more of a missionary life than anything else, and I am working, strictly, with the pupils of this mission.

They say that too much money is being spent on this school and house, but I may add that I have not even lead pencils to give my pupils to write with; I have only 6 for 16 pupils.

They have been to me to complain of the agent here, and to accuse him of spending their money for his own uses.

You will see from the above that, although I am willing, and have promised to stay here, some kind of protective measures must be taken. My relations, with regard to the chief, clearly defined, and a promise of future conduct from members of this band.

MEMORANDUM FOR FILE:

On September 16th, 1922, Mr. W. H. Lloyd called at the Department and made application for an Indian school. His qualifications were good and he was appointed to the South Bay Indian Day School at a salary of $700 per annum plus any bonus provided by law. As Mr. Lloyd was badly in need of funds, we made an advance for transportation expenses.

Shortly after Mr. Lloyd arrived on the reserve, he tactlessly aligned himself with the unceded portion of the South Bay Band and incurred the displeasure of the other faction. Furthermore, he openly took into his own residence boarders, four pupils, one of which was a 15 year old girl. This Department ordered a discontinuance of the practice of taking pupils into the teacher's residence, but Mr. Lloyd's associations with certain Indians continued to be unpleasant.

Early in December, after a wordy combat with two members of the band, Mr. Lloyd was scared off the reserve and he remained in Manitowaning a few days until our agent, Mr. R. J. Lewis, had poured oil on the troubled waters. Our representative reported that, as the teacher could not live in harmony among the Indians, and as he was on bad terms with the missionary, it would be advisable to close the school.

In December the Department gave Mr. Lloyd a month's notice, and, when we learned from our agent that he was about to marry a 15 year old Indian girl, there was directed a definite notice of dismissal as from January 31st. It was hoped that such action would result in an indefinite postponement of the alliance, which, at best, would be unfortunate.

Mr. Lloyd has written several letters to the Department, appealing against our decision; he has interested Mrs. Wilson of the Red Cross Society of this city; he has directed communications to the Minister of Justice and to His Excellency the Governor General.

This Department prepared cheques for Mr. Lloyd's salary and bonus up to the end of the current month - a total of $895. These were directed to Mr. Agent Lewis with instructions to personally supervise the closing of the school and residence, to see that Mr. Lloyd settled any accounts incurred by himself and to have him leave the reserve.

Your Excellency,

I am taking a great liberty in writing to you in this manner, and I am hoping that my letter may be read by you, and that you may use your influence in my case, although you must have more distressing cases which come under your notice.

I am a fully qualified School-master, a graduate in arts, but owing to war disability, I have had to take charge of small elementary schools, but I hope, in the near future, to be able to take up my old work as a specialist in Classics, etc.

I have been very weak and unwell since I came out of hospital, and I was actually a patient at the Christie Street Hospital, Toronto, when Your Excellency visited that institution last year.

Last September, on my return from a visit to my parents in the old country, I was sent down here by the Department of Indian Affairs, to take charge of the above school. The trip, which had been mainly for my health, cost me a great deal of money. I was therefore glad to get into a position on my return. I understood from the officials that my position as teacher was for a year's duration, at least. I therefore did not commence saving any money, and having to supply my own food, etc.
etc. I was barely able to pay my way for the first two months, so that I have practically nothing saved up. During my sojourn here as teacher, I have given myself body and soul to the work before me, I have tried to be warm, generous hearted to all. I had even intended giving myself entirely to this work among the Indians. God only knows how I have tried. But it is generally admitted that I have the most difficult school, and people generally, to deal with. There has been trouble with a small band of Indians, and I may be guilty of lack of tact in dealing with these people. But I was inexperienced among a people of whom I knew nothing, that is the best excuse that I can make. Moreover, I was positive of success and only needed time to work myself into the confidence of these people. Success was apparent already, and 1200 of the Indians have already testified to my ability as a teacher, and only about 20 men are against me. It is pleasing these few men of the South Bay band, that the Department has decided to close this school on the 31st inst. without giving me a chance to have the case investigated, or to find another school, it being the wrong time of the year to find vacancies. I feel hurt, because I gave up a head-mastership to go overseas as a soldier, and now I am about to be thrown out of employment, owing to a few men who have always given trouble to every teacher here, so far.

I am asking for nothing more than justice and fair play, from a government and country which I tried to serve faithfully, and I hope and pray, with all my heart, that Your Excellency may use your influence in having my services retained as teacher, at least until March 31st, or June 31st.

The Department of
The Department of Indian Affairs has written me to the effect that they have nothing to say against my ability as a teacher. I love my work here, and am not working for the salary, but in order to gain experience and so fit myself for the future. This is my first position since the war, and I want to carry on and be faithful in my duties in training future citizens for this great Dominion.

Thanking Your Excellency in anticipation,

I have the honour to remain

Your Excellency's obedient servant.

Sir,

I have the honour to report that I visited South Bay Indian School on the 19th instant, and found that the attendance has been below the standard required by the Department to warrant a school to be continued.

The majority of the pupils attending this school are young and reside a long distance from the school so that during the rough weather they cannot attend, and four of the older pupils will have to be sent to the Spanish Boarding School after the mid-summer holidays as they have lost their mother and there is not any person to take care of them.

A number of the Indian families are removing from South Bay in the near future, and the teacher in charge of the school at the present time has informed me that it is her intention to not remain in charge of the school for another year, so taking all things into consideration I consider it advisable for the Department to close the school during the coming year.

If the school is kept open the Department will have to make a number of repairs in the class-room, in the teacher's living quarters and the fence around these buildings, and then there would be days during the next school term that there would not be any pupils attending.

I would recommend to the Department to close the school for the next year or so, and any children of school age be sent to the Spanish Boarding School.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, May 23rd, 1924.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 20th instant, in which you recommend that owing to the poor attendance the South Bay Indian Day School be closed after the end of the present school year, viz: June 30th, next.

In reply I beg to say that in view of your report as to the number of pupils who will be available and the condition of the building, it is considered that it would be advisable to carry out your suggestion. It is noted that the present teacher intends to resign and therefore it will be necessary to obtain the services of another teacher for the next school year. No action need be taken by you in carrying out the repairs mentioned in our letter of the 20th instant, which were brought to the attention of the Department by the Separate School Inspector in a report on his inspection of this school.

When the school closes, you should arrange to have the building properly secured and all furniture and school material stored. It may be possible to utilize some of the classroom material at other schools, and, if so, you may have the same transferred where required. A list of school material and classroom equipment, as well as any furnishings in the teacher's residence, remaining on hand after any distribution to the other schools is made should be prepared and forwarded for the information of the Department.

The necessary arrangements should be made when the Spanish Residential School re-opens after the summer holidays to have the Indian children referred to by you placed in that school.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

If the Indian Agents were not so much afraid of having a little trouble, and visited the reserves and the schools as it is very likely their duty, Indians would have more confidence in them, and would not apply so often to us, missionaries, in cases that are naturally speaking out of our line.

I know that one must have great patience to deal with the Indians, and must take great pains to do some good to them; but, be it by the religious motive of charity like the missionaries, or only by a motive of pure justice and faithfulness to duty, all who are in charge ought to be able to resign themselves to it.

Besides, is it not greatly desirable that the Agents show to the people that they sympathize with the missionaries, understanding that in them the Government has the greatest and the most devoted assistance for the good civilization of the Indians?

I remain, dear Sir,

Your servant in the Lord.

J. Q. Curtis

Sir,

The chief and the principal men of the South Bay band of Indians in the Manitoulin island assembled together and took the following decision:

As an English lady is coming to teach, the school has to be improved by adding to it: 1) a small shed to protect the entrance door; 2) a second room for the teacher for the purpose of a kitchen 20 x 12; 3) a shed for the wood 20 x 10 x 12.

Besides as we cannot expect that with the small salary that is paid the teacher could provide himself with a cook stove, stove pipe, bed, chairs and table, we want that the Department would approve of the purchase of these articles of furniture, and also of a broom, a pail and some fish.

The expenses would likely be as follows for the material:

1) first shed 5 x 6 x 8 175' lumber and 4 pieces of scantling $1.00

   24 pieces of scantling, 250' window lumber for roof, 360' boards 9' for floor,
   250' for ceiling, 1 board lumber, one window, two doors, and shingles = $1.00
3) windows 640' window lumber $4.00
   nails $1.00 expenses for work at one dollar a day $5.00
4) furniture $30.00

In all $18.00.

Although we think that all this is necessary, if we wish to have a competent teacher, if the Department cannot afford to give us the

I have the honor to report that the School building at South Bay is totally unfit for the purpose for which it is used.

OTTAWA, 2nd August, 1904:

The Deputy Superintendent General:

Mr Agent Sims reports that the school building at South Bay is totally unfit for use and says that it would cost about $500.00 to repair it. He recommends the erection of a new building.

In this connection I beg to refer you to Mr Inspector O'Brien's remarks concerning this building. He visited the school on the 7th June last and reports as follows:

"The schoolhouse is a wretched old log building too small to accommodate the whole attendance properly. In a small corner the teacher keeps her congregation alive. The efficiency with which they discharge their duties and their self-sacrifice and devotion to the reserve would warrant them in asking for more comfortable quarters.

"I would recommend a new building like that at West Bay."

It seems to me that it would be a waste of money to spend $500.00 in repairs as suggested by the Agent. It would be better to put up an entirely new building and I would suggest that the Agent be authorized to submit the question of taking sufficient funds from their capital for this purpose, to the Indians, as they have enough funds to their credit to stand the outlay.

South Bay school building to be similar to Congo Bridge School, but to be six feet longer. See File - 280686 for Congo Bridge building.
Specifications for a School House to be erected on the South Bay Indians Reserve, Manitoulin Island, Province of Ontario.

To be of one story, 50 x 16 feet, with a porch 10 x 8 feet.

Foundations:
To be of Cedar or Tamarack posts, 4 feet long, sunk into the earth to the depth of three feet six inches, and to be not less than 10 inches in diameter, and perfectly sound, to be cut off evenly at the top to admit of the sills of the building resting thereon, also four posts to be sunk of equal length and dimensions for longitudinal centre sill.

Sills and Joists:
The sills to be 4 x 6 inches halved at corners, with centre sill also halved at ends and let into front and rear sills, the whole well spiked together, and to the posts with 3 inch spikes or oak tree nails.

The joists to be 2 x 8 inch sound pine or hemlock or spruce, set two feet apart well nailed to sills.

Walls:
To be 4 x 4 inch scantling at corners and door and windows, the rest of the scantling 3 x 4 inch stuff set at 12 inch centres, all firmly braced and well nailed to the sills and roof plates of double 2 x 4 inch well jointed.

Roofing:
The rafters to be 6 x 4 inch pine notched at roof plates and well nailed thereto and together with tie or collar beam 1 x 6 inches firmly nailed to the rafters with king lap 9 x 1 1/2 inch to give solidity to the ceiling rafters, to be set 1 1/2 feet centres.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6222, file 473-5, part 1)
Roofing:-
Cover the rafters with 1 inch boards and a layer of tarred felt paper over, then shingle with No. 3 shingles set 5 inches to the weather, and surmount with weather boards with 3 inch circular roll.

Flooring and Ceiling, &c:-
Floor to be built of 1 1/2 inch stuff, tongued and grooved blind nailed, without shakes or black knots. The ceiling to be 6 x 2 inch stuff scantling well nailed to rafters and king tie. A small raised platform, raised on 3 x 6 inch joists set on the floor of the school and covered with 1 1/2 inch flooring and nosed. Platform to be 5 feet by width of the building.

Door and Windows:-
Provide and fix six sashes 1 1/2 inches in thickness to receive 18 x 15 inch glass, prime before glazing, bed point and putty. Two paneled doors 7 x 3 feet, two inches in thickness, hung with three inch butt open to outside. Furnish one American 6 inch lock with suitable furniture and two keys. The windows to be English, with ordinary stops and fastenings. Glass to be threaded and weathered, finish door and windows with five inch plain facings.

Porch:-
The floor, walls and roof of the porch shown on the drawing are to be constructed the same as the main building.

Front Platform:-
Provide and fix a platform and steps to the entrance door floored with 1 1/2 inch stuff.

Chimney:-
Build with hard burnt brick a chimney and stack as shown on the drawings, firmly frame the support timbers into 4 x 4 inch studs and bolt thereto, and make a square topped frame covered with 3 inch plank.
Chimney:
plank on which set the chimney, and also support chimney at collar beams, well purge the flue throughout leave small hatch opening in ceiling 18 X 30 inches with hinged cover.

Top the chimney as shown on the drawings, and fix the requisite flashings around chimney.

Skirting:
Skirt with 1 inch tongued and grooved stuff 4 feet high, after one coat of plaster has been put on, and cap with 2 inch rounded nosing and 1 1/2 inch bevelled strip along floor.

Cover studding outside with a good layer of tarred paper well jointed, and then cover with clap boards firmly nailed to studs, and finish around doors and windows as shown on the drawings, also with base angle and weather boards.

Plaster:
Ratten lath and plaster the ceiling with two coats, including sand finish. Lath and plaster as above the side of the school and also the chimney. Plaster to be made of good stone lime and clean sharp-sand and clean water, with a good proportion of cow hair, mixed thoroughly together.

Painting:
Knot, prime and paint with two coats of Sherwin and Williams Paint, or (if this cannot be had) with good whitewash and boiled Linseed Oil, the inside dressed work, (not the floor) mixed with any suitable colour chosen by the officer in charge of the work, and for the outside work also paint the sides of the building with two coats (not the roof) but the weather boards, roll and pinnacles.

Clothes Hooks:
Fix suitable strong clothes hooks where directed upon battens 5 X 1 1/2 inches, thirty in number, 5 feet from the floor.

I have the honor to acknowledge receipt of your telegram dated 21st instant as follows: "Advise contractor Berry Department requires immediate performance of contract for school house as same is urgently needed."

I beg to report that since awarding the contract to Mr. Berry I have repeatedly urged him to push the work forward in order to have the building completed before the bad weather set in.

He assured me before I asked the Department to accept his offer that he would commence the work the following week. I have just returned from interviewing him personally and he informs me that he deeply regrets the delay but that it has been caused by matters entirely beyond his control that the workmen who agreed to go right on and do the work have disappointed him and that it took longer time than he figured on to get the materials together.

He has given me his assurance that the work will now be commenced without delay and that he will have it rushed to completion.

Regretting the delay in this matter but assuring you that I have done everything I possibly can to hurry matters up.

I have the honor to be

Sir

Your obedient servant

Frank Pedley Esq
Deputy Superintendent Gen'l of Indian Affairs
Ottawa, Ont.

The Deputy Superintendent General:

Mr W.J. Berry of Providence Bay tendered for this building last fall at the sum of $525.00 and his offer was accepted. Sir,

The teacher of the South Bay Indian school in her report for the past year states that there is no foundation and hence the building is going to ruin.

The Department would like to have a report from you on the condition of this building with recommendations as to repairs that are necessary. Kindly attend to this as soon as possible so that any work may be done during the approaching summer holidays.

Sir,

Referring to Official letter of date 9th April last asking for a report on the condition of the South Bay school with recommendations as to the repairs that are necessary to the building.

I have the honor to report that the building does require a stone foundation in the worst way and it will be necessary to raise the building one foot when the foundation is being put in as one end of it is very close to the ground and every spring the snow backs up around it and water runs through the school room. The spot where the school is built is under a large hill and the ground behind it is very wet during the Spring freshet. I had a practical stone mason look over the building and he offers to do the work of putting in the foundation, raise the building one foot, build abutments under the centre of the school of stone and complete the whole work of foundation including materials for the sum of $150.00. The name of the mason is Mr. Thomas Pollard and I would most respectfully recommend that he be given the contract to do this work for the sum above stated. It will be some time yet before the work could be proceeded with as the weather has been so wet that the roads around South Bay at the present time.

are not in a condition to haul stone on but if the Department decide to have the work done it would be well to authorize same at once in order that the contractor may make arrangements with the Indians to quarry the stone and get it on the ground as soon as the roads will permit. There will probably be some plastering to do to the interior after the building has been raised as the plastering in several places is showing signs of weakness. 158-16 Sir,

Referring to official letter of 20th Instant authorizing certain repairs to the South Bay School and asking for a resolution of the band authorizing the expenditure from the capital funds.

I have the honor to report that it is an utter impossibility for me to get a resolution from this band at this season of the year as they are nearly all absent from the reserve and will not return till some time in the fall and I very much fear that this band will not pass any such a Resolution. The South Bay Indians are very few in number but they are furnishing education facilities for members of other bands who reside near school and they are constantly complaining of this.

When they passed the Resolution in 1904 authorizing the erection of the school building they did not receive any interest distribution for several times and there was very great dissatisfaction among them on account of this so that with this fact before me I am positive that they will refuse to pass a Resolution authorizing any further expenditure from their funds. On looking over the last quarterly return from the South Bay school I find there are 23 Pupils enrolled therein out of which there are only 5 children who really belong to the South Bay Band. Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 27th Sept., enclosing requisitions for supplies for the South Bay School.

In reply I beg to say that the stationery asked for will be ordered from the Government Stationery Office and you may purchase the yarn, wool, crochet hooks, brooms and combs asked for.

You may also purchase six shades for the teacher's residence and lumber for the making of the kitchen cabinet or cupboard.

The sum of $10.00 will be allowed for the purchase of material for instruction in domestic science to the girls.

You may supply Miss Leush with sufficient paint to paint the inside of the old building, upon condition that the work is done by the boys of the school.

Mr. MacKenzie of this Department, who recently visited this school, reports that a new box stove is needed and you may purchase one similar to that installed at the Wikwemikongising School and have it jacketed in the same way. It is understood that there is an Indian on the reserve who is competent to do the tinsmithing work and you may let him have this job.

Six outside blinds for the protection of the windows.

Wm. McLeod, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Manitowaning, Ont.
windows of the teacher's residence may also be furnished. The teacher has also asked for a strip of oilcloth and three chairs for use in the dormitory upstairs. These you may purchase.

As it is the intention of the teacher and her companion to keep during the winter months a number of the children who reside at a distance from the school you may purchase for them two single iron beds and mattresses. These should be inexpensive, but of a good serviceable kind.

It is noted that the contractor who excavated the cellar for the addition to the teacher's residence did not remove the clay from the yard and I have to ask you to be good enough to obtain an estimate of the cost of having this moved across the road to the plot of ground which it is proposed to use for a school garden.

In connection with the proposed garden, if the Indians will complete the clearing of at least half an acre in the lot directly opposite the school-house, the Department will next spring be prepared to provide a suitable wire fence. I have to ask you to be good enough to submit an estimate of the cost of the fencing for half an acre.

You may also have two saw troughs placed on the addition to the building, as arranged for by yourself and Mr. MacKenzie.

Your obedient servant,

(Signed) S. Stewart
Assistant Secretary.

Sir,

I have the honor to enclose herewith an account in favor of Charles S. King amounting to $15.00 for labor at South Bay School and erecting a flag pole. I had no authority to have the flag pole erected, but the Department sent the school a flag and it was necessary to erect the pole. The doors and windows of the school and teacher's residence had to be repaired, and the fence around the school and garden, also the residence had to be banked around on account of the cellar filling with water in the wet weather. BLACKBOARDS.—Some of the boards on the side of the room should be placed lower down so that the small children could write on them.

Water Closets.- They need repairing.

The water runs down from the hill into the woodshed and freezes to the depth of three feet and the consequence is that the wood from the shed cannot be used during the winter time, the door being frozen up, etc. I would suggest that the shed be raised up so that the water might run under it. Sir,

Mr. Inspector Finn in his report on the South Bay Bay School states that the closets need repairing and that the water runs down from the hill into the woodshed and freezes to the depth of three feet and the consequence is that the wood from the shed cannot be used during the winter time, the door being frozen up. He suggests that the shed be raised up so that the water might run under it or that the water be turned away from the buildings by putting a ditch on the side of the hill above them.

You will be good enough to give an estimate of the cost of having the necessary repairs made to the closets.

Kindly state which you consider would be the better way of keeping the water from running into the woodshed and give an estimate of the probable cost of having the work done.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 31st ultimo in reference to repairs to closets and shed at the South Bay school, and in reply to inform you that the repairs to the closets may be carried out at the estimated cost. The shed should also be put in such condition that the water will not interfere with the opening and closing of the door or the procuring of wood therefrom.

The Department has no profile of the school site to refer to, but I am of the opinion that it should be an easy matter to board up the bottom of shed on the high side to prevent the water entering the shed and if necessary to raise the grade of shed floor with earth or stone and provide a door opening on a side where the ice cannot accumulate. If this is possible and can be economically done, you should attend to this at the same time as the repairs are being made to the closets.

The expenditure, on account of the shed, should not however, exceed $10.00.
